I'd advise them to take accounting courses, do a lot of reading about investments, and gain as much business experience as possible. They should also talk to people in business to learn what makes their operations tick and where they face challenges.
How will the recipients of large charitable grants from your foundation get the liquidity they need without driving the stock price down?

I don't think selling a small percentage of Berkshire's stock will materially affect the price. For example, if my foundation had to sell 5% of its holdings each year, that's only about 2% of Berkshire's total capitalization. I believe the market can absorb that without a significant impact on the stock price.
Do you think the annual sale of Berkshire shares to meet the 5% distribution requirement of your charitable foundation would have a significant impact on the stock's price?

No, I don't think so. The prospects of the business, not the sale of a relatively small amount of stock, drive the price. If the price is affected by such a small sale, it might even be a healthy sign that the market is working properly, rather than being artificially propped up.
You mentioned a shareholder who died and had 3/4 of 1 percent of the company. How quickly was their stake sold?
That stake was sold in about six weeks, and it raised around $250 million at the time. It was a pretty quick process, all things considered.
Do you think the price of Berkshire's stock would be significantly affected if a larger percentage of shares were traded each year?

I don't think so. If our businesses are sound and worth money, the stock price shouldn't be drastically different whether 3 percent or 10 percent of shares trade annually. It's the underlying value of the businesses that matters, not the trading volume.
Does the book 'Buffettology' by Mary Buffett accurately represent your investment philosophy?

Well, I'd say it gets at the investment philosophy in a general way, but it's not the book I would've written. I think you can get more of our philosophy from reading Berkshire's reports, to be honest.
Is there a book or resource that you would recommend for someone looking to understand your investment philosophy?

Actually, I think Larry Cunningham did a great job of organizing our philosophy into a coherent presentation. His work, which was presented at the Cardozo School at Yeshiva, is probably the best resource if you're looking to understand our approach.
What was your thinking behind selling Disney in the 1960s?
Well, I'd say selling Disney in the '60s was a huge mistake. I should have been buying more, not selling. It's a decision that, in hindsight, doesn't make much sense to me.
Did the advertising companies you sold in the 1970s perform well after you sold them?
Yes, the ad agencies did very well after we sold them. It's a pattern I've seen with many of the businesses we've sold - they tend to continue doing well and even increase in value over time.
Do you think companies like Coke and Gillette will benefit from increased prosperity in the Third World?

Yes, I do. In fact, I believe they'll be helped by a great increase in prosperity in what is now the Third World. Their products have demonstrated an ability to 'travel well' around the world, and people crave them, which gives me confidence in their potential for growth internationally.
Do you think the international aspect of your top holdings will lead to faster growth outside of the US?

Absolutely. I think a company like Coke, for example, will grow faster outside of the United States than in the US. The same is true for Gillette, and possibly American Express. This international growth potential is something we factor into our evaluation of these businesses.
Do you encourage subsidiaries to use each other's products?

I leave it up to the management of each subsidiary to decide what's best for their operation. If they think using another Berkshire subsidiary's product makes sense, that's fine, but we don't dictate it. For example, some of our subsidiaries accept American Express, while others don't.
Can managers from one subsidiary, like American Express, initiate discussions with managers from another subsidiary?
Absolutely. If Harvey Golub at American Express wants to talk with managers at any of our other operations, we're all for it. We encourage that kind of collaboration, but we don't force it.
How do you approach decision-making for subsidiary managers at Berkshire?

We give our subsidiary managers the autonomy to make their own decisions, including choosing vendors. We believe that if we start making decisions for them, they'll no longer be responsible for the operation, and that's not how we want it to work. They're responsible for their businesses, and they should do what's best for their subsidiary.
What happens when people try to bypass your managers and get you to dictate decisions, such as choosing a specific advertising agency?

It doesn't work that way at Berkshire. People can try to write to me all they want, but I'm not going to second-guess our managers or tell them what to do. They need to deal directly with our managers, and if they can't convince them that their service is the best choice, then that's just the way it is.
What's your philosophy on inheritance, and how do you think your wealth should impact future generations?

My philosophy is that I want my kids to have enough so they can do anything, but not so much that they can do nothing. I feel lucky to have been successful, and I don't think that luck should enable future generations to do nothing. I want them to have the freedom to pursue their passions, but also to have a sense of purpose and responsibility.
Do you think your success is solely due to your own abilities, or do you acknowledge the role of luck and circumstance?

I acknowledge that luck and circumstance played a big role in my success. As I said, I was 'wired the right way at the right time in history' to do well in this market economy. And let's be honest, if I were born thousands of years ago, I'd probably be someone's lunch! So, I don't think my success is solely due to my own abilities - I think I was just fortunate to be in the right place at the right time.
Do you think people are often ruined by inheriting money?

I don't think that's the case. As Charlie said, few people are ruined by money. In fact, many people who end up in trouble would have found a way to get there regardless of their wealth. It's not the money that's the problem, it's the person.
Should individuals have a choice in how they distribute their wealth after they're gone?
Absolutely. Charlie and I seem to be on the same page here - once any necessary taxes are paid, it's up to each person to decide how they want to handle their estate. I think that's only fair.
What conditions do you think need to be met for the current valuation to be justified?

Well, I've mentioned two big ifs, and I mean exactly what I say - if those conditions are met, I think it's not overvalued. One of them is that corporate earnings, at present levels, are likely to be maintained. That's a key assumption, and I don't think it's obvious that's the case.
Do you think it's easy to determine if the current valuation is justified?
No, I don't. It's very tough at any given time to look forward and know what level of valuation is justified. You can spot some danger signs, but making a call on valuation is a tricky business.
Does the percentage increase in Berkshire's book value still track pretty well with the percent increase in intrinsic value?
Yes, the two have tracked pretty well over the years. In fact, I'd say our market price has tracked intrinsic value more closely than about 90% of the companies we've looked at.
Has the spread between book value and intrinsic value narrowed due to the addition of more owned businesses like GEICO and FlightSafety?

No, the addition of those businesses hasn't significantly changed the relationship between book value and intrinsic value. If anything, our stock price has tracked intrinsic value 'better than most' companies, even with the changes in our business mix.
Do you think the market price of Berkshire's stock always reflects its intrinsic value?

No, I don't think it does. In fact, I've said that the market price will sometimes outpace the change in intrinsic value and sometimes lag behind. It's not a perfect system, but we believe Berkshire's stock tracks its intrinsic value better than most companies.
If you and Charlie Munger were in charge of setting the stock price, how would you approach it?

If we were running Berkshire as a private company and setting the stock price once a year, we'd try to set it as close to the intrinsic value as possible. That would be the ideal - a perfect tracking of the stock price to its true value. But, of course, that's not how the market works.
You mentioned corporate tax rates in Japan and the United States. Can you compare the two and speculate on potential changes?

Well, as I said, corporate tax rates are quite high in Japan, while here in the US, they've come down from 52 percent to 35 percent. It's possible that Japan could follow suit and lower their rates, which could give corporate profits a boost. But I don't have any inside information on that - just what I read in the papers.
How do you and Charlie Munger evaluate corporate culture, especially in foreign countries?

Charlie hit the nail on the head - we look for companies where the culture prioritizes all stakeholders, not just shareholders. It's like trying to read a person's character - you want to know if they'll make tough choices that benefit everyone, or just look out for themselves. And as Charlie said, it's tougher to gauge that in foreign countries, but we do our best to get a sense of it.
Why don't you think calculating the correlation coefficient between Berkshire Hathaway's daily performance and the S&P 500's daily performance would be useful?

I don't think it would be useful because it's an historical correlation coefficient, and I'm reluctant to have people place weight on it. Past performance doesn't necessarily dictate future results, and our edge in the past is not relevant to today. It would be misleading to publish or make calculations based on it.
Would you be open to someone else calculating and sharing the correlation coefficient between Berkshire Hathaway and the S&P 500?

We have no objection to anybody wanting to make that calculation. However, we don't think it would be of any utility to us, and if we don't think it's useful, we don't want to put it out for shareholders as being of possible utility.
Have you or Berkshire ever made a successful pure real estate investment?

Honestly, our record in real estate is pretty dismal. We've had a 'certified record of failure' in this area, and I think it's safe to say that we've been demonstrably foolish in almost every real estate operation we've touched.
Is your lack of success in real estate due to a circle of competence issue?

I'd say that's a big part of it. We just don't have the expertise in real estate that we do in other areas, and it's shown in our results. We've learned that it's often better to stick with what we know and invest in fields where we have a competitive advantage.
Who do you give credit to for the strong American economy?

I give credit to several individuals, including Volcker, Reagan, Greenspan, Rubin, and Clinton. I think Clinton's first tax bill, which passed by just one vote, was particularly important, and I suspect he was listening to good advice from Rubin.
What is your opinion on the current state of the American economy?

I think the economy is doing well, with healthy growth and stability over the last five years or so. I'm pleased with the overall direction, and I think there's been some good decision-making along the way.
What is the scuttlebutt approach and how does it help in understanding an industry?

The scuttlebutt approach is all about gathering information by talking to people in the industry. It's like gathering pieces of a puzzle from those who have firsthand experience. By listening to what they have to say, you can learn a lot about the industry's strengths, weaknesses, and trends. It's an independent perspective that helps you understand the industry better than just relying on your own preconceived notions.
Can you give an example of how you've used the scuttlebutt approach in your investment decisions?

I recall using the scuttlebutt approach when we decided to keep American Express after exchanging our Percs for common stock in 1994. I talked to Frank Olson, who was running Hertz Corporation at the time, and he gave me valuable insights into the strengths and weaknesses of the American Express card. His perspective as a user of the card and his experience in consumer marketing were incredibly helpful in making our decision.
What do you think about Berkshire Hathaway's reported earnings, specifically the drop from 1996 to 1997?
To be honest, I think the final bottom line GAAP reported earnings mean absolutely nothing to us at Berkshire. We don't put much stock in them.
Would you or Charlie Munger consider doing commercials for Berkshire's subsidiaries, like See's candies or Coca-Cola?

Ha! I think Charlie summed it up well - we aren't old enough to be really good in a commercial. But in all seriousness, I don't think you'll see us doing any commercials like Dave Thomas did with Wendy's.
What do you consider when interpreting the look-through earnings that Berkshire publishes?

When interpreting our look-through earnings, I consider factors like whether we've had a super-cat occurrence - that's insurance speak for a massive catastrophe - or if one of our businesses, like GEICO, had an unusually good year. We try to mention those factors so people can get a clearer picture.
How do you measure the progress of Berkshire, and what role do capital gains play in this assessment?

To measure our progress, I look at the change in book value compared to the S&P, and our look-through earnings give some insight, though not perfectly. Capital gains, on the other hand, don't mean much to me in terms of measuring progress. We can report them in any number, and while the IRS cares about them - we might even send them a billion dollars this year - they don't reflect our real performance.
What is Berkshire's current after-tax cost of running the operation as a percentage of capital value?

Our after-tax cost of running the operation is down to a half a basis point of capital value. To put that into perspective, it's significantly lower than what many mutual funds are paying - they're at 125 basis points, which is 250 times our overhead ratio.
Do you think it's possible to reduce Berkshire's overhead costs even further?

Charlie thinks we can get a lot lower, and I agree with him. Although, I'm not sure if our board of directors would be willing to take a pay cut to $500 a year from $900 - but that's a different story.
How do you determine if someone is honest or not?

Well, I think Charlie and I can do pretty well in spotting honest people, but we need some evidence of their behavior in front of us. We've found that after working with someone for a few months, we can get a pretty good sense of how they behave. It's not an exact science, but we've had a high batting average in terms of figuring out who's trustworthy.
Can you give an example of someone who demonstrates honesty in their behavior?

Tom Murphy is a great example. He's always bending over backwards to make sure the other person gets the better end of the deal. Now, that doesn't mean he's not competitive - he wants to win if we're playing a game for money! But he's just one of those people who doesn't take credit for things they didn't do, and that's the kind of honesty we appreciate.
What is your approach to evaluating stocks, and how do you decide what to buy?

I look at stocks as parts of businesses, not just little items on a piece of paper with charts attached. We evaluate individual businesses, their management, and whether we can buy them at an attractive price. If it makes sense for Berkshire in terms of value, we'll buy it. If not, we wait.
Do you believe it's possible to predict the stock market's movements and make money from it?

Honestly, I know of no one who has been successful at predicting the market's actions and made a lot of money from it. What I do know is that people have done well by picking good businesses and buying them at sensible prices. That's our strategy, and we stick to it.
When was the first hedge fund set up, according to the report you read?
Well, the report claims the first hedge fund was set up in 1949, but I'm here to tell you that's just not true. I've seen that claim repeated many times, but it's inaccurate.
What type of investment entity did Ben Graham and Jerry Newman have, and how does it relate to modern hedge funds?

Ben Graham and Jerry Newman had what I'd call a classical hedge fund back in the 1920s. It was an investment partnership, and I even worked for their company, Graham-Newman Corp. Their setup, with a 20 percent participation in profits, is exactly the sort of entity that today we'd call a hedge fund.
Why would you issue a fairly-priced bond when you can use low-cost float for financing?

Honestly, right now, I wouldn't. Our insurance companies have a terrific experience with the cost of float, making it the best form of financing for us. We've got more money than we know what to do with, so issuing a bond just isn't something we're interested in at the moment.
What makes the float generated by your insurance companies attractive for investing?

It's the low cost. We've been fortunate to have a terrific experience with the cost of float in our insurance companies. This low-cost float is essentially cheap financing, which is ideal for investing. Most insurance companies don't have this advantage, but we do, and we're developing it as fast as we can.
Under what circumstances would you consider borrowing money, and how much would you be willing to borrow?

I'd consider borrowing money when we've utilized all our funds from float and retained earnings, and we still see attractive investment opportunities. In such cases, we might borrow moderate amounts of money, even though it would cost us more than our float. However, we'd never borrow huge amounts of money.
How does the cost of borrowing compare to the cost of using float, and what's the implication of this difference?

Borrowing would cost us more than using our float, but it would still provide incremental earnings. Think of it like buying a slightly more expensive ticket to a game you really want to attend - it's still worth it if you think the game will be a winner.
You mentioned the auto and airplane industries as significant in the first half of the century. Did investing in these industries guarantee wealth?

No, not at all. In fact, I said very few people got rich by riding the back of the auto industry, and even fewer made money in the airline industry. It's a great example of how a marvelous industry can be a terrible business when it comes to making money.
What's the key takeaway from your discussion about the auto and airplane industries?

The key takeaway is not to equate the prospects of growth for an industry with the prospects for growth in your own net worth by participating in it. Just because an industry is going to grow and change the world, doesn't mean you'll make money investing in it.
What makes investing in Chinese companies with high growth rates and low valuations an interesting opportunity for you?

It's the combination of strong earnings growth, like 20 percent per annum, and low valuations, such as five times earnings, that makes it interesting. If I can find companies with high-quality earnings and the potential to continue growing, that's a compelling investment opportunity.
Why do you think it might be challenging for Berkshire to invest in Chinese companies, despite their potential?

My guess is that the field of Chinese companies that meet our investment criteria - strong earnings growth, low valuations, and high-quality earnings - is just not large enough for Berkshire to make a significant investment. We need to find opportunities that can move the needle for our portfolio, and it's not clear that these Chinese companies can do that.
Do you prefer negotiated purchases over buying stocks, and why?

I do prefer negotiated purchases, but that's not because I dislike buying stocks. It's just that in a negotiated purchase, we're more likely to find what I call a 'fair deal' under today's circumstances. You never get that kind of buy in a negotiated purchase when you're buying the entire company, but when buying stocks, you can sometimes find a good price for a portion of a company, like I did with the Washington Post Company back in 1974.
What's your outlook on making significant investments over the next five years?

I think we'll do both - buy entire businesses and take big positions in the stock market. Charlie Munger agrees with me on this. We're not finding a lot of opportunities in either arena right now, but I'm hopeful that over the next five years, we'll be able to make some smart investments in both areas.
What is Charlie Munger's view on the profits made by pharmaceutical companies?

Well, I think Charlie summed it up pretty well - he believes the country has been wise to allow pharmaceutical companies to make significant profits, even if they seem 'almost obscene' at times. He thinks this system has served us well, given all the incredible inventions and advancements that have come out of the industry.
What specific example does Charlie Munger give to illustrate the positive impact of the pharmaceutical industry?

Charlie mentions the development of antibiotics as a prime example. He notes that in his lifetime, these inventions have prevented a tremendous amount of death and family tragedy, which is a pretty powerful testament to the industry's contributions.
Why do you buy shares in so many companies, and what's the typical amount you purchase?

I buy a hundred shares in a great many companies because I want to be a registered shareholder and receive their mailings promptly. It's not about investing a lot, but rather about staying informed. I figure if I'm interested in one company, I should also keep an eye on its competitors, so I buy a hundred shares in those as well.
What do you do with these shares after you've bought them, and do you often sell them?

To be honest, I very seldom sell any of these shares. Even if I lose interest in a company, I tend to just keep the shares. I'll just keep buying more in other companies, and that way, I keep getting a flow of information about them. It's like keeping a library - you don't necessarily read every book, but it's nice to have them on the shelf.
Has Berkshire's competitive advantage in the insurance industry, specifically regarding its financial strength and ability to pay after a catastrophe, changed since your 1994 remarks?

I'd say that advantage has only grown stronger. Our reputation as the reinsurer most certain to pay after any conceivable natural disaster is stronger today than it's ever been, and that's a major commercial advantage for us.
How has the merger of General Re and developments in the super-cat insurance industry affected Berkshire's competitive advantage in this area?

The merger of General Re has enhanced our position, and I believe our reputation, along with General Re's, is stronger than ever. This means our competitive advantage in the insurance industry has been reinforced over the past five years.
Why do you feel comfortable having the vast majority of your net worth in Berkshire?

I feel comfortable with it because I have faith in the businesses, managers, and the successor top management we have at Berkshire. I think they're ready to run the company effectively, and that gives me peace of mind.
Do you think Berkshire's corporate culture will change significantly after you're no longer involved?

I don't think so, and Charlie agrees. He believes the prospects for continuity of our corporate culture are higher than at most other large public companies. I trust that our successor management will continue to operate Berkshire in a way that's consistent with our values and approach.
Are you worried about the impact of the strong dollar on Coca-Cola's earnings?

I don't have any big feeling about the dollar's behavior, and I don't make investment decisions based on predictions about currency fluctuations. While the strength of the dollar has affected Coca-Cola's earnings in the past, I'm more focused on the company's share of market and share of mind, which I believe will continue to grow over time.
Do you think the current P/E ratio of Coca-Cola is justified, given the potential risk of rising interest rates?

I don't worry about the P/E ratio in relation to interest rates. My view is that Coca-Cola's strong brand and global presence will continue to drive growth, regardless of interest rate fluctuations. I'm more concerned with the company's underlying fundamentals and its ability to maintain its share of mind and market over the long term.
How do you measure the performance of your investments, such as Coca-Cola?

We measure it by unit cases sold and by shares outstanding. We want to see a lot more unit cases sold and fewer shares outstanding over time. It's a simple but effective way to gauge the health of a business like Coca-Cola.
Do you think the current P/E ratios of companies like Coca-Cola are reasonable, and does it affect your enthusiasm for buying more shares?

To be honest, the P/E ratios of companies like Coca-Cola strike us as quite full. That doesn't mean they're going to go down, but it does mean our enthusiasm for buying more shares is less than it was when the P/E ratios were substantially lower. We've been spoiled in the past by getting a lot for our money, and we hope to get spoiled again in the future.
How do you think the economic turmoil in Japan will affect Berkshire's investment decisions?

Honestly, it doesn't affect our thinking at all. Unless a business is directly involved in Japan, we don't consider it a factor in our decision-making. We focus on the specifics of the business itself, not on macroeconomic trends like Japan's economic slump.
Do you believe Japan's economic issues will have a significant impact on the U.S. stock market over the next 5-10 years?

I don't see why it should have more impact now than it has in the last few years. Japan's problems have been around for a while, and they've had very little effect on the U.S. so far. I'm not saying it's impossible, but I just don't think it's something to worry about too much.
What was the pretax income of See's Candy in 1972 when you bought it?
The pretax income of See's Candy in 1972 was $4 million. I remember it like it was yesterday, and it's amazing to see how far the company has come since then.
How much did See's Candy make last year, according to your statement?
Last year, See's Candy made $62 million. It just goes to show that if you're right about a business, the macro factors won't get in the way of its success over time.
You mentioned that Japan has short-term rates down to zero and long-term rates at 2 percent. Do you think this should be enough to stimulate the economy?
Well, you'd think so, but it doesn't seem to be working that way. I mean, if those rates were available to me, I'd be pretty excited, but apparently, it's just not having the desired effect.
Charlie Munger brought up the 'wealth effect' related to the stock market. Do you agree with him that this factor might be more significant than people think?

I think Charlie's onto something there. The wealth effect can be a powerful thing, and it's possible that people have been underestimating its impact. When the stock market is going up and up, it can make people feel wealthier and more confident, which can have a ripple effect on the economy.
What kind of owners do you want for Berkshire, and what characteristics do they need to have?

I want informed owners who are in sync with our objectives, measurements, and time horizons. They should be comfortable owning Berkshire and understand that they're making an investment in a business, not just buying a ticker symbol. They should know how we think and measure ourselves, and be okay with that.
Do you have a preference for individual or institutional owners, and how do you plan to communicate with them?

I don't really have a preference for individual or institutional owners, as long as they're informed and aligned with our goals. We've actually set up a non-paid information office to help with this, which is a big plus because it means I don't have to be the one fielding all the questions. Instead, analysts like Alice can help provide information to those who need it.
How does the increase in cable prices affect the Washington Post Company's cable business?

Well, it's not good news for the Washington Post Company when cable prices go up. You see, they're a net buyer of cable, not a seller, so higher prices mean they'll have to pay more to invest in cable systems. It's similar to our approach to stocks - we prefer to buy when prices are low, not high. So, for the Washington Post Company, lower cable prices would be a better scenario if they want to expand their cable business.
Do you have any involvement in the investment decisions regarding TCA Cable?

No, I don't have any involvement in TCA Cable. That's an investment made by Lou Simpson, who runs a separate equity portfolio at GEICO. I don't know anything about TCA Cable, and it's not something that falls under my management at all.
You mentioned that deflation is good for investors because the value of money appreciates. Can you explain how this works?

Well, think of it like this - when deflation occurs, the buying power of money increases. It's like having a coupon that's worth more tomorrow than it is today. For investors, this means that the money they have will go further, which can be a good thing. Of course, as I said, it's not all equal and there are other consequences to consider.
You also mentioned that owning long bonds in Japan during deflation was a 'tremendous bonanza'. How did this work out for bondholders?

It's quite simple really. When deflation occurs, interest rates tend to come down. If you owned long bonds that were issued at higher interest rates, their value would increase as interest rates fell. This means that the bonds would be worth more, and the money you received from them would buy more than it would have otherwise. It was a pretty good deal for bondholders, I'd say.
What was your experience like when you visited GEICO in 1951 and later shared your findings with other investment firms?

Well, I thought I had stumbled upon something great, but when I shared it with the folks at Blythe and Company and Geyer & Co., they just didn't see it my way. In fact, they told me I didn't know what I was talking about. It was a good lesson in learning to think for myself and not relying on others to validate my investment ideas.
What does Charlie Munger believe is helpful for people to achieve their financial goals, particularly in accumulating the first $100,000?

According to Charlie, getting that first $100,000 can be a real struggle, but he thinks people who are passionate about being rational, eager, and opportunistic - and who also make a point to underspend their income - are more likely to get there quickly. I've got to say, I think he's onto something there.
How did you initially learn about the insurance industry?

I learned about the insurance industry by reading lots of reports, including those of property-casualty companies, and going through convention reports and examination reports at the Department of Insurance in Lincoln. I also read manuals and asked for additional reports, which helped me develop my expertise.
What advice would you give to someone looking to learn about the insurance industry today?

I would advise them to read the reports of insurance companies, such as the insurance section in Berkshire Hathaway's annual reports for the past 20 years. I think that would teach them something about the economics of insurance. Additionally, finding someone who knows the business well and is willing to share their knowledge can also be very helpful.
Why haven't you considered buying back Berkshire shares when you thought the price was inefficiently low?

Well, it's quite simple really. Even when I thought Berkshire was underpriced, I usually found other investment opportunities that I believed were even more attractive. For instance, back in 1974 when Berkshire was selling for $50 a share, I thought it was cheap, but I was even more excited about the Washington Post Company, which I believed was significantly undervalued at the time. So, I chose to invest in what I thought were the best opportunities, rather than buying back our own shares.
Can you think of a time when buying back Berkshire shares would have been a better decision than the investments you chose to make?

Yes, unfortunately, I can. There have been times when I thought Berkshire was underpriced, but I still chose to invest in other securities that I believed were even better deals. In hindsight, I was wrong, and buying back our own shares would have been the smarter move. I've learned from those experiences, but it's a reminder that even with the best intentions and analysis, investing is never a sure thing.
How do you think the Berkshire Hathaway brand can be utilized on the internet to capitalize on its strong reputation?

I think our brand can be a huge asset on the internet, where trust is crucial since you're not dealing face-to-face. By associating our name with our brands like Executive Jet, Borsheims, and Berkshire Hathaway Life, we can enhance their value and build on the trust people have in us.
Do you believe the internet changes how companies should approach building trust with their customers?

Yes, I do. The internet means you're often dealing with people you'll never meet, so trust becomes even more important. Companies need to focus on building a reputation for trust, and I think Berkshire Hathaway is well-positioned to do that, given our history and values.
How many policy holders does GEICO currently have, and what is the projected number by the end of the year?

We currently have about 3.7 million policy holders, and by the end of the year, we expect that number to grow to around 4.5 million. It's a significant milestone for us, and I'm pleased with the progress we're making.
What do you believe is the key factor in GEICO's ability to maintain a large customer base despite being a direct-to-consumer business?

I think it all comes down to trust. People are willing to pay us around $1,200 a year for a promise, which is a significant commitment. The fact that they're willing to do so without ever meeting anyone from the company is a testament to the trust they have in us. And that trust is a huge asset for our business.
Why can Berkshire B shares sell at a discount to the A shares?

The B shares can sell at a discount because they can't be converted into A shares, but A shares can be converted into 30 B shares. This means if the price of B shares goes too low, people can buy A shares, convert them, and sell the B shares for a profit, which keeps the price of B shares from going too far below the price of A shares. However, the reverse isn't true, so B shares can indeed sell at a discount to A shares due to supply and demand.
Under what conditions would you recommend buying Berkshire B shares over A shares?

I've said on our website that if the B shares are at more than a 2% discount to the A shares, I think it's a better deal to buy the B shares. Essentially, if you can buy B shares at a significant discount, it's like getting a bargain compared to buying A shares.
Do you think Gillette and Coke will increase their business in their respective areas in the future?

I'm pretty sure they will. In fact, I'd almost guarantee that 10 or 20 years from now, both of those companies will be doing a lot more business in the blade and razor business for Gillette, and the soft drink business for Coke, than they are currently.
How do you approach investing in different markets or sectors, such as emerging markets?

We don't operate on the basis of trying to time markets or sectors. I think all that talk about emerging markets or country funds is nonsense. We just think for ourselves about what we know and what we don't know, and go where that leads us. We're not trying to stay up on every damn thing that's going on in the whole world, our game is to find a few intelligent things to do.
Do you think the internet will have a significant impact on the commercial world?
I do think the internet will have a huge impact. In fact, I've said it's a huge development, and it could well be one of the most important changes in the last 500 years in the commercial world.
Would you consider investing in an internet-focused fund managed by a reputable firm like Kleiner Perkins, if the terms were attractive?

While I think I understand what firms like Kleiner Perkins do, and I acknowledge the internet's potential, picking winners in this space is too hard for me. So, I wouldn't consider it within my circle of competence to invest in such a fund, regardless of the terms.
What was your thought process when deciding to sell McDonald's?

Well, I'd say it was a mistake, plain and simple. I didn't think it belonged in our top list of businesses we want to own, and that decision has cost us around a billion dollars-plus. I reported it as a mistake in the interest of candor.
How much did selling McDonald's cost Berkshire Hathaway?
I'd estimate that selling McDonald's has cost us in the area of a billion dollars-plus. Not a great decision, but we learn from our mistakes, and that's what postmortems are for.
Why do you believe in conducting postmortems at Berkshire?

I believe in postmortems because they help me understand what worked and what didn't. It's like being a doctor - you can't just prescribe a treatment and never check on the patient again. You need to see how things turned out and learn from your mistakes. By looking at the results of our decisions, I can improve my 'batting average' and make better choices in the future.
What do you think is the benefit of reviewing past decisions, including the ones that didn't work out?

Reviewing past decisions, including the ones that didn't work out, helps me identify areas where I need to improve. It's human nature to want to focus on the successes and ignore the failures, but that's not how you learn. By looking at what went wrong, I can figure out what I did wrong and try to do better next time. And if my 'batting average' gets too bad, I know it's time to reevaluate my approach and maybe even hand over decision-making to someone else.
How do you typically determine the intrinsic value of Berkshire's securities?

I tend to use market prices as a guide when thinking about intrinsic value, although there have been times when I felt our securities were worth far more than their current market price. For example, back in the mid-1970s, I mentioned in our annual report that I believed our securities would be worth significantly more than they were selling for at the time.
Have you ever considered marking up the value of Berkshire's securities in your mind or publicly?

Yes, there was a time in the mid-1970s when I felt comfortable marking up the value of our securities in my mind, but not publicly. However, in recent years, I haven't felt the need to do so, and if I thought the market value was ridiculously high compared to intrinsic value, we would likely take action.
You compared investing in certain assets to a chain letter. Can you explain how that works and why it's not sustainable?

Well, think of a chain letter like any other investment mania. If you're early in, you might make some money, but the truth is, no new wealth is being created. It's just money moving from one person to another, with some getting destroyed along the way due to frictional costs like trading fees. It's not a sustainable model because eventually, the music stops, and those left holding the bag lose out.
You mentioned a mania in farmland prices in Nebraska about 20 years ago. What happened, and what was the outcome for investors and banks?

That was a wild time. Farmland prices skyrocketed, with land selling for as much as $2,000 an acre, even though it couldn't produce more than $70 or $80 an acre. It was pure momentum investing, and it killed a lot of investors who bought in at those inflated prices. Unfortunately, it also took down several banks that had lent money based on those valuations. The math just didn't add up, and when the bubble burst, it was ugly.
You mentioned that mistakes can be useful on occasion, citing GEICO as an example. Can you elaborate on how a mistake in the early '70s worked to your benefit?

Well, GEICO made a mistake that really did bankrupt the company, but fortunately, there was an insurance commissioner who saw that it could be resuscitated. That mistake enabled us to make many, many billions of dollars. It's a great example of how sometimes, mistakes can lead to unexpected opportunities.
You also talked about the potential for surprises or fraud in the insurance industry. Do you think it's possible to completely avoid surprises like Unicover in the future?

I wouldn't say that. I think it's unlikely that we'll go 20 years without a big surprise, and it's almost impossible to avoid them entirely. The insurance industry attracts chicanery, and we've seen that same people come back again and again with new schemes. We try to minimize the risk, but I wouldn't bet my life that we've seen the last of a Unicover-type situation.
What made you decide to invest in American Express in 1964?

I invested in American Express in 1964 because I saw the power of its brand and the special cache it held. When people pulled out their American Express card, it identified them as someone special, and that told me a lot about the consumer franchise they had built. It was a huge investment for us at the time, 5 percent of the company, but I believed in the strength of their brand.
How do you think American Express has maintained its competitive edge over the years?

I think American Express has done a good job of reaffirming and intensifying its cache over the years. They've segmented their card offerings, introduced new products like the black card, and maintained a high average discount fee. This has allowed them to generate significant revenue and invest in their clientele. Additionally, they've shown an ability to withstand adversity and come back stronger, which is a testament to the underlying strength of their business.
What do you think is more important for a business, short-term profits or a sustainable competitive advantage?

I think a sustainable competitive advantage, or what I call a 'moat' around a business, is far more important than short-term profits. In the end, it's the durability of that competitive advantage that will determine a business's long-term success, not just how much money it makes in a given year.
How would you recommend someone learn more about creating a sustainable competitive advantage?

I'd say the best way to learn about it is to study companies that have achieved a sustainable competitive advantage and try to figure out how they did it. Look at businesses like the razor blade industry, for example, and ask yourself what gives them their 'moat'. You can also read up on the subject, maybe even check out some of the work by Professor Michael Porter, but I think learning from real-world examples is the most valuable way to understand this concept.
What do you think about the moat around Moody's compared to the operating company?
I think the moat around Moody's is far wider, deeper, and has more poisonous characters than the operating company. That's about all I can say on that.
Can you elaborate on what you mean by 'poisonous characters' in the context of Moody's moat?

Well, I was being a bit dramatic, but by 'poisonous characters', I mean the significant barriers that make it difficult for competitors to replicate what Moody's does. It's not something I can go into detail about, but let's just say it's a formidable set of challenges.
Why do you consider Moody's a stronger franchise than the operating company?

Well, when it comes to making decisions about credit information or securities ratings, I think Moody's has a more solid foundation. It's not that the operating company can't succeed, but if you're thinking about potential downsides, Moody's seems like a safer bet to me.
What does Charlie Munger mean by comparing Moody's to Harvard?

Ha! I think Charlie's point is that Moody's, like Harvard, has a reputation that's somewhat self-sustaining. Even if you were to mismanage it to some extent, the brand would still hold up pretty well. It's a clever analogy, and I think it highlights the strength of Moody's franchise.
You mentioned that cutting the price of admission to the Harvard Business School by $10,000 a year would likely result in less demand. Can you explain why this is the case?

Well, it's because the prestige and cachet of attending a top-tier school like Harvard Business School actually increases its appeal when the price is high. It's counterintuitive, I know, but think of it like a luxury brand - the higher the price, the more exclusive and desirable it becomes. So, if you lower the price, you're actually diminishing some of that allure.
What makes the Harvard Business School or the Stanford Business School a 'wonderful business' in your opinion?

I think they're wonderful businesses because they defy traditional economic principles. The more they raise their prices, the more people want to attend. It's a unique situation where the product's value is perceived to increase with its price. I mean, can you think of any other business where that's the case? It's a pretty remarkable phenomenon.
Who was your great teacher at Columbia?
That was Ben Graham - a marvelous teacher who didn't have to go out of his way to teach us, but did anyway. I feel lucky to have had him.
Why do you prefer talking to students over people your own age?

Well, when I talk to students, I feel like I'm passing on something valuable. If I talk to guys my age, they're often just looking to be entertained or want me to make predictions, which isn't very productive or enjoyable for me.
Do you think it's necessary for corporations to have detailed contracts with their CEOs?

No, I don't think it's necessary. At Berkshire, we've managed just fine without them. We work out compensation arrangements and other details with our managers, and it's all been very straightforward. I think it's actually a bit maddening when CEOs show up with 20-page contracts - it's just not how we do business.
How do you think the practice of excessive CEO pay and detailed contracts became so widespread in corporate America?

I think it's because of the way consultants and committees operate. They look at what other companies are doing, and then they say, 'Well, that's the standard, so we should do it too.' It's a bit of a follow-the-leader approach, and it's driven by a desire to keep up with the Joneses, rather than to do what's actually best for the company or its shareholders.
Do you think the world is heading into a deflationary situation?
My opinion is that the world is not going into a deflationary situation, but I've been wrong about economic predictions before, so take that for what it's worth.
How do you and Charlie Munger consider macroeconomic factors when evaluating potential investments?

To be honest, macro factors just don't enter into our discussion when we're looking at a business. We focus on the company itself, not on broader economic trends. I've never recalled a time when Charlie and I considered macro conclusions when deciding whether to buy a business or pieces of it through the stock market.
What is your view on the role of economics departments in banks?

I think they're a bunch of nonsense, to be honest. I mean, what do they really do? Some guy comes in and predicts GDP will be 4.6 instead of 4.3, but that doesn't help you make better loans or take in cheaper deposits. It's just fashionable to have one, and I've seen banks cut them when they merge just to justify the costs. If Berkshire ever gets an economics department, it'll be a sign that we've gone off the rails.
Why do you think banks cut costs like their economics departments during mergers?

I think they do it to justify the merger and make it look like they're getting more efficient. But the truth is, they're cutting costs they wouldn't have touched if they weren't so eager to do the merger in the first place. It's like they're trying to put lipstick on a pig - they want to make the merger look good, so they'll cut anything that doesn't seem essential, even if it's not really going to make a difference in the long run.
How do you think people can develop qualities they admire in others?

I think it's pretty simple - you just try to figure out what you find admirable in others and then decide to take on those qualities yourself. It's not about physical abilities, but about qualities of personality, character, and temperament that can be emulated. And the key is to start early, as it's tough to change behavior later on.
Can people look to historical figures or those who have passed away as models for qualities they want to develop?

Absolutely. As Charlie mentioned, the eminent dead can be some of the best models around. You're not limited to just looking at people who are alive today. In fact, some of the best models have been dead for a long time, and you can learn a lot from their lives and experiences through biographies and other accounts.
What do you think about being paid to be a CEO, and how does it compare to other aspects of the job?

Honestly, I think we should pay to have this job. It's that enjoyable. The compensation is just the frosting on the cake - the real reward is the interesting problems, the variety, and the fun that comes with being a CEO. I mean, where else can you find a job that's different every day and presents you with new, exciting challenges?
Why did Charlie Munger bring up the saying about a finance minister, and what was his point?

Charlie brought up that saying to highlight the honesty and transparency that comes with our jobs. He never wanted a job that required lying, and I think that's a sentiment we both share. His point was that, in our roles, we value honesty and don't have to resort to dishonesty, unlike some other positions, like the example he gave.
Do you think that books about your investment approach try to make it more complicated than it actually is?

I think some books do try to make our approach sound more complicated or mysterious than it really is. They might be looking for formulas or secrets that just aren't there. As I see it, we've been pretty straightforward about what we do in our annual reports and meetings.
Is a book about Charlie Munger coming out soon?

Yes, there's a book about Charlie coming out soon. I'm looking forward to it, and I think it'll be a great read. Larry has done a good job of rearranging our reports by topic, making it easier to understand our views.
Why do you think people are so drawn to hearing predictions about the market and other events?

I think people love predictions because they're looking for a sense of certainty in an uncertain world. It's like they're trying to get the inside scoop on a horse race - they want to know who's going to win before the race even starts. But the truth is, nobody really knows what's going to happen, and all these predictions are just space fillers.
Do you find any value in predictions, or do you think they're entirely useless?

Honestly, I've never seen any utility in predictions. I mean, there will be surprises in the world, that's for sure. But betting on specific outcomes or catastrophes? That's just not a smart policy. In fact, we usually bet against those super catastrophes. I just don't think predictions are worth paying attention to.
Do you think it's a good idea to prepare for economic catastrophes by investing in things like gold?

I don't think so. As Charlie said, it's hard to imagine scenarios where owning gold would be the best option, except in extreme cases like fleeing a country in turmoil. For most people, it just isn't a practical way to navigate economic life.
How do you view the likelihood of a major earthquake happening in California in the next 50 years?

We're pretty certain it will happen - a 7.0 or greater quake, that is. We just don't know when or where. It's a bit like knowing a punch is coming, but not when or from which direction. We're willing to pay out if it happens tomorrow, because that's what insurance is for.
What do you think about people who make a lot of money in the US and then move to another tax jurisdiction to avoid paying taxes?
I find it reprehensible. It's like they want to enjoy all the benefits of living in the United States, but don't want to contribute their fair share. I just don't think that's right.
Do you mind paying taxes yourself?

No, I don't mind paying taxes. In fact, I've said I'm a little crazy because I don't mind paying them. I think it's part of being a citizen and contributing to the system that has allowed me to be successful.
You mentioned that generating float at a low cost is a key part of Berkshire's strategy. Can you explain what you mean by 'float' in this context?

Well, when I say 'float,' I'm talking about the money that comes in from our insurance operations before we have to pay out claims. It's like having a big pool of money that we can invest and earn returns on, and it costs us very little to get it. As Charlie said, it's a wonderful thing to have millions or billions of dollars to invest at a cost way below what you'd pay for a Treasury bond.
You also mentioned that it's getting harder to find investment opportunities that are material relative to Berkshire's size. Can you elaborate on what you mean by 'material' in this context?

When I say 'material,' I mean investments that are big enough to really move the needle for a company of our size. If we were smaller, we could find plenty of great investments that would make a big difference. But now, we need to find opportunities that are much larger to have a significant impact. It's like trying to fill a huge bucket with water - you need a lot of water to make a difference, and that's what we're looking for.
What is your opinion on EVA valuation, as mentioned in the book 'Quest for Value' by Bennett Stewart?
Well, I'll let Charlie's opinion speak for itself - he's called EVA valuation 'twaddle' and 'medieval theology'. I think that sums it up pretty well.
Will you and Charlie Munger be available to answer more questions tomorrow at 9:30?
Yes, we will be here tomorrow at 9:30 to answer more questions. Jason Tang already asked about that, and I'm happy to confirm it's true.
What is Charlie Munger's opinion on EVA?
Charlie thinks EVA is a lot of nonsense, to put it bluntly. He believes it incorporates cost of capital ideas that don't make sense and compares the mental system behind it to medieval theology.
Why did you ask Charlie to comment on EVA instead of saying something yourself?
I knew Charlie would give a candid response, and I have to admit, I agreed with his sentiment. I just didn't want to be the one to say it myself, so I let him take the floor.
What was the general sentiment about the US economy twenty years ago, according to your recollection?

Twenty years ago, the country had a bit of an inferiority complex about its place in the world economic order. We were worried we'd lose our edge in industries like steel and autos, and there was even talk about us becoming a nation of hamburger flippers. It was a pretty gloomy outlook.
Do you think the US should interfere with the current state of its tech industry, given its success, as seen in the case of Microsoft?

I think we've got something working very well that probably doesn't make a lot of sense to tinker with too much. The US has become a world leader in the tech industry, and I believe it's best to let it continue to thrive without too much interference.
How does inflation impact GEICO's business, according to your analysis?

Inflation isn't necessarily harmful to GEICO. In fact, a speed-up of inflation would lead to more dollar volume in the insurance business, which is good for us. However, people might get irritated about the rising cost of everything, including insurance, and that could be a problem.
What specific risks or challenges does inflation pose to insurance businesses like GEICO, and how do you plan to address them?

The main risk is that people will get upset about the increasing cost of insurance, which is a significant part of their annual budget. As for addressing this risk, I don't have a specific plan mentioned here, but I do note that pricing would eventually catch up with inflation, which would help mitigate the issue.
What is the minimum deal size Berkshire Hathaway is looking for in real estate finance opportunities?
We're looking at deals in excess of $100 million. That's the threshold we've set for considering real estate finance opportunities.
How does Berkshire Hathaway approach allocating funds to real estate deals?

We don't operate with a fixed budget or a team that needs to keep busy. If the deals are right, we'll invest many billions. But if they're not, we won't force it. Our approach is simple: we'll do real estate deals, but only at the right price.
How do you handle the accounting for 'pain today, gain tomorrow' insurance transactions, and what information do you provide to investors about these deals?

I handle the accounting for these transactions by recording a significant loss in the current year, and then we have the use of float for many years to come with no subsequent charges. We provide information to investors about these deals by disclosing any significant items quarterly or yearly, so they can make adjustments to reflect economic reality. For instance, we disclosed over $400 million in losses last year from these transactions.
How do these 'pain today, gain tomorrow' transactions affect your cost of float, and what would it be if you hadn't engaged in these transactions?

These transactions distort our current year cost of float figure. Last year, our cost of float was 6 percent, which is high, and about a quarter of that came from these transactions. If we hadn't engaged in these transactions, our cost of float would've been about 4 1/2 percent.
What was the consequence of not immediately buying more Belridge Oil shares when you had the chance?
Well, that mistake cost me $200 million. It just goes to show that sometimes, taking a slight inconvenience to act quickly can make a huge difference in the long run.
How do you define an 'error' in the context of investment decisions at Berkshire?

We only consider something an error if it's within our circle of competence and we fail to act on it or do something very small with it when we could have done much more. It's not about missing out on something we don't understand, but about not taking full advantage of opportunities we do understand.
How do you approach decision-making in insurance and buying businesses regarding the issue of product liability and potential lawsuits?

I make decisions with a very pessimistic attitude toward the chances of the trend of abusive lawsuits being moderated. We project that the trend would accelerate and build in a margin of safety in our decisions.
What's your view on the impact of the plaintiff's contingency and the role of judges in handling junk science and abusive conduct in courts?

I think Charlie Munger summed it up well - the increasing political power of the plaintiff's contingency is a concern, and judges haven't been tough enough on junk science and trashy lawyers. We factor this into our decisions, assuming the trend won't improve.
Do you believe in holding large amounts of cash just for the sake of having it?
No, I don't believe in holding cash just to have it. As I said, we don't 'have cash around just to have cash.' It's there to be used productively or distributed to shareholders.
What is your take on Phil Fisher's statement that 'hoarding cash is evil'?

Well, I think Phil Fisher makes a good point. Companies should either put their cash to good use or give it back to shareholders. Having too much idle cash isn't beneficial to anyone, and it's our job as managers to make the most of the resources we have.
Why do you think asset allocation strategies like 60% stocks and 30% other investments are nonsense?

Well, I just don't think it makes sense to allocate a certain percentage of your portfolio to cash or stocks just for the sake of it. At Berkshire, we want all our money working in decent businesses, and if we can't find those, then we'll hold cash. But we won't hold cash just to meet some arbitrary allocation target.
What is your approach to leverage and borrowing money at Berkshire?

We don't like lots of leverage, and we never will. We'll never borrow lots of money at Berkshire. It's just not our style. We'd rather have cash on hand and wait for the right investment opportunities than take on a lot of debt.
What advantages does Berkshire have when it comes to buying businesses?

Well, I think our advantages are pretty significant. For one, people know our checks clear, so we can make deals happen fast without any financing difficulties. We're also a preferred purchaser for many private and public companies because they know we'll let them run their businesses as they see fit, with no second-guessing from us. And our ownership structure is very stable, which is a big plus.
You mentioned Berkshire has a big disadvantage - what is it?

Actually, I didn't specify what our big disadvantage is in this conversation, but I did acknowledge that we do have one. I think it's worth noting that our size and high equity prices can sometimes make it tougher for us to capitalize on certain opportunities, but that's about all I can say on that topic for now.
What do you consider the biggest disadvantage of Berkshire's current size?

I think the biggest disadvantage we have is size. It's just harder to double the market value of a hundred billion dollar company than a $1 billion company. It's not impossible, but it's certainly more challenging.
Do you expect the investment game to become less competitive in the future?

No, Charlie Munger mentioned that the investment game is getting more and more competitive, and he sees no sign of that changing. I do expect, however, that people will continue to do stupid things in the equity markets, and that's where we hope to capitalize on opportunities.
What's your view on growth in the context of investing, and how does it apply to different businesses like airlines versus See's Candy?

I think growth is a wonderful thing, but it's not always a blessing. In the airline business, for example, growth has been a curse because it requires a lot of capital investment without adequate returns. On the other hand, a business like See's Candy can grow with relatively little incremental investment, making growth a great thing. It just depends on the business and how it operates.
Do you believe in categorizing investments as 'growth stocks' or 'value stocks', and why or why not?

To be honest, I don't think it makes sense to categorize investments as 'growth stocks' or 'value stocks'. At the end of the day, we're just trying to put out capital now to get more capital back later. If you do that successfully, the business will grow, and you can call it whatever you want - growth or value. It's not like they're two different categories. I think it's just a simplistic way of thinking about investing that doesn't really add much value.
How do you think kids can be educated about making and saving money, a topic not typically covered in school?

I think it's great when kids can learn about making and saving money from their parents or from teachers who can explain the subject in a way that's easy to understand. As I said, parents can do a lot to educate their kids on this topic, and it's wonderful when teachers can also provide valuable lessons.
At what age did you buy your first stock, and do you think it's possible for young people to start investing early?

I bought my first stock when I was 11 years old, which is a bit later than this young man, Steven, who's already investing at the age of 10. I think it's fantastic that he's getting a head start, and I believe it's definitely possible for young people to start investing early with the right guidance and education.
What kind of investment do you think is the best for someone to make at an early age?
I think the best investment you can make, at an early age, is in yourself. It's all about developing your mind and your talents, and that's something that will pay off hugely over time.
How much would you be willing to pay for a percentage of a bright student's future earnings?
I'd pay $50,000 for 10 percent of a bright student's future earnings - that's how much I think their potential is worth. In fact, I think that student would be a $500,000 asset just standing there.
What was your experience like with the credit and delivery grocery business, specifically the Buffett & Son Grocery Store?

Well, I can tell you it was a tough business. It barely supported my family for a hundred years, and that was with everyone working 90 hours a week. I used to go out on those delivery trucks, and it was pretty darn inefficient. We'd take orders over the phone, write them down with a pencil and order pad, and then haul the stuff around town. It was a lot of hard work for not a lot of payoff.
How do you think the internet affected the prospects of businesses like Webvan, which attempted to revive the delivery grocery model?

The internet didn't change the fundamental economics of the business, but it did offer a way for people to monetize the hopes and dreams of others. In other words, it allowed promoters to capture the greed and dreams of millions of people and turn that into instant cash through venture capital and the markets. But at the end of the day, it's been a huge trap for the public, and very little money has been created by pure internet businesses like Webvan.
What is your expectation for the growth of your insurance float this year?

I would certainly expect our float to grow at least 2 1/2 billion this year, which is close to 10 percent of the beginning of the year float. That's a rational expectation based on our current business.
Do you think it's possible to sustain a 10 percent annual growth rate for your insurance float over the long term?

I don't think we can sustain a 10 percent growth rate over 25 years. As we get bigger, it's harder to grow at that rate. We're already close to 10 percent of the entire U.S. float, and I don't think the aggregate float is going to grow at a 10 percent rate. But we'll do our best to keep growing, while also keeping our costs low.
How do you use credit history to inform your underwriting decisions at GEICO?

Well, we've found that people with a good credit history tend to be better drivers than those with a poor credit history. We don't necessarily care why that is, but we do care that the two factors correlate. So, we use that correlation to help us make more informed underwriting decisions.
What's the importance of fast and fair settlement of claims in the property-casualty business?

Fast and fair settlement of claims is vital because people who aren't really injured can start feeling worse and worse as they talk to more lawyers. It's just human nature. So, we prioritize getting claims settled quickly and fairly to avoid unnecessary headaches and costs.
What's your view on how people invest during a bull market?

I think people get a bit too careless with their money during a bull market. They start to believe it's easy to make money, and that's just not the case. It's like they're tossing money around without much thought, hoping to catch the next big thing. I've seen it before, like with internet stocks a few years ago, and I'm sure we'll see it again with something else next year.
Do you think great investment performance is what's driving big money-making on Wall Street?

No, I don't think that's the case. From what I've seen, the biggest money made on Wall Street in recent years has been due to great promotion, not great performance. It's all about selling the idea, rather than actually delivering results. And that's a recipe for trouble, if you ask me.
Have you ever expressed interest in the business of Level 3 Communications, especially at current prices?

I don't think I've ever expressed interest in Level 3 Communications, at least not publicly, and I haven't discussed it with Walter Scott in a way that would suggest we're looking to get into that business.
If you were to strip out the leverage effect of the insurance float from Berkshire's portfolio, how much do you think the book value would have grown over the last 30-plus years?

Honestly, I've never made that calculation, but I think it's safe to say the float has been very useful to us. I don't think the growth would be as high as 5 or 6 percentage points without the float, but it's definitely been a significant contributor to our success.
What advice would you give to an 11-year-old who is interested in financial matters?

Well, I'd say you're off to a great start just by being interested! If you can maintain that curiosity, I'd recommend reading financial publications, learning about the businesses in your area, and talking to people who run successful businesses. Just keep accumulating knowledge - it's cumulative, and every dollar you save or learn early on can be worth a lot more later.
Why do you think it's easier to save money during teenage years if your parents are taking care of your financial obligations?

It's simple: when your parents are covering your expenses, every dollar you earn is essentially free to save or invest. It's like having a head start in a race. You can put that money to work for you, and over time, it can grow into something much bigger - every dollar can turn into $10 or $20 later on.
What advice do you have for young people who want to get ahead financially?

I think it's essential to start building a financial foundation early on. Stay away from credit cards, and try to get a few dollars ahead. It's like building a database in your mind - the knowledge and habits you develop will pay off over time.
Do you think it's important to prioritize learning and personal development when you're young?

Absolutely. The stuff I learned when I was 20 is still useful today, even if it's not in the same way. It just goes to show that investing time in learning and personal growth can have long-term benefits.
What kind of opportunities does being part of Berkshire Hathaway bring to General Re Cologne?

Well, being part of Berkshire Hathaway gives General Re Cologne access to a much larger distribution capacity, which means we can take on bigger risks that we might not have otherwise seen. It's a synergistic relationship, really - we can offer something that others can't, and that's the ability to write large, complex contracts quickly, often in just an hour, whereas other companies might take a month or more to figure out what to do with them.
How does Berkshire Hathaway's risk tolerance compare to other companies?

We're willing to take on more risk than just about anybody else in the world, knowingly, that is. Although, I think some other people take on a lot more risk than they realize, unknowingly. But when it comes to writing a specific contract, we're both bigger and faster than anybody else, which gives us a unique advantage in the market.
What is your view on the efficiency market theory and how it's taught in finance departments?

I think the efficiency market theory is a cop-out. If I didn't know how to value a business, I'd probably come up with a theory that says nobody knows anything too. It's just a way to avoid the hard work of actually learning how to invest. And that's what's being taught in many finance departments - that nobody knows anything, rather than teaching students how to think critically about valuation.
Do you think business schools are doing a good job of teaching investment and valuation skills to their students?

No, I don't think they're doing a good job at all. In fact, I think it's kind of pathetic. They're missing a huge opportunity to teach students how to think intelligently about investing and valuation, which would not only make them better investors but also better business managers. Charlie and I see it all the time - CEOs who don't know how to think about the value of businesses they're acquiring, and it's a real problem.
What advice do you give to young people regarding debt?

I tell them not to start out behind the eight ball. It's crazy to get in debt because it's so hard to get out of debt. I advise them to use credit cards responsibly and pay off the balance before it starts revolving, because the interest rates are just too expensive.
Why do you think credit card debt is particularly problematic?

Well, the interest rates are just too high. I mean, we can't even make money borrowing at 18 percent. Charlie and I are always looking for ways to avoid paying high interest rates, and I think individuals should be just as cautious. It's just too expensive and can be hell to get out of once you're in debt.
Do you think a significant trade deficit over a long period is beneficial for a country?
No, I don't. I think it's a significant minus for the country. It's like trading away your assets for trinkets or consumer goods that don't provide long-term value.
Are there any situations where running a trade deficit could be considered a smart move?

Well, Charlie brought up a good point - if a developing country is running a trade deficit to invest in things like power plants or infrastructure, like we did with railroads in the past, that could be a smart move. But that's not what we're doing today, we're mostly running deficits on consumption goods like radios and TVs.
What's your view on how volatility relates to risk in business?

I think it's a mistake to equate volatility with risk. Just because a business has ups and downs doesn't mean it's a bad business. And on the other hand, a business with smooth results might actually be a terrible business - like one that's just stagnant and doing nothing. Volatility doesn't necessarily translate to risk.
What should you do if someone starts talking to you about beta?

Zip up your pocketbook! In other words, be careful and don't let them talk you into something that might not be in your best interest. I'm skeptical of fancy financial terms like beta, and I think it's often used to make things sound more complicated than they need to be.
What does the concept of low expectations, as related to Zen Buddhism, have to do with your wife Susan's peaceful smile?

Well, according to the fellow who asked the question, Susan's peaceful smile might be due to her low expectations in life, which is a principle from Zen Buddhism. But my partner Charlie Munger has a different take - he thinks it's because I, as her husband, have exceeded those low expectations! (laughs)
Did your wife Susan practice or follow Zen Buddhism, and if so, how did she share it with others?

From what I've been told, Susan used to send Zen Buddhism books to her sorority sisters. I think that's a pretty neat way to share something that's meaningful to you with others. But I don't think she was a practicing Zen monk like our questioner - although she does seem to have a pretty peaceful outlook on life!
How often do you have a 'big idea' that can significantly impact Berkshire Hathaway?

I'd say we have a big idea about once every year or two. It's not a frequent occurrence, but when it happens, it can be really significant. And as Charlie mentioned, if we took the top 15 ideas from Berkshire Hathaway, it would be a major part of our success.
Can you recall any specific instances where you knew you had stumbled upon a 'big idea'?

Yes, there have been a few times when I knew I had a big idea. For example, when I met Lorimer Davidson and he explained GEICO to me, I knew it was a big idea. Similarly, when I found Western Insurance Securities, I recognized its potential. These ideas don't come along often, but when they do, I try to capitalize on them.
How do you feel about the succession situation at Berkshire?

I feel very good about it. We've got a strong organization in place, with capable managers and a solid culture. While I won't name my successor today, I'm confident that we've got someone very good lined up to take the reins when the time comes.
What gives you confidence that Berkshire will continue to thrive after you're no longer involved?

Well, for one thing, we've got a lot of assets that will do well more or less automatically. We also have very good managers in place and a system for bringing in new talent. Plus, we've had a test run of sorts - when I took a leave to work at Salomon for nine months, everything ran smoothly at Berkshire without me. That gives me a lot of comfort, and it's why I'm happy to have 99 percent of my estate invested in Berkshire shares.
Do you think experience is more important than book knowledge when it comes to investing?

I think experience is useful, but it's not the most important thing. What's more important is having your head screwed on right in the first place, meaning you've got a solid understanding of how to value businesses and look at stocks. Experience can certainly help, especially in terms of knowing more about different businesses, but it's not a guarantee of success.
Would you rather invest with someone who has 10 years of experience but may not share your investment philosophy, or someone with 2 years of experience who thinks like you?

If I had to choose, I'd rather be with the one I'm philosophically in sync with, even if they've only got 2 years of experience. Having a shared investment philosophy is crucial, and if that's in place, I think the less experienced person has a good chance of doing well. Of course, if the 10-year veteran also shares my philosophy, that's even better, but philosophy trumps experience in my book.
Do you think PUHCA is a barrier to capital entering the electricity industry?

I do think PUHCA is a barrier to capital entering the industry. In fact, I believe it restricts the flow of capital to quite a degree, which is a problem because solving our electricity issues is going to take a significant amount of investment.
Why do you think politicians might be motivated to repeal or change PUHCA?

Well, politicians don't like to face the music when it comes to major brownouts. They can try to blame it on someone else, but at the end of the day, the public is going to hold them accountable if we run out of electricity. And let's be honest, it's not like we're lacking the ability to build generators or transmission lines - we just need the capital to make it happen.
