He's pointed out that it may take more fossil fuel energy to create ethanol than you can get out of the ethanol itself, which would be a pretty inefficient solution to our energy problems. I'll just say I have friends on both sides of the ethanol debate, and I'm for my friends - but that's not exactly a ringing endorsement!
What's your view on the current market forces driving commodity prices?
I think the market is responding more to speculative forces now than to fundamental forces. It's like a big party, where people get caught up in the excitement and lose sight of the underlying value.
Can you explain why you're not good at predicting the end of a speculative boom?

Well, it's like trying to leave Cinderella's ball at midnight - everyone thinks they can get out in time, but there are no clocks on the wall. We're not good at figuring out when the party will turn to pumpkins and mice, and that's why we focus on buying when the fundamentals are attractive, rather than trying to time the speculative frenzy.
What is your approach to investing in countries like China and Brazil?

Well, I'd say we're not afraid to invest in countries like China and Brazil, but we want to get paid for taking on that extra risk. We'd need to understand the business really well and get an attractive price. It's like buying a house - if it's in a neighborhood you know, you might pay full price, but if it's in a neighborhood you're not familiar with, you'd want a discount to account for the unknowns.
Are there any specific factors that would deter you from investing in a particular country?

Yes, size of the economy is one factor. We're unlikely to put a lot of money into really small economies because we just can't get enough money into them to make it worthwhile. It's like trying to fill a bucket with a teaspoon - it's just not efficient.
Why did you think silver would get tight at some point?

I thought silver would get tight because it's largely produced as a by-product of other metals like copper, lead, and zinc, and there are relatively few pure silver mines. This made it difficult to increase production, which led me to believe that silver supplies would become scarce.
Did you make a significant profit from investing in silver?

No, we didn't make much money on silver. In fact, I was early in buying and selling, and it didn't work out well for us. As I said, it's a drawback of commodities - they don't earn anything while you hold them, so you have to hope the price moves in your favor.
Do you think addressing poverty would solve the problem of nuclear terrorism?

No, I don't think solving poverty would necessarily solve the problem of nuclear terrorism. As I mentioned, the only times nuclear weapons have been used were by the United States in 1945, which was the richest country in the world at the time. People will find ways to justify the use of nuclear weapons if they feel threatened or have strong beliefs, regardless of their economic situation.
How do you think the US economy would respond to a nuclear terrorist attack on a major US city?

The impact on the economy would certainly depend on the extent of the attack. But to be honest, I think it's a bit misguided to focus on how to profit from such a scenario or even how the economy would respond. The human cost would be devastating, and that's what we should be concerned about. As for the economy, it's resilient, but the effects of such an event would be significant and far-reaching.
What advice would you give to young investment professionals who want to pursue their innovative ideas but are hesitant due to the risk of giving up their significant salaries and corporate perks?

Well, I think Charlie's advice to reduce your expectations is a good starting point. As for me, I'd say it's essential to understand that the investment profession, in aggregate, doesn't necessarily add value above what a layman can accomplish. So, it's crucial to be aware of the dynamics of the industry and not be swayed by the idea that price equals value.
Can you explain why you think the investment profession is unique in not adding significant value, despite the large amounts of money being made by professionals in the field?

It's quite simple, really. I estimate that the investment profession, as a whole, makes around $140 billion a year, yet in aggregate, they can only accomplish what an individual can do in about ten minutes a year by themselves. This is unusual because most professions, like medicine or plumbing, have clear value added that exceeds what a layman can do. The investment profession, however, doesn't seem to follow this pattern.
What changes have you observed in the teaching of finance over the past 20 years?

I've seen a significant improvement in the teaching of finance over the past 20 years. The orthodoxy of 20 years ago, which I think was a bit like believing in a flat Earth, has improved considerably. Now, you've got people in finance departments at schools like KU, Missouri, Florida, and Stanford doing a great job. It's quite encouraging to see.
How do you think the financing opportunities for graduates have changed since you graduated college?

Well, I think the opportunities have improved, but I also think that many students now have unrealistic expectations about getting rich quickly by copying what Charlie and I did many years ago. The amount of brain power going into money management is impressive, but it's also a bit distressing. Overall, I think the changes have been positive, and it's great to see so many talented students coming out of these programs.
You mentioned that Salomon was close to bankruptcy in 1991. How close were you to actually filing for bankruptcy, and what changed?

We were very close - within half an hour, I'd say. The law firm was actually drawing up the papers for bankruptcy on a Sunday. But fortunately, the Treasury reversed itself, and we managed to avoid that predicament.
Can you describe what might have happened on the Monday following that Sunday if Salomon had failed?

Well, it would have been chaotic. We had a significant derivative book at the time, and many security settlements were due the next day. If we had failed, I imagine it would have caused a lot of problems for our counterparties, especially since we weren't going to be able to make payments. It was already a tumultuous time, with the Dow opening down a couple hundred points the next day, and Gorbachev's situation unfolding. It would have been a perfect storm of uncertainty and panic.
What would have happened on the Monday following the potential bankruptcy, according to Charlie Munger?
Charlie thought it could have been absolute chaos. I'd say that's a pretty fair assessment - it was a terrifying prospect, to say the least.
How did Nick Brady's prior knowledge of Berkshire Hathaway influence the situation in 1991?

Nick Brady's prior knowledge of Berkshire Hathaway, due to his family connection with the Chaces, seemed to have given him a level of trust in me and the company. This trust apparently played a role in his decision to reverse the Treasury's initial stance, which had put us in a difficult spot.
If you were starting out today with a million dollars, what type of investments would you look to make in the first five years to achieve 20 percent average growth in value over 40 years?

If I were starting out today with a million dollars, I'd look to invest in securities, probably smaller stocks, because they could have a significant impact on a small portfolio. I'd be looking around the world for opportunities like Korea, where growth potential is high. As I always say, you don't need a lot of good ideas, just one that's worth a ton.
Would you consider buying businesses if you were starting out with a million dollars, and why or why not?

Honestly, I don't think buying businesses would be a viable option with just a million dollars. We'd be too small a player, and without a reputation, people wouldn't be coming to us. I'd have to rely on other investment strategies, like securities, to grow the portfolio. As I mentioned, even Charlie started out in real estate development because it required little capital, and that's a different story.
If you were running a partnership with a small amount of money a couple of years ago, where would you have likely invested and why?
I think I would have probably been 100 percent in Korea. I was looking for something that was very mispriced and which I understood, and Korea fit that bill at the time.
What's your view on modern portfolio theory, and how does it relate to your investment approach?

I think modern portfolio theory is asinine. It suggests diversifying into many investments, but I believe in concentrating on the best opportunities. As Charlie said, most people won't find thousands of equally good investments, but rather a few that stand out. My approach is to act on my best opportunity cost, which is a concept that's actually covered in basic economics textbooks.
How do you determine what facts are correct and relevant when making investment decisions?

I try to make sure the facts I have are correct, and that's usually pretty easy to do in this country with all the information available. Then, I think through what those facts mean, focusing on things that are both important and knowable. I don't take public opinion surveys or pay attention to unimportant things. It's about narrowing it down to what matters and what you can know.
What role does public opinion or what others are doing play in your decision-making process?

What others are doing means nothing to me. As Ben Graham said, you're neither right nor wrong because people agree or disagree with you. You're right because your facts and reasoning are right. So, I don't factor in public opinion or follow the crowd; I make decisions based on my own analysis of the facts.
What does it mean when you say the market is there to serve you, not instruct you?

When I say the market is there to serve you, not instruct you, I mean that the market's primary function is to provide prices, not to tell you what to do. It's up to you to use your own facts and reasoning to decide whether those prices make sense. If they don't, that's when you can take action and potentially make a profit. The market doesn't instruct us; it just gives us opportunities to act based on our own analysis.
You mentioned getting calls on Sunday can be a lucrative opportunity. What kind of situations typically lead to these Sunday calls?

Sunday calls usually mean something's gone haywire. Like during the LTCM crisis, people were getting nervous, and their portfolios were in trouble. That's when opportunities arise. If someone's calling you on a Sunday, it's likely because they're in a tight spot, and you might be able to capitalize on that. Just remember, you want to be the one receiving the call, not making it.
How do you approach creating Berkshire's annual report, and what do you aim to include in it?

I try to put everything in that report that I would want to know if the positions were reversed. If I were an owner of Berkshire and had been out of the loop for a year, I'd want the manager to report to me in a way that's clear and understandable. So, we include information on our businesses, operating earnings, and investments, presented in a way that's easy to grasp. We aim to give you the same information that Charlie and I would discuss if one of us were running the business and the other was inactive.
What do you think is important for a serious owner of Berkshire to consider when reading the annual report?

I think it's worth taking the time to read the whole report, considering what our businesses are, what our managers are trying to achieve, and what resources we have to add to our collection of businesses. You should think about what we're trying to do, the odds of our success, and what it all might be worth if we do or don't succeed in deploying our capital. It's a lot to take in, but if you're a serious owner, it's worth the few hours it takes to get through it.
Do you think your judgments about investments will be proven decent if you have a lot of money 30 years from now?

Yes, that's what I believe. If we have a lot of money 30 years from now, it will mean that our judgments overall were decent. It's not a guarantee, of course, but it's a good indicator that we've made some smart decisions along the way.
How do you think global warming will affect the weather-related insurance business?

Well, I think Charlie said it best - if the oceans get warmer, the weather is going to have more high-energy uproar in it. That means we can expect more frequent and intense weather events, which would increase the risks for our insurance business. As Charlie said, it would be crazy to write weather-related insurance without taking global warming into account, and that's why we need to be careful about pricing and risk control.
You've mentioned that a complicated bankruptcy can offer opportunities for profit. Can you give an example from your past experiences where this was the case?

Well, I'd point to our experience with Fruit of the Loom and Penn Central. In the case of Fruit of the Loom, we initially bought their bonds without any intention of ending up with the company, but it worked out that way. And with Penn Central, it was a big mess, but that complexity created opportunities for mispricing, and we were able to make some money from it.
Do you think the current state of the bankruptcy field offers promising investment opportunities?

To be honest, I think the field is a bit crowded right now, with many people looking at potential bankruptcies. This means that the opportunities for profit might not be as great as they have been in the past. However, over time, I'm confident that we'll find some attractive investments in bankruptcy situations, especially when they're big and complicated.
Do you think big retailers are becoming stronger brands in their own right?

Yes, I do. In fact, I think they're becoming brands of their own and there's more concentration going on in that space. It's a trend that's likely to continue, making the struggle between manufacturers and retailers even more intense.
Why do you think the future of Gillette and P&G is better as a combined enterprise?

I think their combined strength will help them navigate the increasingly competitive retail landscape, particularly against powerhouses like Walmart and Costco. By joining forces, they can strengthen their hand in the ongoing battle between manufacturers and retailers.
What is your view on being a 'strategic buyer' when it comes to acquisitions?

I've never been a fan of being a 'strategic buyer.' To me, that's just a fancy way of saying someone who pays too much for a business. I mean, if it's a good deal, it's a good deal - you don't need to justify it by calling it 'strategic.' I've had people approach me with opportunities, saying I'm the 'logical strategic buyer,' and I'm not interested. It's just a way to get me to overpay, if you ask me.
Have you considered acquiring Oriental Trading Company in the past?

Yes, I did look at Oriental Trading Company about four or five years ago when Terry Watanabe sold it. But I haven't really followed the company since then, and I don't have any current knowledge about it. I do know that we get approached all the time by financial groups looking to resell businesses they've bought, and that's not typically something that interests me.
How do you distinguish between insurance and gambling, given that both involve probabilities and potential financial losses?

I think the key distinction is that insurance involves managing existing risks, like having a home in a coastal area that's prone to natural disasters. Those risks are already there, and insurance helps mitigate them. Gambling, on the other hand, creates new risks that don't need to exist, like betting on a spinning wheel. One is about managing real-world risks, and the other is about creating unnecessary ones.
Do you believe the insurance industry is similar to a gambling market, where the 'house' makes money from people's lack of knowledge about true probabilities?

Well, I wouldn't say the insurance industry is exactly like a gambling market, but I do think there are similarities in how probabilities play a role. However, with insurance, the goal is to manage and distribute real risks, not just to make a bet. It's about providing a service that helps people protect themselves against potential losses, rather than just creating a game of chance.
What distinction do you make between cat coverage and other types of risk creation?

Well, with cat coverage, we're talking about transferring large existing risks, like the risk of a house being destroyed in a hurricane. On the other hand, creating a risk that isn't required is like betting on a football game - you can choose not to take that risk, but you can't opt out of the risk of living in a hurricane-prone area if that's where your house is.
Do you think the 'house advantage' concept applies to investment management operations?

I think Charlie Munger made a great point about that. Some investment management operations, especially in private equity, are taking a house edge that's quite large - similar to the rake of a croupier in a casino. And I have to say, I think that's a pretty apt comparison.
How do you judge whether management is being a good steward of company money, especially in relation to perks like corporate jets?

I think compensation is not rocket science. We have very simple systems that compensate people based on their performance. As for corporate jets, I believe they can be a valuable business tool when used properly. It's all about using them in a way that benefits the company, not just as a perk for executives.
Do you think corporate jets are a waste of company resources, as some studies suggest?

No, I don't think corporate jets are a waste of resources. In fact, I believe they've been a real asset to Berkshire. Of course, like anything else, they can be misused, but when used properly, they can be very beneficial. I've seen firsthand how they've helped us make deals and grow our businesses.
What happened in 1998 that's relevant to the discussion on credit contractions?

In 1998, there was a seize-up of the credit markets when Long-Term Capital Management got into trouble. It wasn't an orchestrated contraction by the Fed, but rather a panic among investors, even regarding the safest instruments, which led to extraordinary things happening in the credit markets.
Do you think we'll see another credit contraction like the one in the past, and if so, what might it look like?

I don't think we'll see an orchestrated credit contraction, but we will see something that 'rhymes' with past events, like 1998. It won't be the same, but history has a way of repeating itself in similar patterns, as Mark Twain said. We'll have to wait and see what form it takes, but I'm confident that we'll learn from past experiences and adapt to new challenges.
What's your view on shorting stocks?

I don't regard shorting as a great way to make a living. It's easy to spot phony or promoted stocks, but it's hard to tell when they'll turn around. If you're short and the stock keeps going up, it can get very painful.
What happens if your broker doesn't deliver the stock you bought after a few weeks?

Well, if I demand delivery after three weeks and my broker still doesn't deliver, I don't have a straightforward remedy. As Charlie pointed out, no court can just issue me a stock certificate because I want it. The clearance system is failing me, and while I may have some ultimate remedy, it's not a simple fix.
Do you think gambling companies will have a successful future?
I think gambling companies will have a terrific future, as long as they're legal. People have a huge propensity to gamble, and the easier it's made for them to do so, the more they will gamble.
Why do you think people are drawn to gambling?

I believe people are drawn to gambling because it's exciting and can add an extra layer of interest to otherwise boring events. For example, betting a few bucks on a football game can make it more enjoyable to watch, even if it's a terribly boring game.
What do you mean by 'margin of safety' when it comes to investing in businesses?

Well, I think Charlie summed it up nicely - it's about getting more value than you're paying for. It's like buying something for 25 cents that you think is worth a dollar. You don't need to be precise, but you want to feel like you're getting a good deal. And that's what a margin of safety is all about.
Do you wait for extremely undervalued opportunities, like buying a business at a quarter of its worth, or do you invest in good businesses at reasonable valuations?

We don't just sit around waiting for those home runs, like finding a wonderful business at a quarter of its worth. If we can buy good businesses at a reasonable valuation, we're going to keep doing it. Those extremely undervalued opportunities are rare, and we're not going to wait 10 or 15 years for them to come around.
Do you think Berkshire can help solve the health care mess in the US?

No, I don't think Berkshire can solve the health care mess. In fact, Charlie and I have discussed it, and we both agree it's too tough for us. We tend to look for easy problems, the ones we think we have the answers for, and healthcare just isn't one of them.
Why do you prefer to focus on easier problems?

Well, I think it's just common sense. We try to look for easy problems because those are the ones we find we have the answers for. It's like trying to hit a baseball - if you're swinging at pitches that are too tough, you're just going to strike out. We'd rather focus on the ones we can hit out of the park, and that's usually the easier ones.
What are you looking for in a private sector solution for health insurance?

I'm looking for something with very, very low distribution costs. You see, when a lot of the revenue gets soaked up in frictional costs between the benefits paid and the premiums received, that's just like trying to fill a leaky bucket - it's not very efficient. I want a solution where most of the money goes towards actual healthcare, not towards administrative costs.
Why haven't you found a good private sector solution for health insurance yet?

Honestly, I just haven't seen anyone who's very good at it. And it's not for lack of trying - if someone could figure out how to make it work with low distribution costs, they'd be onto something big. I mean, we're talking about 15 percent of GDP going towards health costs, so you'd think someone would have cracked the code by now. But so far, I haven't heard anything that's really impressed me.
You mentioned that intelligent people can do irrational things, especially when trying to beat the markets day by day. Can you elaborate on why you think this is a fool's game?

Well, I think it's a fool's game because people get caught up in the short-term fluctuations and try to time the market, which is extremely difficult. It's like trying to predict what's going to happen tomorrow based on what happened today. It just doesn't work that way. And when you've got a lot of smart people trying to do the same thing, it can lead to some pretty irrational behavior.
You also talked about how some financial models, like Gaussian distributions, don't accurately predict market behavior. Why do you think these models are still used?

I think these models are still used because they're easy to teach and easy to compute. Charlie and I were just discussing how some professors might continue to teach outdated ideas because they're simple and familiar, even if they don't really work. It's a bit like the medical school professor Charlie mentioned, who kept teaching an obsolete procedure just because it was easy to teach.
If you were to start over with a small portfolio, would your investment strategy change?

Yes, it would. If I were working with a very small sum, I would be doing entirely different things than I do now. My universe of potential investments would expand, and I'd have thousands of options to consider.
What kind of investments would you focus on with a small portfolio?

I'd focus on things like arbitrage and finding those 'cigar butts' that Benjamin Graham used to talk about. It's a different game when you're working with a small amount of money, and you have to be more opportunistic and look for hidden gems.
What is your view on managed futures funds?

I think managed futures funds are at a disadvantage because they're limited to a specific segment of the financial market. At Berkshire, we prefer to have total authority to invest in anything that makes sense, whether it's stocks, bonds, futures, currencies, or businesses. We don't want to restrict our universe of possibilities.
Do you believe it's beneficial for an investment fund to have a diversified portfolio with the ability to go long and short in various markets?

Well, I believe it's a mistake to shrink the universe of possibilities. Having the flexibility to invest in different markets and asset classes, like we do at Berkshire, is beneficial. However, I don't think it's necessarily about following a specific strategy like managed futures funds, but rather having the right person in charge who can make sensible investment decisions.
What do you believe is the key to minimizing risk in business investments?

I believe the key to minimizing risk is understanding the economics of the business you're in, knowing the people you're doing business with, and ensuring the price you pay is sensible. If you have those factors in place, you don't run any real risk.
Can you recall any significant permanent losses in marketable securities during your tenure at Berkshire?

Actually, I can recall very few, if any, significant permanent losses in marketable securities that were more than 1 percent of our net worth. However, I do remember a notable mistake - buying Dexter Shoe, which cost us significantly more than that. But that was due to my misunderstanding of the business itself, not market volatility.
How do you determine who to trust in business?

Well, I think people give themselves away fairly often. When somebody comes to me with a business, the things they talk about, what they regard as important and not important, there are a lot of clues as to their subsequent behavior. Charlie and I have had very good luck in terms of buying businesses and putting our trust in people, but we filter out a lot of people.
Have you ever been taken advantage of in a financial transaction?

Fortunately, our batting average with the people we've joined with has been well above 90%. It hasn't been a hundred percent, but we've been very lucky. I do get letters all the time from people who have been taken advantage of, though, and it's really sad to see.
How do you approach thinking about the businesses you're invested in?

I think about them all the time, collecting little incremental bits of information about the company, its competition, and the industry. It's a continuous process, but not with the goal of making daily or weekly decisions. Instead, I'm always looking to refine my knowledge and thinking about each business.
What would you do if you needed a large amount of money for a big deal, say $40 billion?

If I needed that kind of money, I'd use the information I've been collecting over time to decide where to raise it. For example, I might decide to sell $10 billion of equities, using my accumulated knowledge to make that decision.
What advice do you give to students regarding the people they surround themselves with?

I tell them to associate with people who are better than they are. It's like the old saying 'marry up' - find somebody who's a positive influence and doesn't mind you 'marrying down.' It's a simple concept, but it can do wonders for your personal and professional growth.
Do you believe that the people who can serve as mentors or heroes are limited to those who are currently alive?

No, I don't think that's the case. As Charlie pointed out, some of the best mentors can be found in history - people who may be dead but whose ideas, values, and achievements can still inspire and guide us today.
How do you think Berkshire would perform during periods of high inflation?
Honestly, I don't think we'd do as well in real terms during high inflation as we do when inflation is low. But, I believe we'd still manage to do better than many other companies.
Are there any businesses that could potentially benefit from inflation?

Well, if you have a business that requires little capital investment and can easily raise prices without scaring off customers, you might actually come out ahead during inflation. For example, if people are willing to give up a half hour of their work each month to buy your product, that's a pretty flexible pricing situation. But, let's be clear, we're not big fans of leverage, we focus on owning good businesses.
How does the rail industry benefit from higher oil prices?

Well, as oil prices go up, it raises costs for both rails and truckers, but it hurts truckers about four times as much as it hurts us. That improves our competitive position, which is a nice tailwind for the rail industry.
Why might it be challenging for the rail industry to earn extraordinary returns on capital?

It's because the rail industry is very capital-intensive. We have to put out tons of capital every year, and that makes it tough to earn really high returns on that capital. But, if we can earn a decent return, that's okay - it can still be a good business over time.
What do you look for in a business to ensure its competitive position doesn't erode over time?

I look for businesses with strong competitive positions, and I think most of our businesses have that. It's like having a loaded gun - we're dealing from strength all the time. And I believe our owner-oriented culture and values, along with our terrific people, give us a solid foundation.
Can you share an example of how your companies have learned to adapt to challenges like foreign labor competition?

Well, Charlie here can tell you about our experience with foreign labor competition in the shoe business. Let's just say we've learned some valuable lessons, and as Charlie likes to quote Will Rogers, sometimes you wish you could learn those lessons without having to try them out the hard way!
What book had a significant impact on your investing approach and at what age did you read it?

The book that changed my life on investing is 'The Intelligent Investor'. I read it when I was 19 years old, down at the University of Nebraska. It's a book that I highly recommend, especially Chapters 8 and 20.
How did you initially approach investing before reading 'The Intelligent Investor'?

Well, I started investing when I was 11 and for about eight years, I wandered around with technical analysis and doing all kinds of things. It wasn't until I read 'The Intelligent Investor' that my approach to investing really changed.
What book do you think is great and has taught you valuable lessons about investing?

That would be 'The Intelligent Investor' by Ben Graham. I think it's as great a book now as I did when I first read it back in 1950. The lessons in that book have been invaluable to me over the years.
What was your experience like working at your grandfather's grocery store?

Well, let's just say Charlie and I weren't exactly the most skilled workers at the grocery store. We worked there a long time ago - Charlie was there about 70 years ago, and I was there too, though I don't recall exactly when. But my grandfather was a hard worker and had some strong opinions, especially about the stock market, which he was very negative about. We didn't exactly follow his investment advice, though!
How do you approach evaluating a potential stock purchase?

I approach it by looking at the business itself, not the stock price. It's similar to buying a farm - you'd evaluate its potential yield, costs, and overall value over time, not its daily price fluctuations. If the business is sound and attractively priced, I'd be happy to own it even if the market were to close for a couple of years.
What factors do you consider when assessing the value of a business, like the farm example you mentioned?

When assessing the value of a business, I consider factors like its expected yields or profits, the prices it can command for its products, taxes, and costs - similar to evaluating a farm's potential based on its expected yields, prices for its crops, taxes, and costs like fertilizer. These factors help me judge whether the business is a good investment at its current price.
What do you think are the essential courses that should be taught in a business school?

I believe there are only two courses that really matter: one is how to value a business, and the other is how to think about stock market fluctuations. Everything else, like option pricing, is just nonsense.
Why do you think business school instructors focus on complex formulas and theories?

It's because the instructors want to teach what they know, and they've spent a lot of time learning it. It's like a priest wanting to share their knowledge of intricate biblical details, but sometimes the simplest truths, like the Ten Commandments, are the most important. In finance, it's about buying into the right businesses at the right price, not about complex math.
You mentioned that you've never given up anything in your life that made a difference in your life when donating money. Can you elaborate on what you mean by that?

Well, I mean that I've been fortunate enough to have more than enough money to live the life I want, so when I give money away, it's not like I'm sacrificing something that would otherwise make a big difference in my daily life. For example, giving away a certain amount of money doesn't mean I have to skip a meal or cancel a vacation. I'm giving away excess, not something I need or would otherwise use.
How do you view your own charitable giving compared to others who may have to make more significant financial sacrifices when they donate?

Honestly, I think my charitable giving is not as impressive as someone who has to make real sacrifices in their life in order to give. I mean, if someone is choosing between donating money and being able to take their family out for dinner, that's a much tougher and more meaningful decision than mine. I'm just giving away money that I wouldn't have used anyway, so it doesn't feel like as big of a deal to me.
What do you think is the key to effective giving, based on your sister Doris's approach?

I think what my sister Doris does is terrific. She gives away not just money, but also her time, looking into the real needs of people and providing help and advice. That's what I call real giving - it's not just about writing a check, but about being involved and making a difference in people's lives.
Do you have any advice on how to avoid pitfalls when it comes to charitable giving?

Well, I think it's simple: give to things that you personally have an interest in and believe in. Don't try to prioritize what's most important - just focus on something that matters to you, and be willing to give your time as well as your money. And as Charlie pointed out, try to avoid letting extreme ideologies cloud your judgment!
Do you feel pressure from Berkshire's corporate office to meet specific earnings targets in any given quarter?

No, I don't feel any pressure from our corporate office to report specific earnings in any quarter. In fact, they don't even give me budgets, so there's no expectation to meet certain numbers. This approach has worked pretty well for us.
How do you handle the issue of labor standards in foreign plants, such as those in China or Central America?

Look, we're not going to tell the world how to run their business, but we do have some standards that need to be met. We recognize that factories in other countries may not have the same norms as we do in the US, and we're okay with that to some extent. We're not going to try to impose our will on them, but we do expect a certain level of decency and fairness in how workers are treated.
How do you maintain your good mental and physical health?

I start with a balanced diet, which for me includes things like Wrigley's, Mars, See's, and Coke. But I think the key is doing what I love every day, with people I enjoy, and having a great attitude about it. I also have a trainer who comes three times a week, which helps. Overall, I focus on the positives in life and count my blessings, which I believe helps maintain my mental and physical health.
Do you and Charlie Munger follow any specific health habits or dietary rules?

As Charlie said, we don't really pay much attention to health habits or dietary rules. We just do what we want and love what we're doing, and it seems to have worked pretty well for us so far. I mean, Charlie is 84 and I'm 77, and we're still going strong, so maybe that's the secret to our success!
Do you think CEO compensation accurately represents a market system?

No, I don't. I think it's ridiculous to believe that CEOs wouldn't do their jobs at half the price or even a quarter of the price. If it were truly a market system, you'd see bidders for their services, but that's just not the case.
Would you be willing to do your job for less pay?

Well, Charlie likes to point out that I'm in a job I'd pay to have, and I think that's true. I love what I do, and I feel fortunate to be able to do it. So, yes, I'd be willing to do my job for less pay - in fact, I think many CEOs would, if they're being honest with themselves.
What was your experience like working for Ben Graham, and what did you learn from it?

Working for Ben Graham was an incredible experience. I was only 24 at the time, and I was excited to learn from him every day. I jumped out of bed every morning, eager to start work and absorb as much knowledge as I could. I didn't even think about my salary when I took the job - I just knew it was an opportunity to learn from someone I admired.
How important do you think it is to have a supportive partner in life, and why?

I think having a supportive partner is enormously important. As I said, it's a huge decision who you marry, and it can make a big difference in your life. If you're lucky enough to find someone who supports you and you enjoy spending time with, it can make it a lot easier to behave well and be happy. And as Charlie likes to joke, finding the perfect partner can be a challenge - but it's worth it!
How did you overcome your fear of public speaking?

Well, I took a Dale Carnegie course, and I have to say, it wasn't easy at first. I initially signed up and then stopped payment on the check because I was so terrified. But I eventually went through with it, and after completing the course, I volunteered to teach at the University of Omaha to force myself to get up in front of people and practice my communication skills.
What importance do you place on the ability to communicate effectively in one's career?
I think the ability to communicate, both in writing and orally, is of enormous importance. It's something that I believe is under-taught, but it's crucial for success in any field.
Why do you think it's essential for introverted people to develop their communication skills at a young age?

I believe it's crucial to develop those skills early on because if you wait until you're 50, it's probably too late. By forcing yourself into situations where you have to communicate with others while you're young, you can build confidence and become a more effective communicator. It's like learning to ride a bike - the earlier you start, the more comfortable you'll become.
What approach do you recommend for introverted people to overcome their hesitation and become better communicators?

I think the best way is to get in with a group of people who are having equal problems. That way, you realize you're not alone, and you don't feel as silly. It's like taking a Dale Carnegie course, where you're with others who are struggling just like you. You can practice and build your skills together, and before long, you'll find you can actually pronounce your own name in front of a group! (laughs)
You mentioned employing a technique similar to pair trading in the 1960s. Can you explain how this technique worked and its goal?

Well, the idea was to reduce risk from overall changes in valuation standards. We'd buy a quality company at, say, 12 times earnings when similar but poorer-quality companies were selling at 20 times earnings. If the market then revalued and those poorer companies were only selling at 10 times earnings, we'd come out ahead. It's a bit like betting on the relative merits of two horses in a race, rather than trying to pick the winner of the whole race.
You also mentioned that Ben Graham had used a similar technique in the mid-1920s. How did his experience with this method turn out?

Ben Graham found that it worked modestly well - he was right about four times out of five, but when he was wrong, it tended to wipe out the gains from the four times he was right. It's a reminder that even with a good strategy, there are no guarantees in investing, and you have to be prepared for the unexpected.
What kind of market dislocations have you seen during the subprime crisis?

Well, I've seen some significant dislocations, particularly with credits trading at large discounts while equities haven't reflected this. It's created some interesting opportunities, but I'll let you figure those out for yourself.
Can you give an example of how you've taken advantage of these market dislocations?

One example that comes to mind is our involvement with tax-exempt money market funds, which relied on the repricing of high-grade municipal bonds. We've made some extra money from this, but I won't bore you with the details. Let's just say it's been an interesting ride.
What do you think is the key to learning and self-improvement?

I think the key is to just soak up as much information as you can, like a sponge. Read everything - World Books, newspapers, whatever interests you. The more you learn, the more you'll want to learn. It's a snowball effect, and it's a lot of fun.
What do you think about a young person's ability to succeed in life based on their curiosity and desire to learn?

Well, I think Charlie said it best - if you've got that curiosity and desire to learn, you've already got a big head start. My friend Charlie Munger seems to think that if you're already exhibiting those traits, you're well on your way to succeeding in life. And I tend to agree with him.
Why are you traveling to Europe to make presentations to potential sellers of businesses?

I'm going to Europe to make presentations because we want to be on the radar screen of potential sellers, so when the time comes for them to consider selling, they think of us. We're more well-known in the United States, and we're trying to increase our visibility in Europe.
Do you buy businesses or stocks at any price, or are you looking for specific criteria?

We don't buy at any price. We look for fair prices for businesses or stocks that we understand and like. We're not going to buy something just because it's available; we need to think it's a good investment at the right price. As I said, the stock market can give you bargain prices, but individual owners usually won't sell at a bargain price.
If you were to invest a large sum of money from another planet, would you put it all into U.S. dollars?
No, I wouldn't put all of it into U.S. dollars. In fact, I think it's wise to diversify and not have all your eggs in one basket, or in this case, one currency.
Do you currently hedge against currency fluctuations for your international investments, such as your stake in Coca-Cola?

No, we don't have a lot of hedges set up. I like that our investments, like Coca-Cola, earn money in various currencies around the world. Over time, I think this will be a net plus for us, and it has been in recent years.
What types of investments would you consider with a small portfolio under a million dollars, aside from buy-and-hold stock investing?
Well, I'd look at small stocks and mispriced bonds for opportunities. That's what I'd focus on with a smaller amount of money. It's like looking for treasures in a smaller pond, you know?
Would your investment approach with under a million dollars involve more active trading or arbitrage strategies, as opposed to your current buy-and-hold strategy?

Yes, that's right. With less money, I'd be more active, doing things like liquidation arbitrage or looking for net-nets, as Benjamin Graham used to talk about. It's a different game when you're working with smaller sums.
You mentioned having three potential CEOs who could step in and do a better job than you in many respects. What qualities do you think make them suitable for the role?

I think what makes them suitable is their ability to make good decisions and understand the Berkshire culture. I believe any one of them could step in and do a great job, but I'm not at liberty to disclose more details about their qualifications at this time.
You also mentioned having four potential investment officers in mind. What makes you confident that any of the four would be a good fit for the role if you were to pass away?

Well, I've gotten to know them, and I think they're all very talented individuals. They're reasonably young, very well to do, and they have good jobs now, but I believe any one of them would take the investment officer role if offered by the board, even at less money than they're making now. That gives me confidence that the transition would be smooth.
What will happen to the management of your investments after you're no longer around to make decisions?

Well, the board will decide who takes over - it could be one, two, three, or four people. They'll consider how the incoming CEO wants to work with them and make a decision based on that. So, there won't be any gap in having someone manage the money, and they might even do a better job than I do, especially since some of them have a better recent record than I do.
How do you respond to concerns about the aging management of your company, given your and Charlie Munger's advanced age?

I think it's funny that people worry about our age. Every management team ages, and we're actually aging at a rate of just 1 1/4 percent a year. That's the lowest rate I know of in corporate America. And let's be honest, if we found a management team that wasn't aging, we'd want to know their secret - maybe they're eating something we're not!
You mentioned that some people have close to a hundred percent of their net worth in Berkshire. Is it generally advisable to put such a large portion of one's net worth into a single stock?

Well, I think it's safe to say that it's not for everyone. But if you're talking about a company like Berkshire, or others like Cap Cities with Tom Murphy at the helm, or even Coca-Cola at certain points in time, then it's a different story. These are strong probability investments, not cinch categories, but strong nonetheless. If you've got a great manager and a solid business, it can be wise to load up, as Charlie and I like to do when we find such opportunities.
What's your view on diversification for investors, especially those who are not professionals?

Diversification is perfect for the know-nothing investor, and I mean that in the best possible way. If you don't know what you're doing, spreading your bets around is a good way to go. It's a safety net. But for the professional, it's a different story. We look for places where it's safe and wise to non-diversify, to put a significant amount of our net worth into something we really believe in. And that's how we've approached investments at Berkshire.
How do you think individuals should manage their finances within their household?

I think individuals should consider all their finances as working for their family, just like all our investments work for Berkshire. It's all one pot, and you should think about how it all contributes to your family's overall well-being.
Do you recommend keeping finances separate in a marriage, especially for newlyweds?

Well, I'm no marriage counselor, but I do think that if you're just starting out, it might be wise to keep your money separate for a while, just until you see how things play out. Unfortunately, a significant percentage of marriages do end in divorce, so it's better to be cautious at the beginning.
What policy decision would you implement regarding taxes if you were President?

I'd make sure the superrich, like myself, pay a little more in taxes, while the middle class pays a little less. It's only fair that those who have been blessed with enormous wealth contribute a bit more to the system.
Why did you joke about having a massive federal program for retirement homes if you and Charlie Munger were Presidents?

Well, I was just poking fun at our ages, I suppose. Charlie and I have done all right for ourselves, but we're not exactly spring chickens. The joke was a lighthearted way to acknowledge that maybe we're not the most likely candidates for the presidency, given our, shall we say, 'advanced' years.
What investment advice do you have for amateurs?
I think amateurs should stick with low-cost index funds. It's a simple, effective way to invest without getting in over your head.
Can you elaborate on why you recommend index funds for amateur investors?

Well, I didn't get a chance to elaborate in the text, but I will now - index funds are like a box of chocolates, they give you a little bit of everything, and the low-cost part is like having your cake and eating it too, you get the benefits of diversification without breaking the bank.
If you were 30-years-old again with your first million in the bank, how would you invest it, given you're not a full-time investor and can cover your expenses for 18 months?

I'd invest it all in a very low-cost index fund, probably something like Vanguard, because they're reliable and the costs are low. I'd do this knowing I'm an amateur investor and wouldn't be actively managing the funds, and I believe this approach would outperform bonds over the long term.
Why do you think most professional investors won't achieve screamingly successful results?

I don't directly address this in my part of the conversation, but my partner Charlie Munger does. He suggests it's because many professionals take 'croupiers profits' out of the system, essentially making money by charging fees rather than generating true investment returns. This is something to be aware of when considering investment options.
What was your initial reaction to Richard Branson's Virgin Cola?

I thought it was an unusual promise to have in a product, to be honest. I never could quite figure out what the promise was, and it seemed like a tough sell to compete with established brands like Coca-Cola.
Why do you think branded products like Coca-Cola and See's Candy are successful?

I think it's because they're runaway leaders in their field and deliver on a promise to the customer. People know what to expect from these brands, and they're willing to pay a premium for that consistency and quality. As long as you don't overpay for these brands, I think you're likely to do OK with your investment.
How do you and Charlie Munger typically handle investment decisions, and do you often need to discuss them at length?

We can usually make decisions quickly, often in just five minutes. Charlie and I think alike and have similar knowledge areas, so we don't need to talk things over extensively. If we're looking at a potential investment and see a significant difference between the price and value, we can move on it right away without needing to confer with each other.
What kinds of investments or opportunities do you tend to rule out immediately, and how does that help your decision-making process?

We rule out certain types of investments immediately, like startups. By doing so, we eliminate a layer of complexity and can focus on the opportunities that remain. We also have a knack for picking up on 'giveaways' early in a pitch that tell us an investment isn't right for us. This selectivity helps us avoid wasting time on things that aren't a good fit, and instead, we can spend our time on the opportunities we're truly interested in.
Do you think the Olympics should be used as a platform to address imperfections in countries like China?

No, I don't think the Olympics is the right way to do it. I believe that if a country is moving in the right direction, it's better to encourage them rather than being punitive. You may want to nudge them a bit, but the Olympics shouldn't be used as a means to address these issues.
How do you think countries like the US and China can learn from each other's progress towards perfection?

Well, I think it's a matter of recognizing that nobody's perfect, and we've all got our own set of problems. The US, for example, has come a long way since our Constitution said blacks were three-fifths of a person. We're still far from perfect, but we're moving in the right direction. I think countries can learn from each other by acknowledging their imperfections and encouraging each other to keep moving forward.
What do you mean by 'institutional stupidity' in the context of banks?

Well, when I say 'institutional stupidity,' I'm referring to the kind of reckless behavior that can get a bank into serious trouble. It's when a bank's culture and decision-making processes lead to actions that are just plain foolish, like taking on too much risk or ignoring warning signs. I think some banks are more prone to this kind of stupidity than others, and that's what I'm trying to avoid when I invest.
Do you think smaller banks are generally in better shape than larger ones, especially in terms of specific regional challenges like the Florida real estate situation?

That's an interesting question. I'm not saying that smaller banks are always better off, but I do think that in certain situations, like the Florida real estate market, the smaller banks might be more nimble and less exposed to the big risks. I mean, if you took the 20 smallest banks in Florida and compared them to the 20 largest, I'm not sure which group would come out on top. But I do think it's worth exploring, and that's why Charlie says it's a territory that has some promise.
What impact did the advent of television and cable television have on the sports industry, particularly in terms of revenue?

Well, it's quite simple really. Television and cable television multiplied the seats in a huge way, bringing in a lot more money. Think of it like a stadium that can now hold millions of people instead of just thousands. A lot of that money went to the players, but some of it did stick to the owners, making team ownership a more lucrative business.
Would you consider buying a sports team, such as the Cubs, if you had the financial means?

Honestly, I don't think I would buy a team like the Cubs at a price tag of $700 million. While there's certainly a psychic income to owning a sports team - it can make you famous and bring recognition - I'm not sure it's worth the cost. Plus, I've learned over the years that just because you can do something doesn't mean you should. There are plenty of other investment opportunities out there that might be more appealing to me.
Why do you think Americans do not save, according to your perspective?

Well, I think the propensity to save seems almost innate, and it's just not something that comes naturally to many Americans. I mean, we've seen other cultures, like the Asians, who save a significant portion of their income, around 40 percent. But for Americans, it seems like living beyond their means has become a bit of a habit.
How do you think owning Berkshire stock can help with saving?

If you own Berkshire stock, you're automatically saving because we retain earnings. As a shareholder, you have an indirect interest in those retained earnings, which is a form of saving. So, in a way, owning Berkshire stock can help you save without even thinking about it.
What was the Webvan business idea, and how did it turn out?

Webvan was an internet-based delivery service for groceries, similar to the old Buffett store. Unfortunately, it was a really asinine idea and met an ignominious failure. I have to say, though, that compared to some of the foolishness we've seen in the mortgage field, Webvan was a stroke of genius!
Do you have any general insights or solutions to the current problems being discussed?

Honestly, I don't have any great insights on solutions right now. I'm as puzzled as the next guy. But I do have a rule that seems to apply to a lot of situations, including politics: the politicians are never so bad you don't live to want them back. It's a bit of a cynical view, but it's served me well over the years.
Do you think Americans will change their preference for using cars over mass transit anytime soon?
No, I don't think that's going to change soon. The American public has a strong affection for their cars, and it's hard to see that shifting towards mass transit in the near future.
What's been your experience with trying to promote mass transit, given your past involvement in bus companies?

Well, I've learned that you can make all the rational arguments you want about the benefits of mass transit, but at the end of the day, many people still prefer the convenience and freedom of having their own car. It's a tough habit to break, and one that I don't think will change easily.
Why do you think Americans prefer driving their own cars to using mass transit?

I think it's just human nature - Americans seem to dislike waiting for buses or trams and prefer the convenience of driving their own cars, even if it means paying a lot to park and dealing with high gas prices. It's almost like it's in their genetic makeup to want that independence.
Do you think mass transit usage will increase significantly in the US anytime soon?

I doubt it. Unless there's some strong evidence to suggest a change, I don't like to bet on something that's been going in one direction for a long time suddenly reversing. Americans have shown a consistent preference for driving, and I don't see that changing without some significant shift in behavior or circumstances.
How do you prefer to learn new information?

I'm a reading guy, through and through. If someone's talking to me, it's either too slow, too fast, or it's something I already know. With reading, I can learn what I want at my own pace, and that works best for me.
Can you think of a specific book that had a significant impact on your financial life?

Yes, there's one book that really changed my whole financial life. I picked it up by chance when I was in school, and I don't even remember why I bought it. But that's the thing about reading - if you keep picking up enough books, you'll find some real gems.
Why do you think a group approach to investing in pharmaceutical companies makes sense?

I think a group approach makes sense with pharmaceutical companies because it's incredibly difficult to predict which specific company will have the next big breakthrough. By investing in a group of them at reasonable prices, you're spreading your risk and increasing your chances of being invested in the companies that will do well over time.
What's your outlook on the potential returns of pharmaceutical stocks if bought at a reasonable multiple?

If you buy a group of pharma stocks at a reasonable multiple, I think you'll probably do OK over the long term - five or 10 years from now. They're doing something enormously important, and that should offer chances for decent profits over time, even if they don't do quite as well as they have in the past.
What is your impression of the current state of the Chinese economy?

I think the Chinese economy is remarkable, with substantial GDP growth per capita. It's like a pent-up potential that's finally being unleashed after centuries of having a system that didn't allow people to reach their full abilities.
How do you think businesses or individuals can learn from others' successes and failures?

I believe you should look for the best practices and copy them, while discarding the rest. It's like studying effective individuals - you try to figure out why they're successful and emulate those qualities, while avoiding the qualities that make others unsuccessful.
What are your hopes for Berkshire Hathaway's future performance and culture?

I hope for two main things: decent performance and that we maintain our unique culture, which is both shareholder-oriented and manager-oriented. I believe these two goals are intertwined and will be key to our success in the long term.
Do you think Berkshire Hathaway's culture will endure beyond your tenure as CEO?

I fully expect it to. We've got the right people in place to succeed me, and our board and managers have all seen firsthand how well our system works. I think we have a strong culture that will outlast me.
What kind of results do you expect Berkshire Hathaway to achieve in the long term?

I think we'll get decent results, but not great ones, simply because of our size. It's like trying to maneuver a large ship - we can't be as agile as smaller companies, but we can still make steady progress.
What is your hope for how Berkshire Hathaway is perceived by owners of fine businesses?

My hope is that when they think about selling their business, they immediately think of Berkshire Hathaway as the ideal buyer, a place where they can trust their legacy and continue to work with their company for the rest of their lives.
What would have been the better investment, buying Treasury bills or putting money under a mattress, according to your example?

Well, believe it or not, putting money under a mattress would've been the better choice in this case. The person would've been $90 better off after four months compared to buying Treasury bills. It's a pretty stark illustration of just how unusual negative yields on U.S. Treasury bills are.
How much money could the U.S. Treasury have made if they sold $5 trillion of these Treasury bills, based on your calculations?

If the U.S. Treasury had sold $5 trillion of these bills, they could've made a quick $90 million. It's a humorous thought, really - Tim Geithner putting all that money under a Nervous Nellie mattress. But it drives home the point that negative yields are a truly extraordinary phenomenon.
What do you think is the current state of financial literacy, and do you believe it's a problem that needs to be addressed?

I think there's a problem with financial literacy with our current generation. It's a tough sell in a world of credit cards and calculators, but I hope our annual reports and other initiatives, like the upcoming ABC program, can contribute to improving it over time.
Are there any specific initiatives or programs that you're involved with to help teach financial literacy to younger people?

Yes, I'm involved with a program that Andy Heyward is working on, which includes a cartoon to teach financial literacy. Additionally, ABC has a program coming up with well-known personalities that will deal with the question of financial literacy, and I'll be playing a small part in it.
Do you agree with the chairman of Wells Fargo regarding the federal government's programs to reinvigorate the banks?

Yes, I do. Although, I must say, Charlie Munger's response sums it up nicely - when the government is reacting to a crisis, you can't expect perfect decisions. But I do share some of the concerns expressed by the Wells Fargo executives, and I think Charlie's blunt assessment of certain accounting principles is spot on.
What was the situation like in the financial system in mid-September last year, according to your description?

It was as close to a total meltdown as I can imagine. We saw a couple hundred billion dollars move out of money market funds in just a couple of days, and the commercial paper market froze up, which meant companies all over the country were going to have trouble meeting payrolls. It was a very dire situation.
What was your assessment of the actions taken during the financial crisis, particularly with regards to the treatment of banks?

I commend the actions that were taken. Overall, I think they did a very, very good job, considering the circumstances. It's unrealistic to expect perfection when people are working 20-hour days and dealing with new, often bad, information coming at them from all sides.
You mentioned Jamie Dimon's letter to his shareholders. What did you find noteworthy about it?

I found Jamie Dimon's letter to be fabulous. It's one of the best shareholders letters I've ever seen. He does a great job of explaining what caused the financial crisis and what might be done in the future. I highly recommend reading it, despite its length.
Do you and Charlie rely on complex financial projections when making investment decisions?

No, we don't. In fact, we've seen that some of the worst business decisions are made with a lot of formal projections and discounts. We prefer to keep things simple and act on opportunities that are obviously better than anything else around, as long as we understand them.
Can higher mathematics and complex calculations guarantee success in investing?

Not at all. I think higher mathematics can actually be dangerous in investing. It can lead you down pathways that are better left untrod. You don't need to understand higher mathematics to be a successful investor, and it's a terrible mistake to think that it will take you a long way in this field.
How are we currently addressing the issue of excess housing units in the US?

We're addressing it by producing less than the natural demand increase. Essentially, we've reduced the number of units being built each year from 2 million to 500,000, which will help absorb the excess supply over time. It's a gradual process, but we're making progress, eating up the excess inventory at a rate of about 700,000 to 800,000 units per year.
What's your outlook on the housing market once the excess inventory is absorbed?

Once we've absorbed the excess inventory, I expect to see a stabilization in pricing, followed by an increase in demand for new housing starts. This, in turn, will have a positive impact on related businesses, such as our insulation, carpet, and brick businesses. It's not a matter of if, but when, and I'm confident that the market will correct itself over time.
What two courses would you teach in your business school for investments?
I'd teach two courses: one on how to value a business and the second on how to think about markets. That's all you need to get started, in my opinion.
Do you think a high IQ is necessary to be successful in the investment business?
Not at all. If you have an IQ of 150, you could sell 30 points to somebody else - you don't need it. What's more important is having emotional stability and being able to think for yourself.
Did the businesses you bought in 2008 turn out to be good investments, despite the market conditions at the time?
Yes, we love those businesses. They were good investments, but the problem was there was no market for many businesses at that time, so their value wasn't reflected in the market.
How do you measure the performance of Berkshire's business, and have you ever under-performed the S&P over a 5-year period?

We measure our business performance against the S&P, using book value as a conservative proxy for intrinsic business value. And I'm proud to say that we've never had a 5-year period where we've under-performed the S&P in terms of intrinsic value.
Do you think Berkshire's market value accurately reflects the value of its retained earnings?
Well, so far, I think it has. Every dollar we've retained has translated into more than a dollar of market value, which is a pretty good test of our performance.
How does Charlie Munger feel about the unusual challenges Berkshire has faced in recent years?

Charlie doesn't get too worked up about these one-in-50-year events. He thinks that if we're prepared, take a small hit, and can capitalize on the opportunities that come out of it, then we've got no reason to shed any tears.
What was your reaction to Wells Fargo's stock price plunge, and what made you confident in the company's future?

I thought it was a great buying opportunity. The fact that the stock ticked below $9 a share, despite the company's strong business fundamentals, such as good spreads on business, strong depositing flows, and a cost of funds advantage, made me confident. I even told a class that if I had to put all my net worth in one stock, it would've been Wells Fargo at that price.
Do you think Wells Fargo will emerge stronger from its current challenges, and what factors contribute to your optimism?

Yes, I do. Wells Fargo's business model is fabulous, and the acquisition of Wachovia, with its large deposit base, will bring in new opportunities. As long as they don't issue a lot of new shares, I think Wells Fargo will be better off a couple of years from now than if none of this had happened. It's a great business opportunity, and I'm optimistic about their future.
What's the main problem with using leverage, according to you?

Leverage is what causes people trouble - it's like having someone who can pull the rug out from under you at any moment. You don't want to be in a position where others can force you to make decisions, or where your own emotions get the better of you.
How do you think people should evaluate their investments, like stocks or a farm?

I think people should look at the underlying business or asset, not just the price. If you own a farm, you don't worry about the daily price of the farm - you look at the production, the costs, and the overall health of the asset. That's how you should think about stocks too, not just letting the daily price quote dictate your emotions or decisions.
How do you run Berkshire, and what kind of culture does that create for the people involved?

I run Berkshire as if I owned all of it, which means we don't have a list of things we'd do differently if we had full ownership. This approach creates a culture where people don't have to adjust to a lot of self-imposed rules, like worrying about earnings predictions and all that jazz. It's a more straightforward way of doing business, and it attracts people who prefer to be part of an enterprise that operates this way.
What kind of response do you get from CEOs when you ask them what they'd do differently if they owned their company outright?

Well, I usually get a list of things they'd change if they had full control. But when I think about Berkshire, there isn't a list like that for us. We already run the company as if we owned it all, so there aren't any major changes we'd make if we had 100% ownership.
Why do you prefer not to webcast your meetings with students and shareholders?

I prefer personal contact because I believe it adds a dimension that's lost when you're just watching something online. It's like the difference between reading a book about Ben Graham's investment principles and actually sitting down with him - the latter is far more valuable. Personal contact allows for a deeper connection and understanding, and that's what I aim for in my interactions with students and shareholders.
Do you think webcasting would discourage attendance at your meetings?

No, I don't think webcasting would discourage attendance, but I do think it would change the nature of the meeting. If we webcasted, it would be like watching a TV show - people might tune in, but it wouldn't be the same as being there in person. We want our partners to show up, see our products, and engage with us directly. That's why we don't plan to webcast our meetings.
Why did you decide not to sell the Buffalo News despite its declining economic value?

I decided not to sell the Buffalo News because, even though it would have made economic sense to do so, our policy at Berkshire is to stick with businesses as long as we don't think we'll face unending losses or major union problems. It's not a traditional business school approach, but it's how we run things at Berkshire.
Do you think anyone will find a viable model for the newspaper business, given the current challenges?

Honestly, I don't know. With about 1,400 daily papers in the US and nobody having found a successful model yet, it's a tough situation. We're as well-positioned as anyone to figure it out, but whether we can find a solution before the financials become unsustainable, I just don't know.
How do you think consumer spending will change in the near future?

I think consumer spending will remain weak for quite a bit longer. People have changed their behavior, and I don't think that will go away very fast. After all, the government was telling people to save for years, and now that they're saving, they're not about to go back to their old spending habits overnight.
Will the housing market reach equilibrium anytime soon?

I think the housing market can reach equilibrium in a relatively short period of time, maybe even sooner than a couple of years. If we're forming households at a rate of a million or so per year, and we're only creating 500,000 new units, it's just a matter of time before supply and demand balance out. And when that happens, it will make a big difference for our businesses that rely on the housing industry, like carpet, brick, and insulation.
Why do you think Berkshire's credit rating is still triple-A, despite what Moody's may have indicated?

I believe Berkshire's credit rating is still triple-A because our management team prioritizes meeting our obligations above all else, including increasing earnings per share. We have a long-term view and take our commitments to creditors and others, like those receiving workers' compensation, very seriously.
Do you think the change in Moody's rating will have a significant impact on Berkshire's future?

No, I don't think the change at Moody's is going to be material in the future of Berkshire. It may irritate me, but I believe our financial strength and commitment to our obligations will continue to speak for themselves.
What happens when someone enters into a transaction with Berkshire and shows a profit, in terms of credit default swaps?

Well, the more profit they show, the more credit default swaps they have to buy to protect themselves against the receivable going bad. And that costs them real money every year, which can add up over time - in one case, it was costing them 5% a year, or $10 million on a $200 million asset.
How do you feel about people wanting to modify their contracts with Berkshire due to these credit default swap costs?
We're open to listening - if they want to modify their contracts enough, we'll definitely answer the phone. But for now, we're just sitting with the money, and it's not costing us anything.
What was the situation with Dynegy when you bought the pipeline from them in 2002?

Dynegy was in a tight spot financially and needed the money from the sale of the pipeline, which they had acquired from Enron, very badly. It was a complicated transaction, but we were able to move quickly and provide them with the funds they needed.
What advantages does Berkshire have that allowed you to move fast on the Dynegy deal?

We've got a couple of advantages that allow us to move quickly. First, we've always got the money, so we don't have to worry about financing. And second, we've got a mental attitude that lets us act fast when necessary. Plus, we've got talented managers who can deliver on the properties once we own them, which gives us the confidence to make deals happen quickly.
What happens to the dollars China receives due to the U.S. trade deficit?

Well, they end up with a bunch of dollars, which they can then convert into various U.S. assets like real estate, stocks, or government bonds. They can even trade them with other countries to get different currencies, but that just passes the problem on to someone else.
Can China simply get rid of its dollar holdings if it wants to?

No, they can't just get rid of owning more dollar assets as long as we're running a significant trade deficit with them. You see, if we're buying $250 billion more in goods from them than they're buying from us, they're going to end up with $250 billion in dollars, and that's just the nature of the trade. They can choose what to do with those dollars, but they're going to keep accumulating them.
What would Charlie Munger do if he were the finance minister of China?
According to Charlie, he would do exactly what China is doing now. He thinks their economic policies are 'exactly right' and have led to tremendous advancement, so he wouldn't change a thing.
How does Charlie Munger view a potential loss of purchasing power on China's dollar holdings?

Charlie views it as a 'trifle' - a small, insignificant matter in the grand scheme of things. He believes the benefits of China's economic policies far outweigh any potential losses in purchasing power from their dollar holdings.
Do you believe in conducting post-mortems on acquisitions, and why?

Yes, I strongly believe in conducting post-mortems on acquisitions. I think they're essential because it's easy to propose a deal, but it's much harder to account for it later on. It's like taking a hard look in the mirror - it helps you learn from your mistakes and improve for the future.
Why don't you think post-mortems on acquisitions should be made public?

I don't think post-mortems should be made public because it can be counterproductive. When you point out the shortfalls of a deal, you're also pointing out the mistakes of the managers involved, even if they're doing a great job trying to overcome those mistakes. It's not exactly the best way to attract businesses or motivate managers, if you know what I mean.
What was your initial impression of Gen Re's reputation when you bought it in 1998, and how did it turn out?

I was dead wrong about Gen Re's reputation when I bought it in 1998. I thought it still had the premier reputation it had 15 years earlier, but it turned out that some practices had changed, and it wasn't the same company. Luckily, with the help of Tad Montross and Joe Brandon, we were able to turn things around, and now Gen Re is the company I thought it was when I purchased it.
Who was instrumental in helping Gen Re recover from its problems, and what was the timing of their involvement?

Tad Montross and Joe Brandon were the key people who helped Gen Re recover. They took over in September 2001, right around the time of the World Trade Center incident, and went to work addressing the company's problems with reserving, underwriting, and other issues. I'm grateful for their hard work and dedication, which has paid off and given Gen Re a great future ahead.
Who was instrumental in the decision for Berkshire to buy General Re?
That was Joe Brandon. He was the one who decided that Berkshire should buy General Re, and I agree with Charlie, it wouldn't have happened without him.
Do you publicly discuss the dumb decisions made at Berkshire?
No, we don't. While we do review and learn from our mistakes internally, I don't think it's wise to disclose them publicly, especially if they might reflect poorly on some of our managers.
