What promise do you make to the people you buy businesses from?

We promise them that we're buying for keeps, just like a marriage. We're not going to spin something off just to get a higher multiple or temporary gain. We buy to keep, and people can trust us to keep our word on that.
Under what circumstances might Berkshire consider spinning off a part of the company?

To be honest, it would take something pretty extreme, like crazy regulation that's hurting one of our operations and tying the hands of other companies in the Berkshire group. But short of that, we're not interested in spinning things off just to please Wall Street or generate fees for investment bankers.
You mentioned that the system in place has unleashed human potential. Can you elaborate on what you mean by 'unleashing human potential' in this context?

Well, when I say 'unleashing human potential,' I'm talking about creating an environment where people can pursue their talents and abilities without unnecessary restrictions. It's like giving a skilled athlete the freedom to compete without being held back by arbitrary rules. In the case of China, they've transitioned to a system that allows their citizens to contribute and innovate, which has led to tremendous growth and progress.
You also mentioned that despite interruptions and setbacks, society moves ahead at a rapid rate. What kind of progress are you referring to, and how do you measure it?

I'm talking about the overall improvement in living standards and the quality of life. For example, in the 20th century, we saw a 7-for-1 improvement in living standards. That's a remarkable leap forward. And it's not just about economic growth; it's also about social progress, like the abolition of slavery, women's suffrage, and the recognition of equal rights. These advancements may not always be linear, but they demonstrate that, despite setbacks, we're moving in the right direction.
What does Charlie Munger see as the main benefit of harnessing solar energy?

Well, according to Charlie, having enough energy from solar power will enable us to solve a lot of our other problems, like turning seawater into fresh water and preserving hydrocarbon resources for future needs. It's a pretty straightforward idea: energy is the key to unlocking solutions to many of our technical challenges.
How does Charlie Munger's age affect his outlook on the economic future?

Interestingly, Charlie says that as he gets closer to the end of his life, he's actually becoming more cheerful about the economic future. I guess you could say he's looking on the bright side - and that bright side is literally the sun, with its potential to provide limitless energy and solve many of our technical problems.
What is the worst-case scenario you envision for Berkshire's insurance business?

I think the worst-case scenario for our insurance business would be a mega-catastrophe where we lose several billion dollars pretax. However, even in such a scenario, I don't think it would significantly impair our basic business. Another worst-case scenario could be high inflation, leading to people becoming unhappy with price increases and potentially calling for nationalization of the insurance industry.
How much would Berkshire's insurance business likely pay out in the event of a $100 billion catastrophe?
If we were to face a $100 billion catastrophe, I estimate that our insurance business would likely pay out around 3 to 4 percent of that amount, which would be $3 to $4 billion.
What is one part of your job that you dislike?
I have to say, it's dealing with situations where a manager is no longer able to perform their duties, often due to health issues. I hate it, and I'd pay a lot of money not to have to do it.
What kind of qualities do you look for in the managers of Berkshire's subsidiaries?

We look for people who genuinely love their businesses. It's a quality that's hard to put into someone, but it's easy to recognize when it's there. For example, Tony Nicely at GEICO is just as excited about the company today as he was when he first started working there as a teenager.
What happens when companies report earnings to the penny, and how does this relate to your management approach at Berkshire?

Well, when companies report earnings to the penny, it can lead to some funny business. As I mentioned, a study found that there were a statistically impossible number of fours showing up, because companies would somehow manage to find that extra tenth of a cent to round upward. At Berkshire, we don't worry about reporting to some specific penny or meeting Wall Street's expectations. We focus on building value over time, and we don't get caught up in trying to hit some specific earnings per share target.
Do you and Charlie Munger agree on the importance of not focusing on short-term earnings targets, and how do you think this approach benefits Berkshire?

Charlie and I are on the same page here. As he said, he agrees with me, and I think that's because we both believe in taking a long-term view. By not worrying about short-term earnings targets or investment gains and losses, we can focus on what really matters: building value for the enterprise as a whole. This approach helps us make decisions that are in the best interest of the company, rather than trying to meet some short-term expectation.
What does Charlie Munger think is needed to address the complexity in the financial system?
Charlie thinks we need a new version of Glass-Steagall that drastically limits what both commercial banks and investment banks are allowed to do, making their mode of business much simpler and safer.
What example does Charlie Munger use to illustrate the benefits of limiting a financial institution's activities?

Charlie uses the example of when we owned a savings and loan association, which had a very restricted repertoire of activities it could engage in and had government credit for its deposits, resulting in the savings and loans generally staying out of trouble.
Do you believe that the current system has reached its limits in terms of what humans can achieve?

No, I don't think we've come close to the limits of what humans can achieve. In fact, I think we probably don't even know our own potential, just like people in 1790 didn't know theirs. They were excited about the prospect of working 10 hours a day instead of 12, and I'm sure we'll have similar breakthroughs in the future.
Would you be concerned about Berkshire Hathaway's investment opportunities if you were limited to investing only in the United States?

Not at all. While I'd rather have the whole world to choose from, I think there would be ample opportunities for investment in the United States. I wouldn't run from the United States - there's plenty to work with right here at home.
How do you envision the process of selecting and compensating a new CEO for Berkshire?

We don't rush into things, so the process will be fairly leisurely. The new CEO's compensation will be worked out, probably in conjunction with the board, and it's not something that's fixed in stone at all. We've got some very able people who are interested in the role and would do a good job, so I'm confident we'll find the right person.
Do you believe Berkshire's culture will endure beyond your tenure as CEO?

I really think we have a strong and distinctive culture, one that's taken a long time to develop. It's self-reinforcing, and I believe it will outlast me. In fact, I think the people who come after me will love it just as much as I do.
Do you think it's easier to build a new organization with a good culture or change the culture of an existing one?

I think it's a lot easier to build a new organization around a culture than it is to change the culture of an existing organization. It's really tough to change a culture that's already ingrained in the people and systems of a company.
Have you and Charlie Munger ever tried to change the culture of an organization and faced challenges?

Yes, Charlie and I have bucked up against that a few times. We've tried to change cultures in some organizations, but it's proven to be tough. The culture at Berkshire, for example, is so ingrained in our managers and owners that I think it would be very difficult for someone to come in and try to change it significantly.
You mentioned starting from scratch with Berkshire in 1965. What was the state of the company like back then?
Well, to be honest, there wasn't much to it. It had some textile mills, but that was about it. It was a clean slate, which was a luxury for me as I got to build it up from there.
You also talked about trying to change the culture at Salomon. How would you rate your success in doing so?

I wouldn't give myself an A+ on that one. Changing culture is tough, and I learned that the hard way at Salomon. It's not something I'd say I was particularly successful at, but it was a valuable learning experience.
What do you think will happen to countries with very high deficits relative to their GDP?
I think those countries will see a significant diminution in the value of their currency over time. It's just a matter of economics - you can't keep piling on debt without consequences.
Do you think inflation will increase or decrease in the future?
I'd bet my life on higher inflation, and maybe a lot higher. The massive dosages of debt we've been taking on are a recipe for inflationary pressures down the line.
How do you think educating children about good financial habits can impact their lives?

I believe getting good financial habits early in life is enormously important. If we can teach kids some basic principles, they can build good habits around it, and that can be a real plus in their lives. It's not about changing the world, but about giving them a better chance to manage their finances wisely.
Do you think business schools have a role to play in preventing financial mayhem, or have they contributed to the problem?

To be honest, I think some of the problems we've seen in the last 30 years have actually been caused by the prevailing conventional wisdom in leading business schools. So, I'm not convinced that business schools are the answer to preventing financial mayhem. In fact, they may have contributed to it.
What do you think about the ability to predict inflation rates by looking at specific metrics?

I don't think you can look at any given metric in any given month and figure out exactly what that's going to do to inflation rates. Inflation can create its own dynamic, and we've seen that in the past, like in the late 1970s and early 1980s.
You mentioned an op-ed piece you wrote a year ago - what was the purpose of writing that piece?
I wrote that op-ed piece to sort of flash a yellow light, to warn about the potential consequences of continuing our current policies and the risk of inflation rising in the future.
How did you come to invest in BYD, a company that makes batteries and electric cars?

I have to give credit where credit is due - Charlie Munger deserves 100% of the credit for the BYD investment. I was going to let him answer that question, and as he mentioned, it was a team effort with Dave Sokol's help as well.
What does the BYD investment say about your learning process as an investor?

The BYD investment shows that even us 'old men' are still learning and expanding our circle of competence. As Charlie said, if the opportunity to invest in BYD had come along 5 or 10 years earlier, we might not have made the investment, but we've continued to learn and grow, which is essential for Berkshire's success.
What kind of return on investment do you think is reasonable for railroads to make in order to incentivize them to invest in improving the transportation system?

I think a decent return is necessary, and if the Service Transportation Board suggests something like 10 1/2 percent, I believe that's a reasonable number. It's not about earning exorbitant profits, but getting a fair return to justify the much-needed investments over the next few decades.
How do you view the current state of the American railroad industry in terms of its ability to adapt to the needs of the country?

I think the American railroad industry has done a fantastic job of adapting to our needs. As Charlie mentioned, they've essentially rebuilt the entire system over the last 30 or 40 years, improving tracks, tunnels, and bridges, and allowing for longer and heavier trains. It's a great example of wise regulation and management coming together to create a successful system.
Do you think short selling is inherently unethical or problematic?

No, I don't have a problem with short selling itself. In fact, I believe it's a legitimate practice when done responsibly. The issue arises when unethical practices are involved, such as spreading false information, which can happen on both the long and short side.
You mentioned that people don't like it when their conventional wisdom is challenged. Can you elaborate on how this relates to the efficient market theory?

Well, when we questioned the efficient market theory 30 years ago, it was like challenging a sacred cow. Many finance departments in major schools had fully bought into it, and if you didn't swear allegiance to it, you weren't going to get promoted. It's natural for people to resist when their deeply held beliefs are threatened, and that's exactly what happened back then.
What was the market share of the company when you first bought control, and what is it now?

When we first bought control, the market share was around 2-and-a-fraction percent. Now, it's up to about 8 1/2 percent. That's a significant increase, but I still think there's plenty of room for growth.
Have you considered expanding GEICO to other countries, and if so, what's holding you back?

Yes, we're aware of the possibilities for expansion, and I'm sure there are plenty of cars in other countries that could use insurance. But for now, we've decided not to pursue international expansion. It's not because we don't see the potential, but rather because we don't think we can replicate our competitive advantage in other markets, at least not in the near term.
Who do you envision as your audience when writing the Berkshire Hathaway report?

I write it with my two sisters, Doris and Bertie, in mind. They're intelligent and interested, but not necessarily familiar with all the business lingo, so I try to explain things in a way that's easy for them to understand.
How important are undistributed earnings from corporations where Berkshire Hathaway holds shares but doesn't control, compared to the past?

They're not as important as they used to be. These days, they're probably around 15 percent of our reported earnings, which is a much lower percentage than in the past. While they're still important, I don't think they're significant enough to devote a lot of space to explaining them in the report.
What is the main concern for bond insurers, in your view?

The main concern is contagion. You see, when one bond insurer gets into trouble, it can spread like a disease to others, causing a lot of instability in the market. It's a bit like a row of dominoes - when one falls, the rest can follow suit.
What kind of places do you and Charlie Munger prefer to invest in, when it comes to municipal bonds?

Charlie summed it up nicely - we like to invest in places that are both prosperous and disciplined. It's simple, really. You want to put your money in areas that have a strong financial foundation and a history of making smart decisions. As Charlie said, 'It's hard for an empty sack to stand upright,' so we look for places with a bit of meat on their bones, so to speak.
Do you think the world has already seen its most significant inventions, or is there still more to come?

I definitely think there's still more to come. In fact, I believe we haven't really started yet. If I had to pick a time in history to be born, I'd choose today, considering all the advancements and opportunities that lie ahead.
How do you think the world will adjust to potentially not relying on oil in the future?

Fortunately, I think the adjustment will be fairly gradual. It's not like we'll see a drastic drop in oil usage overnight. We've got a workable period of adjustment, and I think we'll find ways to adapt, especially since we'll still need oil and gas for chemical feed stocks more than for energy purposes.
How do you feel about buying when the market goes down?
I love it when the market goes down because it gives me the opportunity to buy more. It's like going to your favorite store and finding out everything is on sale - you're happy to stock up.
What advice would you give to someone who gets scared and wants to sell when everyone else is scared?

I'd say they need to change their mental attitude. Instead of relying on others to tell them when to buy or sell, they should focus on buying a good business at a decent price and then forgetting about it for a long time. It's also important to remember that the market's daily quotations shouldn't dictate their decisions - what counts is the quality of the business, not the market's mood.
Why do you think solar power is becoming a more prominent source of energy?

I think solar power is coming because we have no other practical alternative. The fact is, modern civilization would be in a really serious problem if we had no alternative to fossil fuels. It's just common sense that we need to move away from them, especially when you see cities choking to death on their own poisonous air.
Do you think the higher cost of solar power compared to traditional energy sources is a significant obstacle to its adoption?

Not really. I think the cost difference is just a blip in the economic future of our country. If solar power costs twice as much as what we're used to, that's not a huge deal in the grand scheme of things. And besides, I think it's likely that the cost of solar will come down over time, making it an even more viable option.
Do you think your current portfolio is significantly undervalued?

No, I don't think our portfolio is dramatically undervalued at this point. In fact, I've seen similar or even greater undervaluation in the past, and we're not expecting any explosive growth from our current holdings.
What's your overall outlook for the performance of your portfolio?

We think we'll do reasonably well over time. We've got a lot of good businesses, and we try to allocate capital in a rational way without wasting money. So, while we don't have any home runs in our portfolio right now, we're expecting steady, reasonable performance.
You mentioned being optimistic despite concerns like inflation and government debt. Can you explain why you're optimistic about the future?

Well, I think it's pretty simple. As I said, if I can be optimistic when I'm nearly dead, the rest of you should be able to handle a little inflation! But seriously, I believe that humanity has made tremendous progress and will continue to do so. Charlie mentioned that having solutions to our main technical problems, like energy, on the horizon is a big benefit to humanity, and I agree with that.
You also mentioned that children in India, China, and our own country will live better than we do today. What makes you think that's the case?

I think it's because, despite the challenges we face, the overall trend is still upwards. We're making progress in so many areas, and that progress tends to build on itself. It's like a snowball rolling down a hill, gaining size and speed as it goes. I'm not saying it's all going to be easy, but I do think that our children and grandchildren will have opportunities and standards of living that are beyond what we can even imagine today.
What gives you pleasure, and why do you think it's justified?

I get pleasure from seeing people who've had a tough time, through their own hard work and talents, rising rapidly - like in many parts of China and India. And why shouldn't I? It's a great thing to see people succeeding and improving their lives.
You mentioned that reduced expectations can lead to happiness. Can you elaborate on that?

Well, it's quite simple really. Getting your expectations down is a lot easier than getting your results up. It's just common sense. And I think that's a key to happiness - having realistic expectations and not getting too worked up about things that are outside of your control.
Why do you prefer TV interviews over other forms of media?

I prefer TV interviews because they provide a permanent record of exactly what I said, without any interpretation or editing by reporters or editors. It's like having a direct conversation with the audience, where they can see my body language and tone, and understand the context of my words.
Do you think your media exposure benefits Berkshire's shareholders?

Probably not. I mean, I do a lot of things that aren't directly related to Berkshire, like playing bridge on the internet. While I think my media exposure can be beneficial for the American public, I'm not sure it's the best use of my time from a shareholder perspective.
What was the key factor that you believed would contribute to Pete Kiewit's success?

I think it was his discipline and focus on doing things right, avoiding trouble, and putting in the effort to understand the fundamentals of his business. It's not about being brilliant, but about avoiding the obvious mistakes.
Did Charlie Munger have any formal business education that helped him develop his business acumen?

No, Charlie didn't take any business courses in school. He actually took accounting, and his interest in business and valuing companies started when he was a little boy, just by observing and asking questions about how businesses worked.
What kind of businesses do you like, and why?

I like great consumer businesses that need relatively little capital. You know, businesses where people pay you in advance, like magazine subscriptions or insurance. It's like using your customer's capital, which is a pretty sweet deal. And service-type businesses, like Business Wire, are also attractive because they don't require a lot of capital to operate.
What makes a business successful in terms of pricing power?

Well, as Charlie pointed out, a business with incredible pricing power is often a monopoly or a near monopoly. That's a pretty straightforward formula, and it's something we've seen time and time again in successful businesses.
What advice would you give to a young entrepreneur on how to build wealth within their own business?

I'd tell them to start with the principle that Aristotle mentioned, which is to spend less than you earn. And then, I think it's crucial to follow your passion. When you love what you do, you're more likely to do well in it. I've seen this with our managers - they all have different backgrounds, but the common factor among them is that they're passionate about their work.
How did you discover your own passion for the securities business?

I got lucky, to be honest. My father was in the securities business, so I was exposed to it from a young age. I'd go to his office and read books on the subject, and I just got entranced with it. I think I would have discovered my passion for it eventually, but having that early exposure definitely helped.
What is the central philosophy behind the unconventional practices you and Charlie Munger follow, such as not changing the management of acquired companies and not encouraging retirement?

Well, I think it's quite simple really. We just do what makes sense to us, and that's often the opposite of what others are doing. For instance, we believe in applauding longstanding employees and keeping them on, rather than looking for 'fresh blood' all the time. It's like a good recipe - if it works, why change it?
You mentioned not providing earnings guidelines and not living near New York. Are these decisions also part of your central philosophy?

Yes, they are. We just don't believe in playing the earnings guidance game, and as for living near New York, well, we like it just fine in Omaha. It's a bit like choosing a good investment - you go with what you know and what works for you, rather than following the crowd.
What is your fundamental or unified theory of management in life?
Well, I'd say it's pragmatism, as Charlie pointed out. We do things our way because it suits us and our temperaments, and most importantly, because it works. It's as simple as repeating what works.
Can you summarize your approach in a concise manner?
As Charlie said, our fundamental algorithm of life is to repeat what works. That's it. We've found that when something is working well, it's just good sense to keep doing it.
What is your assessment of Berkshire Hathaway's exposure to a potential global financial meltdown, given the current increase in debt in cities, states, and countries?

I believe Berkshire can withstand anything that any corporation can. While we do have significant exposure through our municipal bond insurance, including $40 billion in municipal bond insurance and $8 billion to the states, I'm confident in our ability to weather a storm. As I've said before, huge amounts of debt are not going to do us in.
Could a large-scale financial event, similar to the 2008 crisis, cause a significant number of losses in our investments and lead to an AIG-type situation?

I think it's unlikely. In 2008, I believed the government could solve the panic, and they did. I think they would do the same in a similar situation. While there's always a risk of correlated losses, I believe Berkshire's diversified portfolio and strong financial position would help us navigate such a scenario. We came close to a total meltdown in 2008, but the government stepped in, and I think they would do so again if needed.
Do you think the government would take swift action in the event of an extraordinary economic crisis, similar to 2008?

I do. Having gone through 2008, I believe our government has learned the importance of taking massive action quickly when needed. They've shown they can do it, and I think they'd do it again if faced with a similar situation.
Can huge amounts of debt cause significant harm to Berkshire?

No, I don't think so. As I said, huge amounts of debt are not going to do us in. We're built to withstand financial shocks, and while I can't guarantee protection against extreme events like a comet hitting us, I'm confident that Berkshire can handle financial challenges posed by debt.
What was your initial reaction to the events surrounding David Sokol and the purchase of Lubrizol stock, and how did it compare to the Salomon situation 20 years prior?

My initial reaction was that what happened was inexcusable and inexplicable, similar to my reaction during the Salomon situation 20 years ago. I still don't understand why certain events transpired, and in the case of David Sokol, I believe he violated our code of ethics, insider trading rules, and the principles I've laid out for our managers.
You mentioned that David Sokol made no attempt to disguise his purchases of Lubrizol stock. What did you find puzzling about this, given the potential consequences of insider trading?

I find it puzzling that David Sokol didn't attempt to disguise his purchases, given the potential consequences of insider trading. He was leaving a clear record of his transactions, which seems inexplicable if he knew the penalties that could be attached to it. It's surprising that someone with his experience and net worth would take such a risk so openly.
Do you think the market will react significantly when a tax program comes to an end?

I don't see why it would. The market tends to build in expected changes like that ahead of time, so by the time the program actually ends, it's already factored into the prices. Of course, there could be other factors at play, but solely because of the program ending, I don't anticipate a big reaction.
How do you think the market will change when the current purchasing of Treasurys stops?

Well, it's certainly going to be different. When you're buying $600 billion worth of Treasurys, that's a huge market force. But I think the market has already anticipated this change. The government will still be issuing debt at a consistent level, so it's not like the market is going to be completely flipped on its head. It'll just be a different market, one that we've already seen coming.
What makes it difficult to change CEOs at companies, especially if they are mediocre?

Well, it's tough because a mediocre CEO, particularly one who's also the chairman, has a lot of control - they set the agenda and all that. It's not easy to displace someone in that position, even if they're not doing a great job. It's like trying to remove a captain from a ship while it's still sailing.
What qualities do you think are vital for a CEO of Berkshire to have?

I think it's vital for the CEO to be a high-quality human being, not just a skilled manager. They need to care more about Berkshire's success than their own personal advancement. It's a matter of putting the company first, and I believe we have several candidates who fit that bill.
Why do you think banking can be a very good business, according to the text?

I think banking is a very good business because you get your money cheap, there's an implicit federal guarantee, and you can leverage up to a fair extent. Plus, America's been a pretty good place to lend money, which helps.
What do you recommend readers do regarding the annual reports of M&T Bank and JPMorgan?

I highly recommend reading the annual reports of M&T Bank, specifically Bob Wilmers' letter, and Jamie Dimon's letter at JPMorgan. They offer great insights into the banking scene, the economic scene, and even some moral perspectives on business that I think are well worth reading.
How did you initially attract your first investors for your investment fund?

Well, it was pretty straightforward, really. A few members of my family approached me after I moved back to Omaha in 1956 and asked if I'd manage their investments, just like I had done before I left for New York. I also had a roommate from college and his mother join in. It wasn't about making a big pitch or anything; they just knew me and trusted me to handle their money.
What was your approach to communicating with these early investors about their investments?

To be honest, I told them I wouldn't be keeping them in the loop about every little thing. I said I'd be investing their money just like I would my own, and that was it. I didn't want to have to worry about explaining every decision to them, especially if things didn't go exactly as planned. I figured it was better for everyone if I just focused on making good investments, without having to justify each move to my partners.
What would you like to be remembered for 100 years from now?
I'd like to be remembered as a 'teacher'. I really enjoy teaching and sharing my knowledge with others, and I've been fortunate to have had some great teachers in my life, like my dad and Ben Graham.
Is there a particular quote or saying that you think encapsulates how you'd like your legacy to be viewed?

Well, Charlie mentioned a saying from one of his great grandfathers about having a 'fortune fairly won and wisely used', which I think is a great way to look at it. But for me, it's more about being seen as someone who taught and shared their knowledge with others.
How does the tax treatment for trading S&P 500 contracts compare to other types of work?

Well, it's pretty straightforward - if you're trading S&P 500 contracts, even for just 10 seconds, 60% of your gain is considered long-term and is taxed at a lower rate, 15% maximum. On the other hand, people doing everyday jobs like cleaning washrooms don't get this special tax treatment. It's a bit absurd, if you ask me.
What's the issue with how the tax code is structured regarding this specific tax treatment?

The problem is that a small group of people, who really care about this tax treatment, can influence the system to their benefit, while the cost of it - less revenue for the government - is spread out among a large group of people who don't have enough of a stake to fight against it. It's a classic case of concentrated benefits and diffuse costs.
What is the current status of your 10-year bet against hedge funds, and how will you report on its progress?

Well, it's a 10-year deal, and we're three years in. I've promised to put the figures up every year, and I'll continue to do that. We'll report annually on how the S&P 500 is doing compared to the five funds of funds chosen by Ted Seides and his friends. It's been an interesting start, and I'm looking forward to seeing how it all plays out over the next seven years.
Who seems to be benefiting the most from this bet so far?

As Carol Loomis from Fortune Magazine pointed out, the investment managers are the ones who are ahead so far. The investors in both the S&P 500 and the funds of funds are behind, but the managers are doing just fine. It's a bit ironic, isn't it? (Laughs)
What did Charlie Munger learn from reading the book 'In the Plex' about Google?

Well, I learned about the engineering culture at Google, which I found quite interesting and peculiar, different from what we have at Berkshire. I enjoyed learning about it, and that's what matters to me - going to bed a little wiser every night.
What did you learn in the last year, according to your response?
Ha! I learned that I'm going to have Charlie write the next press release. Just kidding, but I did appreciate Charlie's sense of humor about approving the last press release with no objections.
Why did you decide to make a change regarding your role at the Post?
I decided at 80 that I'd been there since 1974, with a brief interruption, and it just seemed like the right time for a change. Plus, I'm available a lot cheaper now if they want any advice!
Do you think serving on multiple boards is a good idea?
No, I agree with Charlie - serving on a whole lot of different boards is not a good idea. I think it's better to focus on a few where you can really make a difference.
Do you view Berkshire's equity portfolio as an afterthought compared to large acquisitions?

No, I don't view it that way at all. While I do prefer large acquisitions, the equity portfolio is still very important to us. In fact, Charlie and I spend a significant amount of time thinking about it, probably more so than acquisitions, since those opportunities are less frequent.
How do you see the equity portfolio evolving over the next five to ten years?

I see it as a key part of our operations, and we'll continue to spend a lot of time thinking about it. We're also hoping to add significant companies to our portfolio through acquisitions, and our existing companies will continue to make bolt-on acquisitions to grow their earnings. I'm optimistic that many of our companies will be earning considerably more money in five or ten years than they are now.
What makes Ajit Jain's thinking impressive to you?

Ajit is as rational a thinker as Charlie is, or anybody I've met. He loves what he does, he's creative, and his mind works like a machine. I've never seen him make a decision that I think I could have made better, and that's saying a lot.
What do you consider your best deal?
My best deal was hiring Ajit Jain. I don't know what his best deal was, but I know that bringing him on board was one of the smartest decisions I've ever made.
What kind of businesses have you found to be the most challenging for Berkshire to succeed in?

I'd say retailing has been our toughest nut to crack. We've had some successes, like See's, but overall, we haven't created the kind of earning power in retail that we have in other areas. And I think that's because retail is just a very competitive space.
You mentioned someone who could create hundreds of millions of wealth without lifting a finger. What kind of person are you describing?

I'm talking about someone who's very smart and has a great reputation, so much so that people would be willing to give them a significant percentage of a new company just for being involved. But this person, who I think is a remarkable human being, doesn't take advantage of those kinds of opportunities. Instead, they seem to really enjoy what they do at Berkshire.
How do you think about goodwill when evaluating a business, and when is it relevant to consider it?

I think goodwill should be ignored when evaluating the fundamental attractiveness of a business. Instead, look at the return on tangible assets. However, when evaluating how well management is allocating capital, you have to consider goodwill because it represents a significant portion of the capital that was paid for the business.
Can you provide an example of when goodwill should not be amortized, and how that affects the evaluation of a business?

Take a brand like Coca-Cola, for instance. It's an indestructible brand that becomes more valuable over time. In that case, I don't think the goodwill associated with it should be amortized. When evaluating the economics of the Coca-Cola business itself, you shouldn't consider the goodwill. But if Berkshire were to purchase Coca-Cola, we'd have to account for the goodwill when evaluating our own capital allocation, because we paid a significant amount for it.
Why do you think the amortization of goodwill doesn't make sense?

I think it's because when you look at a business, you should focus on the return on net tangible assets. Amortizing goodwill can distort that view. Instead, write-offs of goodwill make more sense when you realize you've made a wrong purchase and the business isn't earning as expected.
How do you evaluate the performance of a business like Lubrizol after acquiring it?

Well, when we acquired Lubrizol, we paid close to $9 billion for the equity. To evaluate its performance, I look at the return on net tangible assets. In this case, Lubrizol earns about $1 billion pretax, and it's employing around $2.5 billion of equity to do so. That's a good business. But when I judge our investment, I have to consider the full $9 billion we paid, which changes the picture. It's like judging two different investments - one based on the business's own capital, and another based on the price we paid to acquire it.
Why do you think business schools don't teach the history of business using the kind of graphs you prefer?

I think it's because those graphs would trample on the territories of professors in subdisciplines like marketing and finance. In academic bureaucracies, people tend to protect their own turf, just like what happened at General Motors.
What was Charlie Munger's request when you both were jokingly 'hijacked' on a plane?
Charlie wanted to give his speech on the virtues of Costco, with illustrations. I have to say, that's a pretty typical request from Charlie, and it's a testament to his passion for the company.
How do societal issues like limited clean water supplies and declining food stocks impact your investment decisions?

To be honest, they don't affect our investment strategy to any real degree. We focus on what we expect a company's earning power to be in the long term, and societal issues like those don't really enter into our decision-making process.
Are there any specific types of businesses you'd like to invest in, despite these societal concerns?

Well, we'd love to buy another business like GEICO, BNSF, or MidAmerican. We look for companies with strong earning power that we can hold onto for the long haul, regardless of broader societal issues.
You mentioned that with enough energy, the water problem goes away. Can you elaborate on how energy helps solve water scarcity issues?

Well, think of it like this - if you've got enough energy, you can desalinate seawater, like Israel does. They can make half their water from seawater when they need to, and that's a game-changer. It's like having a faucet that never runs dry, as long as you've got the energy to power it.
You seem to be critical of the idea of drilling for more oil. Why do you think preserving our own hydrocarbons is a better strategy?

I think it's just common sense, really. If someone else has hydrocarbons they're willing to use up, that's fine - we can use theirs while preserving our own for the future. It's like saving for a rainy day, except the rainy day is when the oil really runs out. And let me tell you, I think we'd all be a lot happier if we'd stored some of that cheap oil from the Middle East away for later, instead of burning it all up.
What is your long-term goal for the return on the money you keep from investors?
My goal is to earn a better-than-average return on that money, which should translate into our stock selling at a premium. It's not about short-term wins, but about consistently delivering over time.
Have you been able to beat the market averages with your investments?

Yes, we have continued to beat the market averages, although I have to admit, it's getting tougher every year. And as Charlie pointed out, we may not be beating our own past record, but that's a high bar to set.
Why did you set different interest rates for the various transactions, such as Goldman, GE, Dow Chemical, Wrigley-M&M Mars, and Swiss Re?

Well, each of those deals was done at a different time, and market conditions were different. Our opportunity costs varied with each transaction, which influenced the terms we agreed to. It's like trying to time the market - you can't always predict what's going to happen next, and you have to make decisions based on the circumstances at the time.
Do you think you could have done a better job allocating your money during the post-panic period, considering the terms of the deals you made?

Honestly, yes. I was early on Goldman and GE, and if I had waited a bit, I might have gotten even better terms. But, as I said, we don't have perfect foresight, and sometimes our timing is off. Still, I'm satisfied with the decisions we made, given the information we had at the time.
How do you approach decision-making when considering new deals, and do past deals influence your thinking?

I approach each deal on its own merits, considering what else I could do with the available funds at the time. Past deals don't really influence my thinking - in fact, trying to measure every new deal against the best one you've ever made can be a huge error. It's about making the best deal you can at the time, not trying to top something you've done before.
What's the potential pitfall of comparing new deals to your best past deals?

The pitfall is that you might take yourself out of the game by setting an unrealistically high bar. The goal isn't to make a better deal than you've ever made before, it's to make a satisfactory deal that's the best you can make at the time. Charlie's analogy about marriage is apt, but I'll let him tell you more about that - the point is, you've got to be rational about opportunity costs and not get hung up on past successes.
Do you think Congress will ultimately raise the debt ceiling?

I believe they will. In my view, there's no chance they don't increase the debt ceiling. It would be, as I said, an asinine act if they didn't, considering our current deficit and the fact that we're a growing country with a growing debt capacity.
What's the key difference between borrowing in your own currency versus another currency, according to you?

The difference is night and day. As long as we keep issuing our notes in our own currency, the United States is not going to have a debt crisis of any kind. This flexibility is crucial and significantly reduces our risk compared to borrowing in another currency.
What are the main concerns for countries that give up the right to issue debt in their own currency, like members of the European Monetary Union?

Well, I think the main concern is that you can't just print money to pay off your debts. You have to rely on your co-members to help you out, which can be a pretty big step. It's like giving up control of your own financial destiny.
Why do you prefer borrowing in your own currency, as seen in the example of trying to buy a bank in Chicago in the late 1960s?

It's simple: when you borrow in your own currency, you have more control over the value of the money you're paying back. If you borrow in someone else's currency, like we considered doing with Kuwaiti dinars, you're at the mercy of exchange rates and foreign economic policies. It's a lot riskier, and I like to keep things straightforward and under my control.
Do you apply the same principles of investing in businesses within the United States to investments outside of the country?

Yes, I do. The basic principles of trying to value a business, finding managements with both ability and integrity, and finding an attractive purchase price apply wherever in the world we're investing.
Are there any countries that are too small for Berkshire to consider investing in?
Yes, there are. Some countries are just too small and won't have businesses large enough to 'move the needle' at a company like Berkshire, so those are off our list.
Why did Berkshire put money into companies that were bankrupt, such as NetJets?

We put money into those companies to make them whole, essentially. It's like helping out a family member in need - you don't just walk away, you try to make things right. And that's what we did with NetJets and other companies that were in trouble.
Can you give an example of another company that Berkshire helped to avoid bankruptcy?

Yes, we had a couple of examples, actually. One was Southern Casualty in Louisiana and another was a company in Chicago. If we had left them to their own devices, they would have gone bankrupt, but we didn't even think about not helping them out. We made them whole, just like we did with NetJets.
What advice do you give to young people from an investment perspective to help them chart their own course?

I'd say the main thing you can do is invest in your own skills. Anything you do to improve yourself, you never know where it's going to pay off later on. For me, that meant a lot of reading and taking courses like the Dale Carnegie course, which was incredibly valuable.
You mentioned the Dale Carnegie course was particularly valuable - can you elaborate on why it was so important to you?

That course, which cost me just $100 back in 1951, has been incalculable in terms of value. I think it's because it focused on communications skills, which I believe are essential for enhancing your value throughout life, no matter what you do.
How important is it to find your passion early on and work to improve your skills in that area?

I think it's crucial. If you get lucky and find your passion early on, that's great. But what's more important is working at something you're passionate about and then putting in the effort to improve your skills in that area. I believe that's a recipe for doing very well.
Do you think taking courses in economics is essential for someone looking to learn and succeed?

Honestly, I don't think so. I mean, I took economics courses at Wharton, but I don't think they were the key to my success. Charlie and I were just discussing how economics can be a complex and disagreed-upon field, even among experts. I'd advise mastering the basics first and not getting too caught up in the more complicated aspects of the field.
How did your experience in the reinsurance business unfold in the first 15 years after starting it around 1970?

Well, to be honest, we didn't succeed at all in the reinsurance business in the first 15 years. Despite having a talented person like George Young running it, the business wasn't good for us, even when considering the value of float. It wasn't until Ajit came along that things started to turn around.
What's the main challenge in the reinsurance business that can lead to significant losses if not properly managed?

The main challenge is factoring in the risk of infrequent events into your pricing. It's like accepting bets on unlikely outcomes - you might win a lot of small bets, but when you lose, you can lose big. If you don't price these risks correctly, you can fool yourself into thinking you're doing well for a few years, but ultimately, you'll end up losing a lot of money.
How do you think an investor's performance should be judged?

I believe an investor's performance should be judged over a longer period, like five years. You just can't get a good read on someone's abilities in six months or a year - it's like trying to determine if a baseball player is going to have a great season based on one game.
What qualities are you looking for in an investment manager for Berkshire?

We're looking for the right people, and that doesn't just mean someone with a high IQ or a great past record. It means a lot of things - we need people who fit our culture and approach. Having multiple investment managers could be a plus, but we don't need to force it - we just need to find the right folks to manage our money effectively.
What are your thoughts on Johnson & Johnson's recent acquisition of Synthes for $21 billion, specifically regarding the use of stock in the deal?

I'd like the deal a whole lot better if it was all for cash. Johnson & Johnson has the ability to pay cash for a $22 billion deal, and when they trade away their stock, it's like they're saying their own businesses are fully valued or the seller is making a mistake. I just prefer cash deals in this situation.
How does your opinion on this deal compare to your previous stance on Kraft's acquisition of Cadbury, which also involved a significant amount of stock?

Well, I was quite outspoken against Kraft's deal for Cadbury, and similarly, I'm not thrilled about Johnson & Johnson's use of stock in this deal. My concern is the same - when a company uses a lot of stock to make an acquisition, it raises questions about the value of their own business and the wisdom of the deal. I just think cash is a cleaner way to do these things.
How do you approach reserving at GEICO and Gen Re?

I'd say our overriding principle is to reserve conservatively. It's a mindset that serves us well, especially in the auto business where claims can be settled quickly. We've had good experience with this approach, as you can see from GEICO's consistent redundancies over the years.
Can you give an example of a challenging reserving situation?

Take 9/11, for instance. It was tough to determine the extent of business interruption insurance claims, like whether closing a restaurant at an airport 2,000 miles away from the attacks would be covered. These kinds of situations can take years to work out, but in the end, we were actually over-reserved for 9/11.
How often do you typically communicate with the CEOs of your largest investments?

I'd say we don't talk to them very often, maybe twice a year at most. And let me be clear, we're not calling them up to offer advice. If we thought our investment's success depended on us telling them what to do, we'd be out of there in a hurry.
What is the total value of your four largest investments?
Those four investments are worth at least $50 billion today. We've held some of them for a long time, 20 or 25 years, and they've done just fine without us meddling in their business.
Why did you include a statement in the prospectus that neither you nor Charlie would buy the stock at the offered price?

Well, we did that because we thought the stock was a little overpriced at the time, and we wanted to be honest with our potential investors. It's like if I were selling you a car, and I thought it was worth $10,000, but I was asking $15,000 for it - I'd want to tell you that I wouldn't buy it myself at that price. We just wanted to be upfront about our valuation.
Will you ever announce if you think the stock is selling above its intrinsic business value?

No, I don't think we'll ever do that. I mean, how would we even know for sure? And even if we did, I'm not sure it would be helpful to announce it. We'll just stick to what we're doing now - if we think the stock is undervalued, we might buy some back, and if we think it's overvalued, we'll just keep quiet and not encourage people to buy it.
What is your view on the current state of U.S. banks compared to European banks?

I think U.S. banks are in a far, far better position than European banks. They've taken their lumps, built up their capital, and have plenty of liquidity. In contrast, European banks were struggling just a few months ago and needed a big boost from the European Central Bank to stay afloat.
What did the European Central Bank do to help European banks, and why was it necessary?

The European Central Bank provided about a trillion euros of liquidity to European banks, which is roughly $1.3 trillion. This was necessary because European banks were losing their funding base, particularly the wholesale funding they rely on, and were in danger of running out of money. The ECB's action gave them a lifeline, providing funding for three years at a very low interest rate of 1 percent.
What was your initial reaction to the Treasury and the Fed's decision to force banks to take money during the financial crisis?

I thought they were maybe a little overdoing it at the time, but in hindsight, I think the policy was very sound for the country's economy. As a shareholder, I might not have liked it if one of the banks I had a stake in was forced to raise capital it didn't need, but overall, I believe our society benefited greatly from their actions.
How do you compare the risk profile of the United States to that of Europe, especially in terms of handling financial stresses?

It's night and day. The United States has a full federal union, which allows our central bank to print its own money and pay off its own debt. In contrast, Europe's lack of a full federal union makes it much more difficult for them to handle financial stresses. I think this difference puts the United States in a more comfortable position when it comes to risk profile.
Do you think the current usage of natural gas is sensible, given its potential value to future generations?

I don't think it's sensible at all. As Charlie said, it's idiotic to use up a precious resource like natural gas when we have other options like thermal coal that can serve the same purpose. I think those natural gas reserves are incredibly valuable and we should be in no hurry to use them up.
How do you see the shift from coal to natural gas in electricity generation playing out in the future?

I think there will be a shift, but it won't be dramatic. The installed base of electricity generation is just too huge to change overnight. Where gas generation is feasible, it will supplant some coal generation, but it's going to be a gradual process. We've already seen some of this shift happen in recent months, but I don't expect it to be a wholesale change anytime soon.
What do you think is more important for someone to learn about investments, and why?

I think it's far more important for people to grasp the basic principles of valuing businesses. You see, investing is all about buying businesses for less than they're worth. If you can do that, you're going to make money. It's not about complex theories like modern portfolio theory or option pricing. I mean, when Ray Kroc started McDonald's, he wasn't thinking about option values, he was thinking about how to sell hamburgers and make great fries.
Why do you think the teaching of investments has become so complicated, with an emphasis on things like option pricing?

I think it's because the 'high priests' in the investment world want to make it seem more complicated than it needs to be. They want to convince people that they need to listen to them, that they have some kind of special knowledge. But the truth is, investing is pretty simple. It's about finding good businesses and buying them at a price that makes sense. All the complicated stuff is just a way to obscure that basic principle.
What is the main idea behind the 'Buffett Rule' that you propose?

The main idea is to ensure that very, very high earners pay a minimum tax rate that's commensurate with what people think they should be paying. I mean, if you're making $30 or $40 million a year, most people believe you should be paying a tax rate of at least 30 percent. The 'Buffett Rule' would restore the tax rate for these high earners to what it used to be back in 1992.
How many of the 400 largest incomes in the United States paid tax rates below 15 percent in the most recent year?

According to the figures, 131 of the 400 largest incomes paid tax rates below 15 percent, which is surprising because that's even lower than the standard payroll tax rate. This is exactly why I think the 'Buffett Rule' is necessary - to make sure these high earners are paying their fair share.
What impact do you expect recent large financial losses from catastrophes to have on reinsurance pricing for catastrophe risk in the near term?

In the near term, I expect the impact on reinsurance pricing for catastrophe risk to be significant. Countries like New Zealand, Australia, Japan, and Thailand have experienced huge losses, and as a result, they've found that their previous rates were inadequate. They're now looking for more capacity, and we're seeing an increase in business written in these areas because they're willing to pay the right rate for the risk they're taking on.
How has the recent trend of increased frequency of major catastrophes affected Berkshire's view on the global reinsurance business?

To be honest, it's hard to separate the random nature of these events from a real trend. We tend to assume the worst, but we don't extrapolate short-term data into long-term predictions. Instead, we've been writing more business in affected areas like Asia, because they need more capacity and are willing to pay the right rate. We're cautious, but we see opportunities in providing reinsurance for catastrophe risk, as long as the price is right.
If you were to start your investment career over, what would you do differently?

I'd try to do things a little earlier and better, especially when I was running my partnership. I'd focus on aggregating money faster and developing a solid, audited record of performance as soon as possible.
Do you think the current generation has the same number of opportunities as yours did?

I think the current generation has all kinds of opportunities. I don't see why they wouldn't - the principles of investing and building wealth remain the same, and it's up to each individual to seize those opportunities.
What is your approach to buying businesses, and how does it differ from private equity?

My approach is to buy businesses with the intention of keeping them long-term, not just to sell them. I want the businesses that join Berkshire to be with us for keeps. This approach is different from private equity, which often buys businesses with the goal of selling them later.
How did you initially build your capital to invest in businesses?
I built my capital by managing money for myself and other people. I did this to accumulate enough capital to buy businesses of significance and interest to me, which has been my goal all along.
What has been your experience with ISCAR since purchasing it six years ago?
ISCAR has been wonderful since we bought it. They just don't stop, and they do everything well. I have to say, I wouldn't want to compete with them - they're that good.
What do you attribute your mistakes in purchasing businesses to?

My mistakes have been made in the purchasing process, specifically when I misgauged the competitive position of the business. It's not because of the faults of management, but rather because I made an incorrect assessment of the business's future competitive position.
Do you think Berkshire will engage in significant derivative activities in the future?

I think it's very unlikely we'll do anything huge in derivatives. While I wouldn't restrict our managers from exploring opportunities, especially when derivatives get mispriced, it's just not going to be a major factor for Berkshire.
How do you expect Berkshire's derivative positions to perform, and what kind of returns are you anticipating?

I like the positions we have, and so far, the ones that have expired have done fine. Charlie and I think we'll do really well with them. In fact, Charlie estimates that by the time all is said and done, we'll have made at least $10 billion, possibly a lot more, from these contracts.
Why do you think people get so emotional when discussing gold?

I find it fascinating, but it's clear that gold arouses passions in people. I think it's because they've invested so much emotionally, not just financially, in the idea of gold as a valuable asset. It's like they're defending a family member or a deeply held belief, rather than just discussing an investment.
What's your take on the comparison between investing in gold and investing in productive businesses?

Well, I think it's pretty straightforward. As I said, it's very hard for an unproductive investment to beat productive investments over the long haul. Gold just sits there, whereas a productive business can grow and generate real value over time. My partner Charlie Munger put it well - working with businesses and people engaged in business is just a more rewarding and sensible way to invest your time and money.
How do you decide to make a personal investment versus one in your role as a fiduciary for Berkshire shareholders?

I decide based on what Berkshire is already investing in. If Berkshire is buying a stock, like Wells Fargo, I won't buy it personally because I've already got my best ideas invested through Berkshire. So, I look at my second choices or smaller companies that Berkshire isn't investing in.
Do you prioritize diversification in your personal investments?

No, I don't prioritize diversification in my personal investments. In fact, I tend to follow Charlie Munger's approach, who says his family is only invested in two or three things. My best ideas are all invested in Berkshire, and for personal investments, I look at what's left that I like, even if they're not my top choices.
Why do you prefer using cash for purchases instead of Berkshire shares?

I prefer using cash because we generate a lot of it, and to be honest, we hate giving out shares. It's like trading away a part of our exceptional businesses like See's Candies or GEICO. We don't want to leave our shareholders with a lower percentage interest in these great companies just to fulfill our acquisition ambitions.
Do you have a preference for the price at which Berkshire shares are traded, and if so, why?

Yes, I do have a preference. As I'm giving away all of my stock over time, I'd rather it be at a higher price than a lower one, simply because it will do more good philanthropically. I'm not looking to sell cheap; I want the stock to reflect its fair value, so we can make the most of our charitable efforts.
What was your initial thought about people using the internet to look for quotes, and how did that change?

I originally thought that only young people would look for quotes on the internet. To be honest, I didn't think I'd be one of them - I'm old enough that I remember using a rotary dial phone! But it's clear that the internet has become the go-to place for all sorts of information, including quotes.
Do you think Amazon's success will have a negative impact on certain businesses?

Yes, I think Amazon's success could definitely hurt some businesses, especially retailers. My partner Charlie Munger thinks it'll be 'really terrible' for most retailers, and I tend to agree. When you have a business with millions of happy customers, like Amazon, it can introduce them to new products and services, making it tough for other companies to compete.
What gives Berkshire a significant competitive edge in acquiring large private businesses?

It's the fact that many owners of large private businesses think of Berkshire first when considering where to lodge their business after they're done with it. If they think of us first, they don't think of anybody second, so we get the call. This allows us to acquire businesses without having to bid at auction, which isn't usually our strong suit.
Do you think you could replicate Berkshire's success if you were to start over from scratch at a younger age?

Well, I'd like to try, but I think it would be a hell of a challenge. As Charlie mentioned, even if I went back to being 30 years old with some capital, I'm not sure I could do it again. But I'd certainly be willing to give it a shot!
Do you think Berkshire will be taken over in the future?

I really don't think so. The size of our company and the concentration of voting power, which will likely remain around 20% in the hands of my estate or family, make it extraordinarily unlikely. Plus, the longer we go, the larger we'll get, which only adds to the stability.
What makes you confident about the future of Berkshire under your successor?

I'm confident because my successor will be totally imbued with the Berkshire culture, which is reflected throughout the company, including the board of directors. This culture is what sets us apart, and I believe it will continue to guide the company's decisions and actions.
What kind of investments or opportunities do you tend to avoid?

I avoid industries where I have no idea who the winners will be, even if they have a wonderful future. I also tend to avoid things with big commissions - if someone's paying a high commission to sell me something, the chances of it being a good deal are low.
How do you approach evaluating potential investment opportunities?

Charlie and I have a number of filters that things have to get through quickly before we're willing to think about them. We try to avoid big mistakes and focus on doing a few things well, rather than trying to do a lot of things. We also look at what other smart people are buying as a way to sort through opportunities.
How much will you spend this year to improve and expand the railroad system?

We'll spend $3.9 billion this year, and it will go towards improving our present system and some expansion. It's a significant investment, but I believe it's necessary to keep our railroad industry efficient and competitive.
Why do you think the railroad industry is a good way to move heavy stuff over long distances?

I think trains are a fundamentally good way to move heavy stuff a long distance. It's hard to conceive of anything better, except maybe barge traffic, but that's limited to areas with navigable rivers. Compared to air, pipeline, or vehicles, trains are pretty darn good.
What kind of structural disadvantage does Berkshire face when bidding for certain assets, such as forests?

Well, we're at a disadvantage because many of these assets are held in pass-through organizations like flow-through partnerships or REITs, which don't pay normal corporate income taxes. This means they have a lower tax burden than we do, giving them an edge when it comes to bidding for these assets.
Can you give an example of the type of companies that have eliminated federal income tax through their structure?

Yeah, companies like Plum Creek Timber are a good example. They've set themselves up in a way that allows them to avoid paying federal income tax, which is a significant advantage when it comes to investments like forests. It's a bit like having a lower cost of entry, and that makes it tough for us to compete.
What lesson did you learn from the 1901 Northern Pacific Corner event?

I learned that life in financial markets has no relation to statistical models like sigmas. That event, where a stock went from $170 to $1000 in one day, causing margin calls and chaos, taught me that understanding history and being prepared for the unexpected is crucial. I'd rather not end up like the brewer who committed suicide by diving into a vat of hot beer due to a margin call!
What's your view on the use of statistical models like the Gaussian curve in finance?

I think they can create false confidence. Charlie and I have always been skeptical of these models, and we've seen how they can fail to account for extreme events. They've tried to adapt by talking about 'fat tails,' but even that's not enough. The truth is, they still don't know how to accurately predict these rare but significant events.
Will the expiration of the Swiss Re contract affect Berkshire's strategy for writing new business?

No, it won't. The expiration of that contract is what I call a 'nonevent' in terms of our future strategy. We've got the capacity to write billions of dollars in business, and we'll keep doing what we do best - looking for good opportunities to write smart business, regardless of whether that contract is in place or not.
Are you looking to replace the premium volume from the Swiss Re contract with another transaction?

We're always on the lookout for more good business, but the expiration of the Swiss Re contract doesn't change our approach. We'd love to write more business if it's the right opportunity, but we're not going to force it just to replace the volume from that contract. We'll stick to our discipline and only write business that makes sense for us.
How do you approach decision-making when it comes to new business opportunities?

I regard every decision as independent. Just because we've got money coming in or a new opportunity arises, it doesn't mean we're going to rush into something we wouldn't have considered the day before. We look for terrific opportunities, and if we find one, we'll pursue it, regardless of what else is happening.
What metrics do you use to measure the success of your insurance operation?

We don't measure ourselves by size. Instead, we focus on the growth in value over time. If a particular business line doesn't make sense, we're not afraid to let it shrink. We're cheerful about losing volume if it means we're making smart, value-driven decisions.
How do Todd and Ted's investment responsibilities differ from yours, and what's the scope of the stocks they can consider?

They operate in different stocks, and they've got a much bigger universe to consider because they're working with $2.75 billion, compared to the $150 billion I oversee. This allows them to look at a lot more potential investments.
How is Todd's performance compensation structured, and what are the potential consequences if he underperforms?

Todd's performance compensation is structured so that he receives a third of his gain in the first year, but the next two years are deferred. If he underperforms, he could lose that deferred compensation. I think this system works well and motivates him to make smart investment decisions.
When evaluating investment opportunities, what factors do you consider to gauge a company's environmental responsibility and potential as a good investment?

Well, we try to look at every aspect of the company and its industry to understand how the world will develop for them in the future. It's like trying to predict the weather - sometimes we're very confident, like with a company like Coca-Cola, and sometimes we're not so sure, like with a retail business.
Do you use specific financial statements or publicly available data to assess a company's environmental responsibility?

The text doesn't specify particular financial statements or data we use, but I can tell you that we consider all available information to get a sense of a company's future prospects, including its environmental responsibility.
How does rail transportation compare to trucking in terms of resource usage and environmental impact?

Well, it's quite simple really. Rail transportation requires less of the world's resources to move goods. When you've got a train a mile long with 120 cars and only a couple of people involved, that's a lot more efficient than using trucks, which need many more people and a lot more fuel to deliver the same amount of tonnage.
What factors do you consider when evaluating the dynamics of a specific industry and company?

We don't rely on any particular magazine or book. We just look at the dynamics of the specific industry and company. For instance, in the case of rail transportation, I was able to figure out that using less fuel per ton of freight means fewer undesired particles in the air. It's about understanding the basics of how things work and making informed decisions based on that.
You mentioned paying out a dividend of 10 cents a share back in the 1960s was a big mistake. Why was that?

Well, it's simple - if we had paid out dividends at any point in our history, including that 10 cents a share, our shareholders would be worth less money today than they are because we reinvested the funds instead. It was a mistake because I think leaving the money in the company to grow has been the better choice.
You and Charlie Munger discussed the potential for significant investments, possibly up to $100 billion, in the future. What kind of opportunities are you seeing?

Charlie mentioned that MidAmerica may have some very unusual opportunities in the next ten or fifteen years to employ a large amount of capital at a reasonable return. That's what we're looking at, and it's why we're not too excited about paying dividends right now - we think we can put our money to better use.
If you had $1 million to invest now, do you think you could achieve better returns than you could have in the past with the same amount of money?

I believe we've learned a thing or two since then, and yes, I think we could do even better with $1 million now than we could have back in the day. Experience and learning do count for something, after all.
Is it possible to replicate your past spectacular performance with your current resources?

No, I don't think that's possible. As Charlie said, we can't do now what we did back then with our current resources. Some things are just not scalable, and our current size and scope limit our ability to achieve the same returns we saw in the past.
Do you think it's possible to do well financially with a small amount of money and a lot of time?

I do think that's possible. As Charlie and I were discussing, if you have endless time and only a small amount of money, you could find ways to do pretty well. It's all about being resourceful and taking advantage of the opportunities that come your way.
How important is continuous learning in achieving success, according to Charlie Munger?

According to Charlie, continuous learning has been crucial to Berkshire's success. He said that if I hadn't kept learning and learning, our record would have been terrible. I think that's a pretty strong endorsement of the importance of staying curious and adaptable over time.
What makes a business less vulnerable to new competition, according to your experience?

Well, I've found that if you're buying something at a huge discount from replacement cost and it's an essential activity, you've certainly got a barrier to new competition. It's like having a railroad - nobody's going to build another one, so you've got a natural barrier there.
Can you give an example from your past experiences where having a competitor significantly impacted your business?

Yes, I can. When I had a gas station out at 30th and Redick in Omaha, there was a Phillips station right next to it. Whatever price they charged for gas, I had to match it. It was tough to compete like that, and I learned that you don't want to be in a business where you're at the mercy of your competitor's pricing.
Do mutual insurance companies tend to have compensation abuse issues like some corporate companies?
No, most mutual insurance companies don't have that kind of compensation abuse. In fact, companies like State Farm are good examples of ones that don't have those issues.
Do you think the tax code currently favors the rich, and if so, why?

Yes, I think the tax code has moved away from the rich bearing their fair share of the cost of government as they've gotten further away from the middle class in terms of earnings. The rich like it that way, and it's one of those underlying trends that can push a democracy towards a plutocracy if we're not careful.

Why do you think Berkshire's book value per share growth has been less than 12% on average for 9 of the last 11 5-year periods, despite your statement that the S&P 500 earns considerably more than 12% on net worth?

Well, I think it's because the last ten years haven't been the best for business, generally. But I still believe that 12% is a reasonable target for us, even if we haven't hit it in the past. And it's worth noting that we're likely to do better in down years than in up years, so our performance is a bit countercyclical.
Will Berkshire's performance be disappointing if it fails to match the S&P 500's performance, including dividends, over the current 5-year period?

It won't be a happy day, but it won't totally discourage us either. We've had periods where the market has gone up every year, and that's just not our sweet spot. We tend to shine in down years, like 2008, so we'll keep doing what we're doing and hope that our intrinsic value keeps growing, even if our book value doesn't always keep pace with the market.

You mentioned that gaining a million policyholders at GEICO adds a billion-and-a-half to intrinsic value but doesn't add to book value. Can you explain why there's such a significant gap between intrinsic value and book value?

Well, book value is like looking at a snapshot of our current financial situation, but it doesn't capture the future potential of our businesses. In the case of GEICO, adding a million policyholders means we'll have more premiums coming in, which will lead to higher earnings over time. That's what increases intrinsic value. But book value only reflects the assets we have on our balance sheet today, not the future cash flows those assets will generate.

You also mentioned that when you buy a company, like ISCAR, you immediately mark down its value on your books. How does this markdown affect your view of the purchase, and do you think it's an accurate reflection of the company's true value?

The markdown is just an accounting rule - it doesn't change our opinion of the company's value one bit. When we buy a company like ISCAR, we're buying its future earnings potential, not just its assets. The markdown is just a way of reflecting the difference between what we paid for the company and its book value. It's a bit like buying a house - just because you pay $500,000 for it doesn't mean that's its book value. But we think ISCAR is a great business, and we're confident it will generate strong returns for us over time.
What specific competitive advantages does ISCAR have over its primary competitor, Sandvik?

Well, I think ISCAR's advantage is quite simple - it's brains and an incredible passion for the business. That's what sets them apart from Sandvik, a company that's certainly very good in its own right.
What kind of challenges did Stef Wertheimer face when he started ISCAR in 1951?

Stef Wertheimer faced some significant challenges when he started ISCAR. He was just 25 years old at the time, and he was competing against well-entrenched, well-financed companies like Sandvik and Kennametal. Plus, he had to import raw materials from China and sell to customers all over the world, which isn't exactly a locational advantage when you're based in Israel. But despite those challenges, he built a remarkable business.
