Do you think the SEC's new rule allowing companies to make material announcements over social media will negatively impact Business Wire?

I think it's a mistake, but I don't think it will necessarily hurt Business Wire. You see, the key to disclosure is accuracy and simultaneity, and Business Wire does a magnificent job of that. It's not about just throwing information out there, it's about making sure everyone gets it at the same time and that it's accurate.
Why do you prefer Business Wire over other methods of disclosure, like company webpages or social media?

Well, I like Business Wire because it ensures that I get accurate information at exactly the same time as everyone else. I don't want to have to constantly check a company's webpage or Twitter account, worrying that I might be 10 seconds behind someone else if there's an important announcement. Business Wire takes care of that for me.
Do you think it would be significant if the United States were to lose its status as the reserve currency of the world?
I don't think it would be all that significant. It's in the nature of things that sooner or later every great leader is no longer the leader. It's just the way the world works.
What are your thoughts on the likelihood of the U.S. dollar remaining the reserve currency 20 years from now?

Well, Charlie thinks it'll still be the reserve currency of the world 20 years from now, and I tend to agree. However, as Charlie also said, that doesn't mean it's forever. Nothing lasts forever, after all.
What do you think are the long-run risks of the Fed's current economic stimulus process, and how might they stop it without negative implications?

I'll be honest, I don't have a clear answer. Charlie Munger said it yesterday, and I agree - it's really uncharted territory. The Fed's balance sheet is huge, around 3.4 trillion, and they've created a lot of liquidity that's just sitting there. It's a lot easier to buy things than to sell them, and I think the Fed will face challenges when they try to reverse this process. I have faith in Bernanke, but it's a complex situation with potential inflationary risks.
How do banks currently view the large amounts of liquidity created by the Fed's stimulus, and what are they trying to do with it?

Banks like Wells Fargo are not happy with having large amounts of money, $175 billion in their case, just sitting at the Fed earning almost nothing. They want to make loans and get this money out into the market, but they're cautious and want to make sure they can get it back. It's a bit of a challenge for them, but they're looking for ways to use this liquidity productively.
Why do you prefer building a commercial operation from scratch rather than buying an existing one?

I prefer building from scratch because it allows us to create an operation at book value, without inheriting any bad habits from other companies. It's like building a new house - you get to design it exactly how you want, without having to deal with someone else's renovation mistakes.
How confident are you about the prospects of your commercial insurance operation?

I'm very confident. With the right people, like Ajit, who's a terrific manager, and the right mindset, I predict we'll have a good and significant commercial insurance operation up and running in a relatively short time. We've got the right ingredients, and I'm excited to see it all come together.
What do you think will happen to Berkshire's reputation after you're no longer around?

I think Berkshire's reputation will become even more solidified. We've established ourselves as a go-to provider of capital for sound deals, especially during times when others are hesitant. And as Charlie pointed out, our ability to act quickly and provide a good home for big companies without suffocating them with bureaucracy will continue to set us apart.
What gives Berkshire an edge in providing capital for large companies like Bank of America or Goldman Sachs?

It's simple: we have the money and the willingness to act immediately. Others may not have the financial resources or the flexibility to move quickly, which gives us an advantage. And as we grow, I think our unique position in the market will only become more pronounced, making us an even more attractive partner for companies looking for a reliable and hands-off investor.
What were the concerns of the business owner who considered selling his company to you?

He was worried about what would happen to the people who had helped him build the business over 30 years if he sold it to a competitor or a private equity firm. He didn't want them to lose their jobs or for the company culture to be destroyed.
What made Berkshire an attractive option for this business owner?

I was the only option left that wasn't a competitor or a private equity firm. He knew that with Berkshire, he'd get a permanent home for his company, and the people who had worked with him would continue to have opportunities. He could still do what he loved, and he wouldn't have to worry about what would happen if something happened to him.
What was the interest rate on the Harley-Davidson notes that you invested in back in 2009?
The interest rate on those notes was 15 percent. It was a great deal for us, and I wish we could've locked it in for longer than five years.
Will you be looking to make similar investments in the future when opportunities arise?

You can bet on it. We're always on the lookout for good deals, and when the market gets crazy like it did back in 2009, we're willing to act. The world has a way of getting back to excesses, and when it does, we'll be ready to pounce on opportunities like we did with Harley-Davidson.
Do you restrict the investment decisions of Todd and Ted, such as how much to diversify their portfolios?

No, I don't tell them how much to diversify. They have the freedom to make their own decisions, whether that's putting all their money into one stock or spreading it across 50 stocks. I believe in giving them the autonomy to manage the money as they see fit, just like I wanted when I was managing money.
What kind of trust and responsibility do you place in the people you hire to manage money, like Todd and Ted?

We place a tremendous amount of trust in them. It's not something Charlie and I take lightly. We believe they deserve that trust, and we've seen them in action long enough to be confident in their abilities. I can tell you, it takes a special kind of person to be given that kind of responsibility, and we think Todd and Ted are those kinds of people.
Do you use a specific method for prioritizing your desires, such as writing down 25 things you want to achieve and choosing the top 5?
No, I don't use that method. In fact, I've never made lists like that in my life. I think it sounds like a good way to operate, but it's just not something I've ever done.
What do you and Charlie Munger like to do in your free time?
Charlie likes to design buildings, and I like to read a lot. We both enjoy doing what we want, and fortunately, we have the option to do so.
How much in pretax earnings do you expect from the newspapers you've bought?

We're probably getting close to about $100 million in pretax earnings from the newspapers. And I might add, we get a favorable tax treatment on a fair amount of that because they were bought from S corporations.
Why did you decide to invest in newspapers despite expecting their earnings to decline?

Well, we bought the papers at very low prices compared to their current earnings, which is important because we do expect those earnings to go down over time. It's a decent return on capital employed, and to be honest, we like newspapers. Plus, it doesn't require any extra effort from me, Charlie, or our headquarters team.

You've expressed admiration for Teledyne CEO Henry Singleton's management style. What did you learn from him, and how do you think his approach could be applied to Berkshire's management after your departure?

Well, I think Henry Singleton is a manager that all investors, CEOs, and MBA students should study. He was 100 percent rational, which is a rare trait in CEOs. As for applying his approach to Berkshire, I don't anticipate any significant changes in management style after I'm gone. Berkshire seems like an easy company to manage, and I think our current approach will continue to work well.
You mentioned that breaking Berkshire into separately-traded companies along business lines would produce a poorer result. Can you elaborate on why you believe this?

Yes, I'm convinced that breaking Berkshire into separate companies would not be the best approach. I think it would lead to poorer results, both now and in the future. I didn't elaborate on the specifics, but I'm confident that our current structure is the best way to manage our diverse range of businesses.
What do you believe is the number one problem for American business?
I think the number one problem for American business is the health care cost disadvantage. It's a huge competitive disadvantage that we face compared to other countries.
How do you think the $1500 per car health care cost disadvantage affects General Motors compared to a similar disadvantage in steel costs?

Well, if General Motors had a $1500 per car disadvantage in steel costs, management would be all over it. But because the health care costs are sort of beyond their control, it's a tougher problem to tackle. Still, it's a big deal - if they had even a $15 difference in steel costs, they'd be focused on it, so you can imagine how much attention a $1500 difference in health care costs deserves.
What were your and Charlie Munger's early career beginnings?

Charlie and I both started out in the same grocery store, believe it or not. Neither of us ended up in the grocery business, though. Guess you could say we didn't exactly see a future for ourselves there!
Did you find your career path interesting from an early age?

I was lucky to have found something I enjoyed doing very early in life. My dad was in a business that didn't particularly interest him, but it really sparked my interest. I'd go down to his office on Saturdays and read all the books I could find, and it just took off from there.
What's the problem with having a competitor who is willing to sell a product below cost, and how does this relate to your experience?

Well, having a competitor who sells below cost is a real headache. I mean, think of it like running a service station across from someone who's willing to lose money on every gallon of gas they sell. It's a tough spot to be in. That's why I got out of the gas station business, to be honest. But in insurance, we've been able to weather similar storms because our standby costs aren't enormous, like they would be with something like idling steel plants.
How did Berkshire's insurance operation become so successful, and what role did luck play in this process?

Our insurance operation's success is a combination of sticking to our principles and getting incredibly lucky with the people we've brought on board. I mean, we've got talents like Tad Montross, Ajit Jain, Don Wurster, and Tony Nicely, and they've thrived in Berkshire's environment because we don't pressure them to make foolish decisions. It wasn't something we anticipated from the start, but it evolved over time, and we're grateful for how it's turned out.
What is the current status of your wager with the hedge funds, and how will the results be used?
We're at the halfway point, and I'll continue to report on our progress every year. If Berkshire does well, we'll have over a million dollars to distribute to one of two charities.
Can you tell us more about the website longbets.org and the types of propositions people have wagered on?

Longbets.org is a website that holds the money for these wagers, and it's got some interesting propositions. For example, there's a $1,000 bet that a large collider will destroy the Earth in 10 years, and another $2,000 bet that at least one human alive in 2000 will still be alive in 2150. You can check out the website to see more of these unique bets.
How did your understanding of American Express change over time, particularly in relation to your two purchases of the company's stock?

Well, I'll tell you, the first time I bought American Express, I didn't know much about it, so I had to dig in deeply. But the second time, after talking to Frank Olson and seeing how integral American Express was to his business at Hertz, it was a much easier decision. It's all cumulative, as Charlie says - what I learned the first time around made the second purchase much more straightforward.
What benefits do you see in companies like American Express repurchasing their own shares, and how does this impact your investment?

I love it when companies like American Express, Coca-Cola, or Wells Fargo repurchase their shares. It's a double play for us - not only do they likely earn more money, but our interest in the company also goes up every year because there are fewer shares outstanding. And the best part is, they're doing it for us, so we don't even need to buy more stock ourselves.
You mentioned that George W. Bush issued the ten greatest words of economic thought in history. What were those words?
Unfortunately, I didn't specify the exact words in this conversation, but I wish I had - it would have been a great addition to our discussion!
Do you believe the amount of deficit spending in the last four years was appropriate given the circumstances?
Yes, I do. I think the fiscal stimulus provided was quite appropriate in relation to the threat to the economy posed by the greatest panic in my lifetime. We needed it to prevent a worse outcome.
What's the main problem you think amateur investors face when it comes to buying stocks?

I think the main problem amateur investors face is getting excited about stocks at the wrong time. They tend to buy when everyone else is excited, which isn't a great strategy. The key is to avoid buying at the wrong time and to avoid getting caught up in the hype around certain industries or stocks.
What advice would you give to amateur investors who don't have the time or expertise to be professional investors?

My advice would be to buy into American business in a broadly diversified way, through an index fund for example, and to put your money in over time. This way, you can still benefit from the growth of the stock market without having to be an expert. It's a simple, logical, and profitable approach that can serve you well.
Do you think a 1 percent annual supply of Berkshire stock would significantly impact the stock's trading level?

No, I don't think it would. The volume of Berkshire stock traded daily is so large, around $500 million, that an additional $2 billion over a year is just a drop in the bucket. It's insignificant compared to the overall volume.
Have you ever felt that giving away your wealth has impacted your life?
Not at all. I've never given away a penny that changed my life in any way. In fact, I believe my wealth has more utility in the hands of others than it does just sitting in my safe deposit box.
Do you see any signs of significant economic lift in the U.S. right now?

I'd say it's a slow progress, not a roaring comeback. We've seen a gradual improvement since the fall of 2009, but it's been a steady, slow pace. I wouldn't be surprised if it keeps going this way, with no dramatic ups or downs.
Are you looking to expand Berkshire's business operations internationally, outside of the U.S.?

We're open to opportunities anywhere, but we find most of our opportunities in the United States. It's a huge market, and we're better known here. That being said, we do look for bolt-on acquisitions outside the U.S., and if we find a good deal with good management, we're willing to go for it.
What is your current outlook on the housing market, specifically regarding housing starts and household formation?

I think we're seeing a balance between housing starts and household formation, which is what we want to avoid overbuilding. It's not going to be a surge, but we'll move forward, and I don't think we'll stall either.
How do you approach investment opportunities, especially when it comes to making large investments?

We keep playing the game, and if we hear about something we like, we'll move in an instant. We need to have the ability and the mental fortitude to act when opportunities arise, even if it means going against the crowd.
What kind of work environment do you try to create for your managers?

I try to create an atmosphere where our managers can enjoy running their businesses without a lot of hassle. We want them to be able to focus on their work, not spend all their time reporting back to headquarters or doing what I call 'show-and-tell' operations. It's about giving them the freedom to do their job and have a good time doing it.
How do you think Ajit's early involvement would have impacted Berkshire's success?

Well, it's fun to think about, but if Ajit had joined us in 1965 instead of 1985, I think we would have achieved even more incredible things. I jokingly said we'd probably own the world by now, but in all seriousness, Ajit's contributions have been immense, and having him on board earlier would have likely accelerated our growth and success.
What do you think is a better investment, owning businesses or fixed-dollar investments, and why?

I've always felt that owning businesses makes more sense than fixed-dollar investments, probably about 90% of the time. It's because businesses have the potential to grow and increase in value over time, whereas fixed-dollar investments, like bonds, typically don't keep pace with inflation. For example, earning a quarter of a percent on a million dollars is only $2,500 a year, which isn't what people expected when they were saving all those years.
How do you think low interest rates have affected ordinary people, particularly savers?

Low interest rates have hit millions of people, especially savers, in a very harsh way. I get a lot of letters from people who have saved, say, $300,000, and they're wondering what to do with it because the returns are so low. It's a real dilemma for them, and it's not something you hear much about, but it's a big problem. As Charlie said, the savers were convenient to hurt in this situation.
How does your investment strategy change when managing smaller amounts of money, such as $1 million, compared to managing billions?

Well, managing a million dollars is a different game than running a huge fund. If I were running a million dollars now, I'd be looking at small things, small discrepancies in certain situations. It's a more focused approach, looking for tiny advantages that can add up.
Would you focus on specific industries or types of stocks, such as small cap or large cap, when investing with smaller amounts of money?

When investing with smaller amounts, like $1 million, I'd probably look at very small things, not necessarily specific industries, but situations where there are small discrepancies that can be exploited. The key is finding those small opportunities that can generate significant returns.
How has social media impacted GEICO's marketing strategy?

Well, social media has made a difference in GEICO's marketing, just like the internet did before it. We've had to adapt to the changing times, from mail to TV ads to phone numbers, and now to social media. It's been a big change, but we're listening to our customers and adjusting our approach accordingly.
Did you expect the internet to affect GEICO's younger customers' buying habits as quickly as it did?

To be honest, I was a bit surprised at how fast the internet impacted the buying habits of younger people, especially when it came to GEICO. But I've learned to expect the unexpected when it comes to technological changes - the world is changing fast, and we've got to keep up!
At what age do you think children should be involved in discussions about their parents' will?

I think they should be participants in the will by the time they're in their mid-30s or thereabouts. I don't advise doing this with your 14-year-old, but once they're older and more mature, it's a good idea to involve them in these discussions.
Do you believe in treating all children equally in a will, even if they have different interests or needs?

Well, I think equality is important, but it's not always straightforward. There may be circumstances where one child has more interest in a particular asset, and you want to make sure your definition of equality is understood by all the children. It's not just about giving everyone the same thing, but about making sure everyone feels treated fairly.
How does the performance of the insurance business impact Berkshire's financials, even if it just breaks even?

Well, if our insurance business breaks even, that $77 billion - which is technically a liability on our balance sheet - essentially becomes cost-free money for us to invest. It's a remarkable situation, really. Having that kind of capital to work with, without any associated costs, is about as good as having additional net worth. It gives us tremendous flexibility and opportunities to generate returns over the long term.
Why do you advise shareholders to ignore quarterly or annual realized gains or losses in securities?

We manage our investments for the long haul, not to produce earnings in any given quarter. I mean, think of it like trying to time a good harvest - you can't just decide when to pick the crops to make your quarterly numbers look good. We make our investment decisions based on what we think will do well over time, and we let the short-term results take care of themselves. Focusing too much on short-term gains or losses can be misleading, so we tell our shareholders to take a step back and look at the bigger picture.
Do you think a blending of Berkshire's system with another company's would work well?
No, I don't think a blending of the two would work very well. We've got a system that works very well for us, and it's unique to Berkshire.
How do you feel about overstaffing at Berkshire's subsidiaries?
We don't enforce a strong discipline on every subsidiary as to whether they have a few too many people or not. We encourage a lean basis by example, but we don't dictate it through edicts.
Do you think corporate taxes are holding back American businesses?
No, I don't think corporate taxes are holding back businesses. In fact, I think American business is doing extraordinarily well, and if you look at corporate profits, you'll see that's the case.
What's your view on the state of the American economy under the current president?

I think American business is doing well, but many American people are not. I disagree with the notion that the president's policies are a 'wet blanket' to the economy. I believe efforts like Obamacare are aimed at helping those who need it, but I expect we'll have differing opinions on politics.
How does Berkshire's performance compare to the market in different types of years?

Well, I've said it before - we tend to underperform in very strong up years, match the market in moderate up years, and do better than average in flat or down years. It's not a hard and fast rule, but that's the general trend.
What was the increase in Berkshire's net worth over the last couple of years, according to Charlie Munger?

Charlie mentioned that our net worth, after full corporate taxes, went up by something like $60 billion over the last couple of years. And on a pre-tax basis, it was probably around $90 billion. Not bad, if I do say so myself!
Would you consider an IPO of Berkshire's individual operating units to narrow the discount between the current share price and intrinsic value?
The answer is no. I don't think that's something we'd ever consider.
At what price are you eager to buy back Berkshire shares, relative to the company's book value?

We're eager to buy back shares at 120% of book value. With our book value being close to $230 billion now, that means we think buying at around $45 billion over that figure is a bargain in relation to intrinsic value.
What kind of businesses or sellers are most attracted to Berkshire's unique approach?

Well, it's the sellers who have built up their companies over 20, 30, or 40 years and are looking for a good home for their business. They're often very rich and have accomplished a lot, but they care deeply about where their business ends up and want to make sure it's in good hands. They don't want to see their life's work torn apart by someone who just wants to make a quick buck.
How do you think Berkshire's approach will continue to work in the future?

I think it'll continue to work well because we're comfortable with it, and the sellers who care about their businesses are comfortable with it too. As long as we behave properly and keep our promise to the managers, I believe we'll maintain this unique asset and be hard to compete with. It's not a solution to all problems, but it's the way we want to operate, and it's worked pretty well for us so far.
You and Charlie Munger have been partners for a long time. Have you two ever argued?

Charlie and I have never had an argument, despite disagreeing on a lot of things over the years. We've been working together for 55 years now, and I think that's a testament to our strong partnership.
What can you tell us about how you and Charlie manage your partnership?

Well, I think the key is that we've learned to disagree without being disagreeable. We've had our differences, but we've never let them escalate into arguments. I think that's the most important lesson we've learned over the years.
How do you currently manage cash flow between Berkshire's parent company and its subsidiaries?

I don't micromanage the cash flow on a day-by-day or week-by-week basis. We give our subsidiaries a lot of autonomy, and we don't try to pull all the cash into the parent company all the time. If we need it, we know where it is and can get it, but otherwise, we let our managers run their businesses without a lot of interference from us.
Do you envision changing your cash management procedures in the future, such as using a sweep account?

Yeah, we could change our procedure someday. A sweep account might make sense at some point, but for now, we're not big on disciplining our subsidiaries on a daily basis. We like to give them the freedom to operate, and it seems to work out just fine.
What gets you and Charlie most excited in terms of investment opportunities?

It's finding a business that we want to buy, one that fits well with Berkshire and will be earning money for us 10, 20, and 50 years from now. That's what really turns us on, not just finding a stock to buy.
Are you looking to sell any of the stocks you currently hold?
No, we're in no hurry to sell any of those stocks. In fact, if we were to raise capital by selling stocks, it probably wouldn't be the names you'd expect us to sell.
Why are you reluctant to borrow money despite the current low interest rates?

Well, it's not that we don't see the appeal of borrowing at low rates. In fact, if Charlie and I were in the same position 40 years ago, we probably would have jumped at the chance. But, we've got a good thing going with our float, which has generated $77 billion for us. And we're concerned about changing our conservative approach to leverage, because we don't want to jeopardize the credit rating of our bonds.
How do you think your approach to leverage would have differed 40 years ago?

If Charlie and I had the opportunity to borrow at these low rates 40 years ago, we would have likely taken it. We would have seen it as a great way to finance some wonderful businesses and make even more money. But, as I said, things are different now, and we've got to consider the implications of changing our approach to leverage.
You mentioned that Berkshire's utility and railroad could withstand more debt. How do you determine the right amount of debt for these businesses?

Well, we look at what the rating agencies think are conventional ratios, but if I'm being honest, we also use a bit of common sense. I mean, these businesses are like sturdy ships that can handle a lot of cargo - in this case, debt - without sinking. We just try to keep it reasonable so we don't rock the boat, if you will.
You also mentioned that taking on more debt at the parent level could be done at a low cost. Why are you reluctant to do so, given the current low interest rates?

It's not that we're opposed to debt entirely, it's just that we don't see a whole lot of great places to put that money to work right now. We've got $25 billion in excess cash just sitting there, and we're finding other ways to make use of our capital, like through these structured settlements that actually cost us less than borrowing would. So, while I agree that taking on more debt could be a good idea, we're just not seeing the opportunities that would make it worthwhile.
If you were running the Fed, would you have handled interest rates differently than Chairman Ben Bernanke did during the period of low rates?

Honestly, I don't think I would have done much differently. I've been surprised at how well things have worked out so far, and I think Ben Bernanke handled things very well, especially considering he didn't have a unanimous view from the other Fed members.
What's your assessment of Chairman Ben Bernanke's performance during the financial crisis?

I think Ben Bernanke was a hero, both during the crisis and afterwards. He's a very smart man who took the necessary actions, even when not everyone around him agreed. I give him particular credit for that.
Do you think the current zero interest rate policy has created a bubble in asset prices?

No, I don't think it has. As I said, it's had a huge effect on rejuvenating the economy and asset prices, but I don't see this as a bubble situation. That being said, it doesn't mean it can't produce one in the future.
What's your view on holding cash in times of economic uncertainty, like in 2008?

Well, I think people often cling to cash at the wrong times. In 2008, I wrote that cash may have been king if you used it, but if you weren't going to use it, it was the dumbest thing you could own. It's all about using your cash wisely, not just holding onto it for the sake of holding onto it.
What was the nature of the bet you made six years ago?

I made a bet for charity on how a Standard and Poor's 500 index fund would compare in performance to a group of hedge funds. Essentially, I'm pitting a simple index fund against a selection of hedge funds chosen by a firm in New York.
What incentives do the fund of funds managers have to select a strong group of hedge funds?

The fund of funds managers have every economic incentive to come up with a wonderful group of hedge funds because they get paid a fee, naturally, but they also get paid an additional performance fee based on how the hedge funds they select do. It's a pretty strong motivation, if you ask me.
What is your view on GEICO's ability to evaluate risk in the auto insurance industry?
I feel very, very good about GEICO's management and its ability to evaluate risk. In my view, there's nobody better at it, in terms of auto insurance, than the GEICO people.
Do you think the development of self-driving cars will lead to you selling GEICO?
It would not cause us to think for one second about selling GEICO. We think GEICO will be doing more business, a lot more business, in my view, five years from now than now, and ten years from now.
How do you determine your circle of competence?

I think it's a matter of being self-realistic and understanding your own talents and shortcomings. It's about knowing what you're good at and what you're not, and being honest with yourself about it. For instance, I've found that I'm not as competent in retail as I thought, and that's a hard lesson to learn.
Can you give an example of a time when you operated outside of your circle of competence?

Yes, I can think of a few times, actually. One example that comes to mind is when I bought Berkshire Hathaway. Initially, I thought I was just going to resell the stock, but then I decided to take control of the company, which was probably a dumb decision at the time. Luckily, it worked out, but it was definitely outside of my circle of competence.
Would you consider moving Berkshire's technical holding company overseas to save on income tax expense and create shareholder value?
No, I wouldn't consider that. As I've said, America has helped Charlie and me become very rich, and it wouldn't be right to try to get our tax to zero while we remain this prosperous.
Do you think Berkshire could have achieved its success in any country other than the United States?
No, I don't think so. I've said it before - we couldn't have done Berkshire in any other country except the United States. This country has been very good to us, and we're grateful for that.
Do you voluntarily pay more taxes than you're required to?
No, I don't. As I said, we don't add a tip of 20 percent or 15 percent or anything beyond what we're required to pay. We follow the rules and pay what we owe, but we don't pay more than that.
Are all of your business deals driven solely by tax benefits?

Not at all. While it's true that some of our deals, like wind energy and solar, are tax driven and wouldn't make economic sense otherwise, that's not the case for all of our business deals. We do what makes sense financially, and if tax benefits are part of the equation, that's okay, but it's not the only factor we consider.
What was the main reason for entering the commercial insurance business at the time you did?

The main reason we entered the commercial insurance business when we did was because we had the opportunity to work with some terrific people. Having the right team in place was the key factor in our timing.
Do you believe the current business cycle will impact your long-term strategy for this operation?

No, we're not going to let short-term troubles dictate our strategy. This is a long-term play, a 'forever play' as I like to call it. We're in it for the long haul, and we're going to play the game hard with our outstanding team and competitive advantages.
Are you interested in buying a professional sports team?
No, I'm not interested in buying a professional sports team. In fact, if you hear that Charlie or I are buying a sports team, it might be time to start talking about finding our successors.
Have you had any experience with sports equipment manufacturing companies?
Yes, we own Spalding and Russell, and while they've been around a long time, the sports equipment business hasn't generally been very profitable, although there are exceptions like Nike.
Do you think making multiple small deals is an effective way to build earning power for Berkshire?

No, I don't think so. As I said, one $30 billion deal is equivalent to ten $3 billion deals or a hundred $300 million deals. Our main emphasis should be on bigger deals because that's where we can really build a lot more earning power into Berkshire.
Is there still a place for small deals in Berkshire's strategy?

Yes, there is. While I believe our future isn't in making hundreds of small deals, that doesn't mean we can't find an occasional small business that fits in and will do well. It's just not going to be the primary focus of our strategy.
Under what conditions would you consider repurchasing shares aggressively?

I'd be very aggressive about repurchasing shares if the stock can be bought at a price that makes sense for continuing shareholders, meaning their value is enhanced by the repurchase. It's all about making sure the deal is a good one for the people who already own a piece of the company.
What principle guides your decision-making regarding the use of excess cash, including potential share repurchases?

Whatever decision is made, it will be done in the interest of the shareholder. That's the principle every decision starts from. It's simple: we're looking out for the people who have entrusted us with their investments.
You mentioned that gross profit and net profit are not the same thing. Can you explain the difference between the two using an example from the text?

Well, let me use Macy's as an example. Their gross profit margin is 40 percent, which means they sell a sofa for 40 percent more than they pay for it. However, after accounting for expenses like salespeople, rent, and advertising, their pretax margin is only 8.5 percent. That's the difference between gross profit and net profit - gross profit only looks at the cost of the product, while net profit takes into account all the other expenses of running a business.

You also discussed Clayton's lending terms and the fact that some borrowers default on their loans. What do you think are the main causes of default, and how do you respond to criticism of Clayton's lending practices?

The big causes of default are the loss of a job, death, and divorce - things that can happen to anyone, but are more likely to affect people living closer to the edge. As for criticism, I think it's unfair to expect a zero percent foreclosure rate. We're lending to people who might not qualify for credit otherwise, and while that means some will default, it also means many will be able to own a home they otherwise couldn't afford. And our delinquency rates are actually quite low, at around 3 percent.
What happened to the number of people employed in the railroad business after World War II?

Well, let me tell you - the number of people in the railroad business dropped dramatically. We're talking about going from around 1.6 million people to less than 200,000. And you know what? The industry is better off for it. We're carrying more freight, over longer distances, and doing it all much safer than before.
What's your view on the importance of efficiency in capitalism?

I think efficiency is essential in capitalism. As I said, it's required over time. You can't just keep throwing people and resources at a problem without getting more output. I mean, look at the railroad example - if we still had a million-six people working in the industry, we'd have a terrible railroad system. Instead, we've got a much more efficient system that's safer and more productive.
When evaluating a business for potential investment, what factors might cause you to stop considering it and move on?

Well, there are several filters in place, and one key factor is who we're dealing with. If we're not comfortable with the people involved, that can be a deal-breaker. Additionally, we look for businesses where we have a reasonable idea of how they'll perform in five or ten years. If we don't have confidence in their long-term prospects, we're likely to pass.
What's a crucial consideration when buying a business where the current owner will continue to run it after the sale?

That's a great question. When we're buying a business and the seller will remain involved, a big question for us is whether we want to be in partnership with that person. We need to trust that they'll behave and make decisions in our best interests, even after they no longer own the business. If we're not convinced of that, it can stop the deal right there.
Why don't you and your team 'talk up' your investments?

We have no interest in encouraging other people to buy what we own because we're likely to be buying more of that stock in the future. It's simple: if we're going to be a buyer next year and the year after, why would we want the price to go up?
Would you ever consider saying pessimistic things about your biggest holdings?

Actually, if we were to 'talk our book' from our own self-interest, we would say pessimistic things about our biggest holdings because all four of them are repurchasing their shares. The cheaper they can repurchase those shares, the better off we are.
How did you get lucky in the mid '80s regarding your business, and who was involved?

I got lucky when a guy named Ajit Jain came into the office one Saturday and offered to help, despite having no experience in the insurance business. It turned out to be a great stroke of luck, and I feel fortunate to have met him.
Do you think it's possible to replicate the success you had with insurance, such as the trifecta you mentioned, in the future?

I'd say the odds are very much against it. However, the key is to remain open to new ideas and opportunities as they arise. If you keep yourself receptive to good opportunities, some positive things will likely happen, even if it's not in the insurance field.
You mentioned being one-quarter Coca-Cola, what did you mean by that and do you think it's had an impact on your health?

Well, I meant that I've consumed a lot of Coca-Cola over the years, and I think it's had a positive impact on my health, believe it or not. I think being happy with what you're doing, and in this case, eating and drinking what you enjoy, can contribute to a long and healthy life. I joke that if I had been eating broccoli and Brussels sprouts all my life, I might not have lived as long, because I would have been miserable!
You also mentioned that Berkshire Hathaway was once the largest shareholder of General Foods, can you tell us a bit more about that investment and how it relates to your current investments?

Yes, we were the largest shareholder of General Foods from about 1981 to 1984, before it was bought by Philip Morris. It's interesting to note that the brands we owned back then, such as Kraft, have endured for over 30 years, and now we're owning them again through our current investments. It just goes to show that certain brands, like Heinz and Coca-Cola, have real staying power, and people will continue to enjoy them for generations to come.
Did you attend business school?
No, I didn't attend business school. In fact, Charlie Munger mentioned that neither of us had business school training, and he jokingly asked why anyone else should need it either.
What advice would you give to someone trying to network without a top business school alumni network?
Well, I think Charlie summed it up pretty well when he said to 'play the hand you've got.' Essentially, make the most of the opportunities and resources you have available to you.
What was the main idea of the efficient market theory that you were taught in business school?

The efficient market theory essentially told us that it's pointless to try and figure out what a company is worth because the market has already set a perfect price. It's like being told that trying to find a bargain in the stock market is a waste of time, which I found to be quite misleading, especially considering the hefty tuition fees I paid.
How much did you mention paying for business school training that preached this theory?

I joked about paying $30 or $40,000 a year to learn that it's futile to try and determine a company's true worth. It's a bit humorous looking back, considering how much I've benefited from doing just that – evaluating companies and finding value where others may not see it.
Do you think the US dollar will still be the world's reserve currency 50 years from now?
I do, and I'd bet a lot of money on it. The probabilities are very high in my mind, though nothing is certain.
What does Charlie Munger think about the government printing and spreading a lot of money?
Charlie's a bit nervous about it, especially when it's just spread around without a specific purpose like improving infrastructure. He thinks it's more dangerous than many economists believe.
Why have you been cautious in your business decisions, especially when it comes to using leverage?

I've been cautious because I have a responsibility to our investors, many of whom are friends and family, and I wouldn't want to take any risks that could potentially wipe out their net worth. It's just not something I could live with. I'd rather be a hundred times too cautious than 1 percent too incautious.
Do you think being cautious has caused you to miss out on any big opportunities?

Yes, looking back, there probably were times when we could have taken on more leverage and swung for the fences, so to speak. Charlie and I have discussed this, and we both agree that if we had used more leverage, Berkshire would likely be a lot bigger today. However, we've always prioritized caution and peace of mind over potentially bigger returns.
You mentioned being prepared for anything, how does Berkshire's cash reserve contribute to this preparedness?

Well, having over $60 billion in cash gives us the flexibility to act quickly when opportunities arise. I'd rather have less cash and make a smart acquisition, but our cash reserve is like having a loaded gun - it's ready to be used when the right target comes along.
You and Charlie seem skeptical of making macroeconomic predictions. Can you explain why?

We've just seen too many people make bold predictions and then fail to deliver. It's like Charlie said, people start to think they know something just because they're on TV talking about it. The truth is, we don't know what's going to happen, and it's better to just admit that and focus on being prepared for whatever comes next.
How do you try to prevent misbehavior in your company, particularly when it comes to incentives and ego satisfaction?

We try to eliminate incentives that would cause people to misbehave, whether it's for financial rewards or ego satisfaction. It's pretty unusual for a business to consider ego satisfaction, but we've seen enough to know it's an important factor. We want to avoid situations where people feel pressured to fudge figures or hide information just to avoid disappointing someone or to feed their own ego.
Can you give an example of how a CEO's behavior can inadvertently lead to misreporting or other problems in a company?

I recall a case at National Indemnity where the CEO, Jack Ringwalt, would jokingly berate the claims manager about the size of claims. The claims manager, not wanting to be kidded, started hiding claims instead of reporting them. This not only led to misreporting but also affected our relationships with reinsurers. It's a great example of how a CEO's behavior, even if meant as a joke, can send the wrong message and lead to serious problems.
Do you think the financial system is still in danger, and if so, why?

I do think the financial system is still in danger. You see, people like to make money and they like to put favorable labels on what they're doing, like 'sharing risk' and 'helping the economy.' But let's be honest, they're really just running a gambling parlor with a proprietary edge. And I also think our competitors don't like the idea that they deserve regulation while we don't, which adds to the danger.
How do you think the Dodd-Frank act affects the power of the Federal Reserve and the Treasury to respond to financial crises?

In my view, Dodd-Frank actually weakens the power of the Fed and the Treasury to take the kind of actions they took in 2008. You know, back then, they were able to stop a run on money market funds by guaranteeing them, and that was a huge deal. It's like piling up gold in front of a bank to stop a run - it's a powerful symbol that says, 'we've got this under control.' But if you take away that power, you're left with a system that's more prone to panics and chaos.
How has the way GEICO operates changed over time?

Well, let me tell you, it's come a long way from Leo Goodwin and his wife stuffing envelopes back in 1936. We've moved from direct mail to TV, phone, cable TV, the Internet, and now mobile. The key is to save people money and give them good service, and we've adapted our approach to do just that.
What do you think is essential for success in the insurance business?

I believe it's quite simple: saving people money and giving them good service. Whatever method achieves that in the most effective way is going to be the winner, whether it's 20, 30, or 50 years from now. We're focused on staying on top of it and experimenting to find what works best.
How do you think the threats of chemical, nuclear, biological, and cybersecurity attacks affect the outlook for the United States?

I believe these threats are the great threat to the United States. Despite our wonderful economic system and the potential for future growth, these threats can nullify all of that. Madmen, rogue states, or religious fanatics with access to weapons of mass destruction can cause immense harm, and it's not just nuclear threats we need to worry about, but also biological, chemical, and cyber threats.
Do you think the U.S. economic system is resilient enough to withstand these threats and continue to provide a better life for future generations?

Yes, I do. I think our economic system is superior and has worked quite well despite its deficiencies. The American people's energies and brains have been unleashed, leading to incredible productivity and growth. While there may be fits and starts, I believe our children and grandchildren will live better than we do, with a potential 20% gain in GDP per capita over the next generation.
Do you think the United States will continue to do well despite potential threats?

Yes, I do. I believe that even with the threats we face, the United States is positioned to do extraordinarily well. In fact, I've said that I think the luckiest person ever born in history, on a probabilistic basis, is the baby being born in the United States today.
Why do you think collaboration between the United States and China is important?

I think collaboration between the US and China is crucial for our respective safety and the general benefit of the world. As Charlie mentioned, it's very important that we like and trust one another, and work together to avoid bad consequences that come from other people's mistakes and misbehavior.
How much would a hedge fund manager earn in a year if they were managing a billion dollars at a 2-and-20 fee structure?

If a hedge fund manager is managing a billion dollars at 2-and-20, they'd get $20 million a year just for showing up to the office. That's the kind of money that can make coming to work every day feel like a pretty good deal.
Where can someone go to learn more about the long bet you mentioned, and what kind of predictions are being made on that platform?

If you're interested in learning more about the long bet, you can search for 'Long Bets' and find the organization that acts as the stakeholder. They've got hundreds of bets up there, covering all sorts of predictions, and you can even make your own bets that pay off in 25 or 50 years if you disagree with one of the parties.
How do you believe one can acquire a great reputation over time?

Well, I think Charlie said it best - it's acquired very slowly over a long period of time. You just have to get the best reputation you can in the years you're allotted and the time available. It's not something that happens overnight, like Charles Lindbergh's fame, but rather something you build through consistent behavior and actions.
What role do you think reputation plays in building an enduring enterprise like Berkshire?

Reputation is key. As Charlie mentioned, it's one of those peculiar attributes that has contributed to Berkshire's success. By behaving well and consistently doing the right thing, we've been able to build trust with our partners, investors, and the public, which has been essential to our enduring success.
What do you believe is the importance of behaving well as you go through life, especially in relation to opportunities and reputation?

I think behaving well is crucial because it's the credibility you've built in the past that often leads to new opportunities. It's like making a wise investment - it may not always work out as planned, but it's still the right thing to do. And as I've seen, having a good reputation can open doors and create possibilities that might not have been available otherwise.
Can you recall any specific advice or quote that has stuck with you regarding reputation and aging?

Yes, I remember a dinner conversation with Gianni Agnelli of Fiat back in 1988. He told me, 'When you get old, you'll have the reputation you deserve.' He said that for a while, you might be able to fool people, but eventually, your true reputation will shine through. I think that's sage advice, and it's something that has stuck with me over the years.
You mentioned that American business is earning around 15 percent on tangible equity. How does this compare to what people are getting from CDs?

Well, it's a huge difference. People who have their money in CDs are only getting around 1/4 or 1/2 percent, which is a far cry from the 15 percent that equity holders are earning. It just shows that equity holders are getting treated extraordinarily well compared to debt holders in this economy.
You and Charlie Munger discussed California's tax policy. What's your take on it?

I think Charlie summed it up pretty well - California's tax policy is 'really stupid'. The 13 1/2 percent tax on long-term capital gains, which is nondeductible for federal purposes, just drives rich people out of the state. And as Charlie pointed out, rich people aren't a burden, they actually contribute to the economy and provide benefits for others.
What did you learn from Adam Smith's 'The Wealth of Nations' and how did it influence your thinking?

I learned economics from it, and while it didn't shape my investment philosophy, it certainly provided valuable insights. It's a foundational book that, combined with the works of other great economists, offers a lot of wisdom.
Who gave you an original copy of 'The Wealth of Nations', and what's an interesting aside you mentioned in relation to this topic?

My friend Bill Gates gave me an original copy of 'The Wealth of Nations'. On a lighter note, I also mentioned that Fruit of the Loom has 'Berkshire Bomber' underwear and other items available, which is a fun aside unrelated to the book itself.
What differences in corporate culture and performance do you see between German and U.S. companies?

To be honest, I was looking for Charlie to chime in on this one, but I think what he said sums it up well. The traditions and family traditions are different in Europe, including Germany, compared to the United States. Germans have a long tradition of being very good at technology and capitalism, and they've performed exceptionally well, often working fewer hours but producing a lot more.
Have you had success buying companies in Europe, specifically in Germany?

Well, Charlie mentioned that we've had a hard time buying things in Europe, and that's true. But we've always admired the way the Germans have performed, especially on the engineering side. And I'm happy to say that we finally did buy a good German company, which is a testament to our long-standing interest in investing in Germany.
What kind of business contracts has Berkshire been successful in writing, and how many of them have premiums of a billion dollars or more?

We've been successful in writing large reinsurance contracts, and I mentioned in the annual report that we've written all eight contracts with premiums of a billion dollars or more. It's a corner of the world where we have a strong position.
Why doesn't Berkshire engage in promotional finance, despite having the opportunity to attract a lot of money?

It's just not our game. We're not looking to take advantage of people or create a robust narrative just to sell something. We're in it for the long haul, and we don't admire the way promotional finance is being played.
How did you and Charlie Munger become more likable as you got older?

Well, I think we both just got a little smarter about human behavior as we aged. I personally tried to learn from people I admired, figuring out what qualities made them likable and then adopting some of those qualities myself. It's not rocket science, but it does take some self-awareness and a willingness to change.
Does having wealth help in making friends and influencing people?

Unfortunately, yes, it can. As Charlie joked, getting rich and being generous can make people see virtues in you that might not be there otherwise. And I added that people tend to see all kinds of good qualities in you if they think you'll write a check. It's not the most noble reason for people to like you, but it's a reality.
What qualities do you think people should strive to have in order to be well-liked?

I think people should strive to be generous, friendly, and accept things with good humor. You know, just be a decent human being. Don't claim credit for things you don't do, and try to have a positive outlook. These are all qualities that I believe make a person likable, and they're definitely possible to cultivate.
Do you think changing oneself is more effective than trying to change others in personal relationships, such as marriage?

Absolutely. As Charlie mentioned, trying to change yourself instead of your spouse is a much better approach. And let's be honest, it's just a lot easier to work on yourself than to try to fix someone else. Plus, if you can be the kind of person you'd like to be around, that's going to make a big difference in any relationship.
You mention that you had a system where shareholders could designate contributions, but had to give it up. What was the reason for giving up this system?
I hated to give it up, but unfortunately, the reasons are not specified here, and I didn't elaborate on them. Let's just say it was a necessity at the time.
You expressed reservations about corporate philanthropy. Can you elaborate on why you feel this way?

Well, I just think it's not right for CEOs or directors to write checks on behalf of their shareholders without putting their own money where their mouth is. If they're not willing to give personally, why should they decide how their shareholders' money is spent on philanthropy?
Do you think a common currency with Canada would have been feasible for the United States?

I think we could have made it work with Canada. We're similar economies, and I believe we could have figured out a way to share a currency. It might have even been useful, but that's about as far as I think it could have gone - a North American currency, not something hemisphere-wide.
What's your stance on the euro currency, and do you think it can survive in its current form?

I think the euro can and probably should survive, but it's going to take some real changes. In its present form, it's not going to work. I believe if it can figure out a way to operate with more cohesion, it will be a good thing for Europe, but that requires some significant adjustments and possibly some examples to be set.
What do you think is important for children to learn about financial habits?

I think it's crucial for kids to develop good financial habits early on. You know, it's like the old saying goes: the chains of habit are too light to be felt until they're too heavy to be broken. Getting a head start on saving and understanding money concepts can make a huge difference in their lives.
Do you have any advice for someone who wants to teach financial literacy to young students in developing countries?

Well, I don't have any specific advice to offer beyond what's already been said, but I do think it's great that people like Chang are taking the initiative to educate kids about money. As for me, I'll just say that getting good habits early on is key, and I'm sure there are many talented individuals who could make a real difference by teaching financial literacy in South American schools.
What is the main goal of the 'Secret Millionaires Club' that you've been involved with?

The main goal of the 'Secret Millionaires Club' is to present good habits to young kids in an entertaining way, through a kind of comedy series. We want to teach them valuable lessons about money and habits that will benefit them throughout their lives.
How did developing good money habits at a young age impact your own life?

Developing good money habits at a young age made a huge difference in my life. I was lucky to have a head start, with around $10,000 saved up by the time I got out of college. If I hadn't had that start, my life would have been vastly different. It's a great example of how getting a jump-start on good habits can change your trajectory.
Do you plan to change Berkshire Hathaway's debt level?

No, we have no plans to change our debt level. In fact, we have virtually no debt, and if anything, we're looking to use our excess cash to make opportunistic investments, like buying a business, rather than taking on more debt.
How do you plan to use Berkshire Hathaway's excess cash?

We plan to use our excess cash, which is cash beyond $20 billion, to put to work buying a business. It's an opportunistic process, so we can't do it at an even flow, but we will get calls and we will put money to work when the right opportunity comes along.
You mentioned carrying a liability of well over $3.5 to $4 billion for something with a settlement value today of $400 million. Can you explain why it's hard to unwind this derivative trade?

Well, it's simple - the numbers just don't match up in a way that would make both parties happy. We're looking at a huge difference between the liability we carry and the current settlement value. It's like trying to sell a house for $4 billion when the market says it's only worth $400 million. Not many buyers are going to be interested in that deal, and similarly, we can't find a price for unwinding this trade that works for both us and the other party.

You also mentioned that you wouldn't want to pay down the debt Berkshire has now, and even considered taking on more debt at current prices. Can you elaborate on why you think taking on more debt might be a good idea?

It's all about the cost of money. When debt is cheap, it can be a good tool for investing. Think of it like borrowing money from a friend at a very low interest rate to invest in something that will give you a much higher return. It makes sense to use that cheap money to your advantage. However, we're not looking to take on debt just for the sake of it; we'd need to find a really attractive investment opportunity that would make it worthwhile. And even then, we'd only stretch a little, not overextend ourselves.
How has the internet impacted GEICO's business?
The internet has changed GEICO's business very, very dramatically. It's one of the many areas where technology has really made a significant difference.
Do you think the internet has made life better?

I do think the internet has made life better. For example, I can play bridge with my friends online in just a few seconds, which is a big improvement over trying to round up people to come over to my house on a snowy day.
What do you think is the key factor that has allowed China to unlock its human potential and achieve such rapid growth in recent decades?

I think it's the system they've put in place. You know, for centuries, the Chinese people were just as smart and hardworking as anyone else, but they didn't have a system that allowed them to reach their full potential. It's like having a great racehorse that's stuck in a small corral - it can't run. But when you open up the gates and give it room to run, watch out. That's what's happened in China, and I think it's a great example of what can happen when you find a system that unleashes human potential.
Do you think the rise of China as a superpower is a positive development for the United States?

Yes, I do. I think it's great that the Chinese have found a way to unlock their potential, and I think it's good for us that they're doing well. We'll have our disagreements, of course, but at the end of the day, we're both better off if the other one is doing well. It's like having a neighbor who's doing well - it's good for the whole neighborhood. And let's be realistic, we're both going to be superpowers for a long time, so we might as well figure out ways to get along and see the virtues in each other rather than the flaws.
What factors do you attribute your early success with small amounts of capital to?

I attribute my early success to having a great teacher, exceptional focus, and the right emotional qualities. I also really enjoyed the game of investing, which made a big difference. It's a game that's hard enough to be interesting but not so hard that it's beyond understanding, and that enthusiasm helped drive me to learn and succeed.
What role did Ben Graham's teachings play in your development as an investor?

Ben Graham's teachings, as outlined in 'The Intelligent Investor', were instrumental in my development as an investor. Before discovering his book, I had enthusiasm but lacked guiding principles. Graham's teachings provided me with the foundation and principles I needed to invest effectively, and they've had a lasting impact on my approach to investing.
Do you find running Berkshire more enjoyable than managing investment funds?
Yes, I do. Running Berkshire has been far, far more fun than running multiple partnerships or just an investment fund. It's incredibly more satisfying.
What do you think about making a life out of just being shrewd in picking stocks and passively holding them?
I think Charlie summed it up well - it's not enough of a life. I mean, if that's all you're doing, it would be a crazy way to go through life. There's more to life than just that.
What is the schedule for the meeting today?

Well, we've got a pretty packed schedule. We'll start with some introductions and slides, then move on to questions from our panels and the audience until about noon. We'll take a break for lunch from noon to 1 o'clock, then come back and keep going with questions until 3:30. After a short 15-minute break, we'll convene the formal meeting at 3:45.
What special topic will you be discussing at a quarter of twelve?

At a quarter of twelve, I'll be giving you a rundown on a bet that we report on every year. And tied in with that, I'll share what I think is probably the most important investment lesson in the world. I hope that'll be interesting enough to keep you all around until then!
What would you have done differently in life in your search for happiness?

Well, I'm 85 and I have to say, I'm extremely happy with how things have turned out. I made a decision early on to be my own boss, which has allowed me to avoid a lot of aggravation and do what I love with the people I love. I don't think I'd change much, to be honest!
What factors do you think are most important for achieving happiness in life?

For me, it's about doing what I love, being with people I love, and having good health. I mean, if you or your loved ones have health problems, that's a real challenge. But if you can avoid those kinds of issues, and just focus on enjoying your work and your relationships, that's a pretty good recipe for happiness.
You mentioned being lucky to have a partnership with Charlie. What makes this partnership more enjoyable for you?

Well, I think it's just more fun doing things with a partner. It's like having a friend to share the experience with, and in this case, we get to make business decisions together. I mean, it's more enjoyable to tackle challenges and celebrate successes with someone who's just as passionate about what we're doing as I am.
If you could go back in time, is there anything you would do differently in terms of your business life?

Actually, I think I would have started with a different type of company. I mentioned it lightly, but if I'm being serious, I don't think I would have started with a textile company. But that's about it - I feel incredibly fortunate with how things have turned out, so I don't have many complaints!
What's your outlook on the coal industry's impact on BNSF's revenue?

The decline in coal is a secular trend, and since coal accounts for 20 percent of our revenues, it's a significant factor. We expect BNSF to lose coal volume, but we also think it will gain in other areas.
How do you value your wholly-owned businesses, like BNSF, in relation to stock market valuations?

We don't mark up or down our wholly-owned businesses based on stock market valuations. While stock market valuations are a factor in our thinking, we know we're going to hold these businesses forever, so we don't mark them to market. We think BNSF is a terrific and valuable asset, and we're happy to hold it long-term.
You mentioned a period in 1973 and '74 where good companies were selling at huge discounts. Can you give an example of such a company?
One example that comes to mind is Cap Cities, which was run by Tom Murphy. It was a really good company that was selling at a significant discount from its intrinsic value back then.
Do you worry about Berkshire's stock being undervalued or facing financial difficulties after you're gone?

Honestly, I don't worry about it much anymore. Given how my estate will be distributed to philanthropies, it's likely that my estate will remain the largest shareholder of Berkshire for some time, which gives me peace of mind.
Why do you think pure money-type leasing is not an attractive business for Berkshire?

Well, it's quite simple really. When someone like Wells Fargo can borrow money at around 10 basis points and we can't match that, it's tough for us to compete. They've got the edge, and in a business where the main factor is the cost of funds, that edge is significant.
What's your view on getting into the aircraft leasing business?

To be honest, aircraft leasing doesn't interest me at all. It's a scary business, especially when you see people using short-term money to finance longer-term assets with big residual risks. That's just not our style at Berkshire.
What does 'widening the moat' mean to you and your business strategy?

Well, 'widening the moat' is just a fancy way of saying we're trying to make our products and services so good that it's hard for others to compete with us. We focus on turning out better products, keeping costs down, and thinking about what our customers will want from us in the future. It's like building a strong fortress that's hard to breach.
Can you give an example of a time when you recognized it was better to exit a business rather than trying to fix it?

Yes, I can. We had a department store in Baltimore back in 1966, and it was clear that it wasn't going to work out. If we'd kept it, we would have gone out of business. So, we made the tough decision to get out of that business. Recognizing reality is important - you don't want to throw good money after bad trying to fix something that's unfixable.
How do you want your directors to approach their role at Berkshire?

I want our directors to walk in the shoes of our shareholders. They should care deeply about the business and be smart enough to know when to get involved and when not to. This way, they can make informed decisions that benefit the company and our shareholders.
What is your approach to organizing and preparing for the annual meeting?

We don't have a special department for it, and we certainly don't hire consultants. Instead, it's a cooperative effort where everyone in the office pitches in to make it a success. We keep things simple and don't believe in make-work activities, which is why you won't find any committees or PowerPoint presentations around here.
How do you and Charlie Munger approach understanding businesses, and what makes it interesting to you?

Charlie and I really enjoy digging into the micro factors of every business. For instance, when we bought See's Candy in 1972, we looked at the numbers for each of their shops and watched how they performed over time. It's fascinating to us to understand how businesses work, and we find it interesting to analyze the details. It's similar to how some people enjoy watching baseball games - every aspect is engaging, and we feel the same way about understanding businesses.
What approach do you think is important when disagreeing with someone, according to Charlie Munger's philosophy?

Charlie says that if you disagree with somebody, you should be able to state their case better than they can. I think that's a great approach - it means you've really understood their perspective, and at that point, you've earned the right to disagree with them. Otherwise, as Charlie would say, you should just keep quiet.
Why do you avoid making personal investments in companies with a market cap of a couple billion dollars?

I avoid making personal investments in companies of that size because, at Berkshire's current size, we typically don't invest in companies with a market cap that small. I like to keep my personal investments separate and avoid any potential conflicts of interest with Berkshire's activities.
Do you prioritize making money for yourself or for Berkshire Hathaway?

To be honest, I'd much rather make money for Berkshire than for myself. I've got all the money I need, and at the end of the day, I'm going to give it all away anyway. My focus is on ensuring Berkshire does well, because that's what really matters to me.
What is the main goal that you and Charlie Munger think about for Berkshire Hathaway?
Our main goal is to add to the normalized earning power per share of the company every year. We believe we can achieve this by utilizing our retained earnings effectively.
Do you think it's necessary to be extremely smart to achieve a decent result in American business?

No, I don't think you have to be extremely smart. American business has been good enough that you can get a decent result without being a genius. If you can just avoid the standard stupidities, as Charlie says, you should be able to get a pretty good result.
What kind of businesses has Berkshire turned down and why?

We've turned down businesses that don't align with our values, including a big tobacco business. I'm not particularly fond of making money from running gambling casinos either, and we don't own any of those. We want to be seen as having won fairly and used our resources wisely.
How did your family influence your values and approach to business?

My family had a significant influence on me. I was lucky to have aunts who reinforced good values and a grandfather who, although tough, taught me about self-reliance. And let's not forget my Uncle Fred, who was one of the finest men my partner Charlie ever knew. They all played a role in shaping my approach to business and life.
Why don't you announce a clear successor at Berkshire Hathaway?

I don't announce a clear successor because things can change quickly, and what makes sense today might not make sense five years from now. Plus, I don't want to create a situation where someone's situation changes, and then we're stuck with a plan that no longer works. It's just more practical to keep our options open.
How do you and Charlie Munger approach decision-making and organizational structure at Berkshire Hathaway?

Charlie and I, we just try to figure out the most logical thing to do at the time. We don't follow some grand organizational design or worry about things like how many people can report to one person. We're flexible, and we make decisions based on what makes sense in the moment. And we're not afraid to change our minds if someone presents a better idea - regardless of their title or position.
What is necessary to successfully manage a portfolio in a changing world?
You have to be thinking all the time and alert to whether there's been something that really changes the game in a big way. It's a tough game, but that's what makes our job interesting.
Do you believe established players in the payments industry are at risk due to changes in the market?
Yes, I think anybody in payments, especially an established long-time player with an old method, has more danger than used to exist. There's just more fluidity in it now.
What are the two key variables you consider when evaluating business performance?
I care about two simple things: growing the business and doing so with a profitable business. It's not rocket science, but it's essential to our success.
Why do you focus on the profitability of seasoned business rather than overall profits?

Well, it's because the first year of any new business is going to be a money-loser due to all the upfront costs like advertising. I don't want our people to worry about short-term profits if they're growing the business quickly, so we look at the profitability of seasoned business to get a clearer picture.
Do you believe low oil prices are beneficial for the United States overall?
Yes, I do. As a net oil importer, low oil prices are a plus for the United States. It's like having low prices for bananas - if we're buying something, it's good for us when the price falls.
How does the decline in oil prices affect consumers and businesses in the US?

The decline in oil prices has had a mixed effect. It's very good for millions of consumers, but very bad for certain businesses, like some of the ones we've invested in, such as Lubrizol. So, it's a bit of a double-edged sword.
How does the impact of lower oil prices differ between consumers and companies with oil fields?

Well, when it comes to lower oil prices, the consumer benefits gradually over time, like when they fill up their gas tank every few weeks. On the other hand, companies with oil fields take a big hit immediately - the value of their oil field can drop significantly, even overnight, if oil prices plummet. It's like the difference between a slow and steady drip versus a sudden splash.
Who benefits and who loses when oil prices are lower, according to your analysis?

It's pretty straightforward: when oil prices are lower, the United States as a whole is better off, while Saudi Arabia is worse off. It's a big shift in the economic landscape, and some regions will feel the pain more than others, but overall, lower oil prices are a net positive for our economy.
What was Walmart's approach to its suppliers regarding payment terms?

Walmart went to their suppliers with a list of requests, one of which was to extend their payment terms. I don't recall the exact details, but they were looking to stretch out the time they take to pay their suppliers, maybe from 30 to 60 days or something like that. And from what I understand, they were pretty successful in getting many of their suppliers to agree to these new terms.
Do you think Berkshire's subsidiaries will follow Walmart's approach to extending payment terms with their suppliers?

I don't think so. We're not under the same kind of pressure for cash as some other companies, like Walmart, which is competing with Amazon. And I think our managers value having good relationships with our suppliers, so they're unlikely to start stretching out payment terms just to free up some extra cash. We've got a good thing going with our float, anyway, so we don't need to worry about that.
Do you think the depreciation expense at the railroad accurately reflects the true operating earnings?
No, I don't think it does. I believe our depreciation expense is inadequate as a measure of true operating earnings.
Why don't you provide adjusted earnings figures to potentially give a clearer picture of Berkshire's performance?

I've seen those adjusted earnings figures often result in inflated numbers, and frankly, things are good enough at Berkshire without needing to tweak the figures. I prefer to keep it straightforward and not risk misleading anyone.
What would be the impact on National Indemnity and Berkshire if Ajit Jain were to leave?
