I mean, if Congress were to suddenly decide that separating the chairman and CEO roles was a bad idea, I'm sure the index funds would change their tune pretty quickly.
You mentioned that State Farm's existence doesn't make sense under capitalism. Can you explain why?

Well, if you were to start a company like State Farm today, with its mutual structure, it's unlikely anyone would put up the capital. I mean, who wants to invest in a company where they won't see any profits? It just doesn't add up. But, of course, State Farm has a huge net worth, around $140 billion, which gives them a lot of leverage.
You brought up Progressive's investment strategy, specifically their bond holdings. What's your take on that?

I think it's interesting that they own a lot of bonds, and when their net worth dropped in the first quarter, they kind of shrugged it off. But, as I said, it's funny how some companies do what everyone else does, without really thinking it through. Peter Lewis, the former chairman of Progressive, was a smart guy, but he ignored the investment side of things, which is just as important as underwriting.
Do you think the experiences and knowledge gained in the first half of life are less valuable than those in the second half?

Well, I think the first half is necessary to get to the second half, but if I had to choose, I'd rather be judged by the second half of my life. I believe that with 30 or 40 years of experience, you learn a lot more about how people behave and that makes you a better person.
Would you or Charlie Munger want to be remembered more for your accomplishments in the first or second half of your life?

I'd definitely say the second half. In fact, Charlie doesn't even like to think about what he did when he was young because it would embarrass him. I feel the same way - I'd rather be remembered for who I am and what I've accomplished later in life.
Can Berkshire Hathaway protect itself against the risk of a nuclear attack?

No, we can't protect against the risk of nuclear weapons. As Charlie said, there's no way to protect against a big nuclear attack. It's a very, very dangerous world, and unfortunately, the major problem is with people that have large stocks of nuclear weapons and ICBMs.
How do you view the likelihood of a nuclear event occurring, given the current circumstances?

I think it's a very, very tiny risk, but it's still a risk every day. It's like rolling a pair of dice - everything will happen if you just keep rolling them. The world is essentially flipping a coin every day as to whether people who can destroy the planet will do it.
What was the original price you paid for the department store stock, and how does that compare to its potential value today if it had succeeded?

We paid $6 a share for that stock. If the department store had succeeded, it might be worth around $30 a share now. But, as it turned out, it failed, and we ended up doing much better by merging it into Berkshire - now it's worth something like $150,000 a share.
What lesson did you and Charlie Munger learn from this experience?

Well, Charlie said it best - we were stupid to get into it in the first place! But the real lesson is to keep learning. You just keep going, and that's the secret. Even when things don't work out as planned, you can still end up doing well if you learn from your mistakes and keep moving forward.
How does knowing more than one discipline help in making investment decisions and in life?

Well, let me tell you, it's like having more than one tool in your toolbox. If all you have is a hammer, everything starts to look like a nail. But when you know more than one discipline, you can approach problems from different angles and make more informed decisions. As Charlie said, it helps you avoid wrong decisions and think more critically.
Do you think being multi-disciplinary can sometimes be seen as a negative, like when you irritate experts in a particular field?

Yes, I've seen that happen to Charlie, and I'm sure it's happened to me too. When you come into someone's territory and say, 'I think I know better,' it can be a bit annoying. But that's just the way it is. If you're going to be multi-disciplinary, you've got to be willing to take a few knocks and ruffle some feathers.
How do you view Berkshire, and what analogy do you use to describe it?
I look at Berkshire as a painting, with an ever-expanding canvas where I get to paint what I want. It's a unique way for me to think about the company, and I enjoy the freedom it represents.
Do you have a personal interest in art or paintings?
Honestly, I don't know much about paintings and I'm not particularly interested in them. If you took me to an art museum, I'd probably be looking for the men's room more than anything else.
What happened with the number that floats around every day that you and Arthur Andersen couldn't find in 12 years?

Well, it's quite simple really. We had to make our assets equal to our liabilities, so we just had to account for it somehow. It's one of those strange things that happen in the world of finance, and I've joked about it being like a 'floating plug' - but essentially, we had to find a way to balance our books, even if it meant dealing with a mysterious number that we couldn't quite track down.
You suggested an experiment to compare how different parties value the same derivative contracts. What did you propose and why?

I proposed taking a random sample of 100 complicated derivative contracts and comparing how each side of the contract values them. I think it would be fascinating to see if there are significant discrepancies between what one party thinks a contract is worth and what the other party thinks it's worth, even if they're using the same auditing firm. It's a simple idea, but I think it could reveal some interesting insights into the world of accounting and finance.
What was the outcome of Charlie's letter to the insurance company chairman regarding the $12,000 claim?

Well, I'll tell you, it's a great story. The chairman got Charlie's letter, and by return mail, we got a check for the full $12,000. It just goes to show you that sometimes, all it takes is a little creative thinking to get what you're owed.
What strategy did Charlie use to persuade the insurance company to pay the claim?

Charlie's strategy was brilliant. He proposed a simple wager: if the insurance company won the dispute, he'd pay them $120,000, but if they lost, they'd have to pay him $120,000. By doing so, he made it worth his while to pursue the claim, and more importantly, made it clear that the insurance company's refusal to pay was likely due to their advantageous bargaining position. It was a clever way to call their bluff, and it worked like a charm.
